title: Struggle for Survival: The Hispanic Land Grants of New Mexico, 1848–2001
abstract: Abstract At the end of the Mexican-American War in 1848, the United States annexed what had been the Mexican Department of New Mexico, and as it did, it absorbed millions of acres of agro-pastoral land whose parcels had been under a communal system of ownership by Mexican citizen-villagers. From the heirs’ point of view, the subsequent American system of adjudicating ownership of these traditional properties proved inadequate, leading to the loss of two-thirds of their commons to American land speculators and the U. S. National Forest. Like the Native Americans, the heirs of these grants have long seethed in resentment over the steady erosion of their hold on their traditional lands and culture. This article outlines the processes of despoliation of the land grants from their original owners, and, more centrally, suggests the historical cycles of collective struggle that the heirs have mounted since the 1840s in order to retain and wrest back their commons, as well as organize the grants that they have been able to secure. A stubborn land-grant movement has gone through various forms of collective action including clandestine violence, protest confrontation, legal strategies, and political lobbying. In the most recent phase, activists have hopeful signs that the U.S. Congress is ready to respond to their demand for return of commons now under federal jurisdiction.

title: Urban Demand and Agrarian Productivity in Pre-Plague England: Reassessing the Relevancy of von Thunen’s Model
abstract: Abstract The article addresses the question as to whether manorial estates in pre-plague England were responsive to market stimuli, as the authors of a 1993 study have argued based on a model originally proposed by the nineteenth century agricultural economist Johann von Thunen. By testing three hypotheses referring to the degree of commercial orientation, levels of intensity regarding various inputs, and the spatial configuration of field systems, the paper concludes that the productive profiles of these estates did not conform very closely to the expectations of von Thunen’s model. The explanation lies in the fact that, by having access to the seigneurial prerogative of tapping into their peasants’ resources, manorial estates were not hard pressed to maximize profitability through a drive towards efficiency.

title: Paradox of Precision: Bright Tobacco as Technology Transfer, 1880-1937
abstract: This article compares two episodes of technology transfer in the 1890s: the movement of bright tobacco production technology to south-central Africa with the spread of the crop to eastern North Carolina and South Carolina. It finds similarities in the people who introduced the crop, but significant differences in the methods used to produce it. This is troubling because the type is defined by the cultivation and especially the curing techniques used to produce it; it is also often described in the historical literature as "Virginia tobacco," even when grown elsewhere. the technological differences are the product of different environments, which include not only the climate but also many elements of the technological system beyond immediate human control: the availability and organization of labor, differences in market structures and marketing institutions, and the government incentives provided to buyers. Therefore, this essay takes as its subject the paradox inherent in the official classification of tobacco types regulated by the USDA and argues that varietal types represent a form of market regulation disguised as botanical taxonomy.

title: <i>Reassessing The Roots of Southern Populism</i> Matthew Hild—Georgia Institute of Technology
The Far-From-Dry Debates: Dry Farming on the Canadian Prairies and the American Great Plains
abstract: The absence of dry farming techniques is the key element that many Canadian scholars use to explain the decade of delay in the agricultural development of the prairie region after the completion of the Canadian Pacific Railway in 1885. They have assumed that American farmers had developed an unproblematic set of techniques, the presence of which was essential before large-scale European settlement of the Prairies could begin. American historians of Great Plains agriculture present a far different picture of those American farmers. Dry farming in the United States did not designate an agreed-upon set of techniques, but a lively field of debate that remained unresolved for decades. Summer fallow comprised the essential practice on the driest Canadian Prairies for the conservation of moisture. Americans neither pioneered nor promoted it first; summer fallow only became general practice on the northern Great Plains after Canadian farmers had demonstrated how it could be practicably done. The flow of this agricultural innovation turns out to have been the opposite of what most Canadian scholars had assumed.

title: Rural Sociology and Democratic Planning in the Third New Deal
abstract: Abstract In the early 1940s, the agricultural New Deal was broader and more democratic than those aspects of it that survived World War II. Carl C. Taylor, who led the sociological research unit in the USDA’s Bureau of Agricultural Economics, and other rural sociologists shared a two-handed commitment to democracy. They merged social science with local knowledge and integrated federal action with citizen participation. These activist principles were best exemplified in a Third New Deal program called county land-use planning, within which sociologists played two roles. First, they "delineated" the boundaries of rural neighborhoods and communities so that the best representation of citizens on the local planning committees was obtained. With local citizen-researchers, Taylor’s sociologists delineated eleven thousand rural neighborhoods and nearly two thousand communities in thirty-two states. Second, they evaluated the planning program in a few select counties. The richest assessment was Arthur F. Raper’s study of Greene County, Georgia, "Tenants of the Almighty." He found that, despite racism, the program made tremendous physical, economic, and psychological gains among the county’s poor blacks and whites. However, a conservative Congress aborted the federal democratic-planning program in 1942; soon thereafter these anti-New Dealers banished critical social science from the USDA. The likes of which have not been seen since, at least not in the United States.

title: "Esteeme a Little of Fish": Fish, Fishponds, and Farming in Eighteenth–Century New England and the Mid–Atlantic
abstract: Abstract Prior to the advent of scientific aquaculture in the mid-nineteenth century, English farming manuals of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries instructed American colonists in the "art of husbandry," imparting advice and passing on the best-known strategies for keeping and rearing fish in enclosed ponds. The development of such ponds in the New England and Mid-Atlantic colonies during the eighteenth century marked the culmination of a long process by which British-American colonists adapted to declines in natural fish populations brought on by over-fishing and disruption of habitat by water-powered mills. The development of private fish-ponds as an increasingly important component of American mixed husbandry practices in long-settled areas by the end of the eighteenth century illustrates early American farmers’ ability to successfully adapt to self-wrought changes in their physical environment.

title: Clearing Swamps, Harvesting Forests: Trees and the Making of a Plantation Landscape in the Colonial South Carolina Lowcountry
abstract: Abstract English colonists and African slaves began occupying the South Carolina Lowcountry in the late seventeenth century. During the eighteenth century thousands of slaves cleared thousands of acres of swamplands to create the colony’s signature rice fields and secure its place within the Atlantic economy. This essay examines the changing perceptions and uses of trees as the key to understanding how planters transformed a perceived wilderness into one of British America’s wealthiest and most repressive plantation societies. Colonists used trees to assess and understand the land’s capacity for market agriculture. Slaves cleared land of its wood to prepare the terrain for planting, provide Britain’s empire with vital commodities, and build the infrastructure of daily material life in the region. As colonists and slaves came into sustained engagement with this landscape they learned to exploit its distinctive natural resources more intensively. This transformation is better understood as a process of agricultural adaptation than as an episode in environmental degradation.

title: The Squatter and Natural Law in Nineteenth-Century America
abstract: Abstract In the decade before the California Gold Rush, the popular idea that Americans held a natural right to land as a legacy of the American Revolution was enriched and expanded by such events as the Dorr Rebellion in Rhode Island, the Anti-Rent War in New York, the flood of Irish refugees into New York City, growing opposition to the expansion of slavery into new territories acquired during the war with Mexico, and the Revolution of 1848 in Europe. These events strengthened popular sovereignty and the notion that human beings had rights that transcended those defined by legislatures, courts, or even constitutions. They also promoted a new discussion of how values within the United States differed from those in Europe--where land was scarce and served as the foundation for aristocratic regimes and sharp class differences. The squatter was a ubiquitous figure on every frontier of the United States, but none more than California, where both town sites and agricultural land were covered by Mexican land grants that took decades to define and confirm. This article tells the story of how powerful forces in California undermined squatter rights--and the heritage of the American Revolution as well.

title: Beyond the Monolith of Modernity: New Trends in Immigrant and Ethnic Rural History
abstract: Abstract This article suggests that the idea of "modernization," the uni-linear transition from peasantry to commercial agriculture, has shaped much of the writing of rural immigrant communities during the twentieth century. It also suggests that the history of immigrant and ethnic farm communities has begun to take a different tack during the last decade. This change reflects trends in the broader historiography of settlement society, including a shift from social history to cultural history. Modernity is no longer seen as an unrelenting force, natural and dominant in character. Rather postmodernity’s concern with fragmentation and asymmetry, and the linguistic turn with its fixation on cultural invention and created mythology, seemed evident. Regional, national, and international-based studies alike reflect this new research agenda, and this article highlights seven books in particular. Three, focusing on settler society and rural culture in regional, national, and transnational variations, describe modernity in particular; they see the very idea of change, once seen as inevitable and inexorable, as constructed, invented, and contrived. Three others are local studies of specific ethnic rural groups in which the immigrant or ethnic farm community stands at a cross current to a commercializing countryside, contesting and subverting the very intentions of the agents of the market economy and state interests. The final book is the author’s own recent work in comparative history, Diaspora in the Countryside: Two Mennonite Communities and Mid-Twentieth Century Rural Disjuncture. The two central words "diaspora" and "disjuncture" suggests that these communities, one located in Canada and the other in the United States, responded to economic changes through a diversity of lifeworlds, including farm commercialization, urbanization, and a conservative recreation of an old order agraria. These Mennonites created a set of contradictory mythologies and master narratives that sought to bring teleological sense, social order, and meaning to inchoate and fragmented cultures. The seven books thus acknowledge quotidian complexity, ethnic variation, and national and regional difference. They are representative of what appears to be a wider trend in the academy of North American rural history.

title: Egyptian Agricultural Labor Under Ptolemy Philadelphus
Australian agricultural historiography: A survey
The Great Plains: Agriculture and the Environment in the Late Twentieth Century
abstract: The significance of the environment is as clearly understood by all men and women who live on the Great Plains today as it was by those who settled the region during the nineteenth century. Drought, searing sun, blizzards and sub-zero temperatures, and hail storms with tornadic winds at harvest time continue to make agricultural life on the Great Plains matters of perseverance and adaptation. Although the term environment is well-known, however, the concept of environmentalism is relatively new. And, while it is largely understood in the context of conservation, that is, the protection of nature, those who have lived on the Great Plains have been environmentalists in other contexts throughout the history of the region. In little more than a century, the residents of the plains have used the concepts of the change, control, and preservation of nature to govern their relationships with the en? vironment and, by so doing, make both settlement and agriculture possible on the Great Plains.

title: A Currant Affair: E. D. Smith and Agricultural Change in Nineteenth-Century Saltfleet Township, Ontario
abstract: L'article analyse l'influence du milieu naturel et de l'environnement direct des agriculteurs d'une petite ville de l'Ontario sur la reussite et la richesse de leurs exploitations. L'auteur prend l'exemple de E.D. Smith, un fermier de la ville de Saltfleet pour expliquer sa theorie et nomme les variables environnementales, elements-cles de la reussite agricole de ce village, la proximite d'une source et l'emplacement geographique.

title: The Transformation of the Dutch Farm Horse into a Riding Horse: Livestock Breeding, Science, and “Modernization,” 1960s–1980s
abstract: This article analyzes the postwar transformation of the Dutch Warmblood farm horse into a riding horse. It gives special attention to the farmers’ practical breeding methods and to the role that scientists and government policymakers played in the transformation process. Until the 1970s, Warmblood breeding methods were a continuation of pre-Mendelian methods that focused on qualitative assessment of a horse’s conformation, that is, its exterior characteristics. In 1980, the Dutch government undertook an effort to modernize Warmblood breeding by turning it into a collectively organized, scientific enterprise. These plans were largely subverted by the fierce opposition of breeders. Nevertheless, quantitative scientific methods, particularly quantitative genetics, started to make inroads into Warmblood breeding at the time. However, the breeders’ decision to switch to quantitative methods was a reaction to other pressures, economic and otherwise, rather than a response to the government’s call for science-based modernization. Moreover, qualitative assessment remained as important in the selection of breeding stock as before.

title: Introduction
Enslavers’ Big Lie
abstract: The combination of environmental history and Atlantic history seems like a natural one. After all, the process of forging the Atlantic World wrought vast ecological transformations on every continent bordering its oceanic basin, and environmental conditions helped shape the boundaries, success, and economies of post-Columbian Indigenous and European societies in the Americas. For many years, however, the scholarship of environmental history and Atlantic history developed largely in parallel rather than in conversation (with some notable exceptions).1 The question is not whether Atlantic history has environmental aspects that can be explored—it does, and scholars such as Alfred Crosby, J. R. McNeill, Keith Pluymers, Marcy Norton, Matthew Mulcahy, Judith Carney, and others have pointed these out—but whether an explicitly environmental perspective can shed light on the major questions that have traditionally driven Atlantic historians.2 Katherine Johnston shows that it can.The Nature of Slavery uses a fine-grained analysis of eighteenth-century perceptions of climate, environmental change, and nature's relationship to human health to comment on several long-standing debates in Atlantic history regarding the politics of slavery and the origins of race. Johnston focuses on the British Greater Caribbean, a region encompassing the British islands in the West Indies together with the Carolina-Georgia Lowcountry. As Matthew Mulcahy lays out in Hubs of Empire (2014), the sites of the British Greater Caribbean shared history, socioeconomic factors, majority populations of enslaved Africans, and, crucially for Johnston's study, environmental factors such as climate and endemic diseases. During the early modern period, the real and perceived environmental hazards of the British Greater Caribbean gave rise to the belief that the plantation economy could only succeed with enslaved Africans as the primary labor force. The climate was too inhospitable for whites to successfully cultivate the land. Or, at least, that is what planters publicized.Johnston argues that enslavers in the British Greater Caribbean deliberately deployed the "climatic defense of slavery"—that "Black bodies were suited to hot climates while white bodies were not"—in direct contradiction to their own experiences and knowledge (3). There was at the time no understanding of climate, health, or environment that supported such a claim. Enslavers knew Africans were no more suited to the West Indies or South Carolina than Europeans were. They said so privately and at length. However, over time, white colonists recognized that the climatic justification of slavery was an effective, politically palatable narrative that gave the practice "the unquestionable authority of nature" (194). It was "manufactured rhetoric," a Big Lie, a narrative constructed not because of planters' personal observations or the medical ideas of the time, but in spite of them (4).The premise of the book, then, is simple. Twenty-first-century readers know very well that people sometimes espouse beliefs with which they do not agree for political or financial gain, so it seems reasonable to suggest that enslavers looking to protect the source of their wealth would do the same. Yet the case that Johnston builds to prove her claim is remarkably complex. Over six chapters that span the mid-seventeenth century to the mid-nineteenth century, The Nature of Slavery tackles several pillars of enslavers' environmental excuses. It reminds us that white Europeans had a long history of successfully cultivating the lands of the Greater Caribbean, uncovers the economic or social grievances undergirding planters' public-facing climatic rhetoric, documents medical and environmental theories of the time, and breaks down planters' observations on the relative health of Black bodies versus white ones.Threaded throughout the first two chapters of the book is a confrontation with one of the enduring questions of Atlantic history: Why slavery, and why Africans? The labor force of the early Atlantic World was a decidedly mixed bag. Wage laborers, convicts, indentured servants, redemptioners, enslaved Indigenous peoples, and enslaved Africans were all present in emerging agro-capitalist colonial economies. By the eighteenth century, however, enslaved Africans made up the majority of the labor force, particularly in the Atlantic Plantation Complex, to borrow Philip Curtain's term. This shift, often abbreviated as "the labor transition," happened at different times in different places, and historians have long debated the timing and reasons for it. Some historians emphasize the role of cultural factors in planters' pursuit of enslaved Africans, such as European perceptions of "Blackness" or a sense of cultural unity within Europe that created insider-outsider ideologies. Others highlight the legal status that made enslaved African labor more attractive to planters and the economic practicalities given the high cost of recruiting and keeping European labor.3Johnston seemingly has no problem with all of the above being true in the Greater Caribbean, although she mentions economic factors most often. She is more concerned with what was not responsible for the labor transition. The labor transition was not, Johnston asserts, due to colonial understandings of climate's effect on the body. It was not because planters believed Black bodies fared better in Caribbean or Lowcountry environments. After all, the region's planters went to great lengths to attract white European laborers even after the labor transition, which, for her, means they knew whites could survive. She then uses the history of early Georgia to prove that they could, focusing on the well-worn but still apt example of the Salzburger community's success. She also sifts through the private writings of planters during the decades when the Georgia Trustees prohibited African slavery. In an admirable example of what a close reading of primary sources can illuminate, Johnston uncovers the ulterior motives of the group called the Malcontents, who campaigned for the removal of the prohibition on African slavery, taking readers through the various arguments they used before landing on a climate-based justification. Petitions claiming Georgia was too hot for white labor acted as a useful "smokescreen for other grievances" and succeeded largely because the rhetoric tapped into preexisting rumors of the region circulating in the metropole (13).Certainly, Johnston's assertion that planters knew white bodies could labor in the Greater Caribbean runs up against the well-established English "fear of hot climates," as introduced by Karen Kupperman in the early 1980s and taken up by several scholars since.4 The characterizations of the colonies disseminated in the metropole were that the tropical climate would injure English bodies, spread disease, and cause unwanted physiological changes. Events in the Caribbean conspired to confirm such suspicions, such as the disastrous Western Design military campaign of the 1650s. As a result of such damning reports of European experience in tropics, the only conclusion was that "venturing to the islands was likely nothing short of a death sentence" (27). Johnston does not refute others' work on early modern assumptions about tropical climates but rather points out that those who lived in the colonies had much more complex beliefs about "hot climates" than those who lived in London. Only headline-grabbing disasters in the Greater Caribbean made it back across the Atlantic, while private declarations of planters' good health or salubrious surroundings did not. Furthermore, the definition of "healthy" was deeply nuanced and hyperlocal. Johnston examines colonists' manipulation of their local environments, homes, and their debates over the location of towns and military barracks to demonstrate that colonists did not think the region was uniformly dangerous. Johnston writes, "For settler-colonists who lived in these places, climatic nuance—a sense of microclimates dependent upon a region's elevation, proximity to stagnant or moving water, and air flow . . . was essential to determining which places were healthy or unhealthy" (76). To say the region was feared for being "too hot" does not necessarily capture on-the-ground beliefs in the colonies themselves.This section of the book—chapter 3—is the only place where Johnston's work deals with material environmental conditions in a substantive way. Although some of her previous work more fully explored deforestation, drought, and planters' alterations to the physical landscape, The Nature of Slavery is concerned primarily with ideas about nature, disease, and heat rather than the land, infections, or climate itself.5 In this way, Johnston's work stands apart from much of the scholarship on the environmental history of American slavery, and especially US slavery, as it has developed so far. Given the title, I expected the book to resemble Mart Stewart's seminal "What Nature Suffers to Groe" (1996), a study of how white planters and the enslaved lived within nature on the Georgia coast. Stewart's work illuminates how the enslaved helped shape the natural landscape, and in turn, how the landscape left marks on their bodies, provided them with sustenance and a measure of independence, and dictated their daily tasks. Similarly, US slavery's first stand-alone environmental history, David Silkenat'sScars on the Land (2022), deals with how the enslaved transformed and experienced a variety of physical environments from forests and mines to farms and furnaces. Environmental histories of slavery in Latin America and the Caribbean also seem primarily concerned with tracking material environmental change.6 Less has been done on the historical climate of the US South or the Caribbean. Still, Sam White'sA Cold Welcome (2017) or Michael Chenoweth's study of Jamaica's eighteenth-century climate show the benefits of including such analysis.7 Johnston's focus on ideas of the environment, rather than the environment itself, thus helps diversify this body of scholarship. However, her approach—centered as it is on the words of white colonists—means she spends considerably less time foregrounding the voices, lives, and identities of actual enslaved people than some other works.This tendency to skirt discussions of the physical environment also affects Johnston's treatment of the material reality of disease in chapter 4, an examination of eighteenth-century notions of seasoning and race. Her evidence shows that medical observers saw no discernible difference between the mortality rates of Blacks versus whites in the Greater Caribbean, and colonists clearly recognized both groups were vulnerable to the same illnesses. Furthermore, planters would have believed that any newcomer to the Greater Caribbean was at risk of illness until they were seasoned. In eighteenth-century understandings of health and well-being, both white and Black bodies required a period of adjustment to the temperature, humidity, and other environmental features of any new location—even if only moving from one plantation to another on the same island. For eighteenth-century colonists, then, "bodies were not fixed entities" subject to the strict Black-white binary (119). Rather, "all bodies were susceptible to the same environmental dangers" (121). Because planters would have not seen illness as related to skin color, and because they would have blamed any fevers or illness on excessively wet weather, lack of seasoning, or even poor behavior on the part of the victim, and because she does not see any evidence that planters acted on any observations of differing rates of illness, Johnston seemingly dismisses historians' efforts to think about what effect malaria, yellow fever, yaws, and other infectious diseases had on the changing composition of Greater Caribbean populations.In fact, Johnston directly calls out scholars who adhere to what could be called the epidemiological explanation for the labor transition. Beginning with the work of Philip Curtin in the 1960s, some scholars interested in the intersection of Atlantic and environmental history have examined the differential impacts of the Americas' disease landscape on enslaved Africans and Europeans, positing that race-based slavery may have seemed more practical than European indentures in part because men and women forcibly brought from West Africa had genetic or acquired immunity to a number of diseases—most notably, malaria and yellow fever.8 The fact that enslaved Africans in the Caribbean perhaps contracted less virulent forms of or died at slightly lower rates from certain diseases had nothing to do with race but rather resulted from where they were born or their longer-term ancestry. However, seventeenth- and eighteenth-century observers might have seen varying mortality as racial, evidence that hot climates punished white bodies differently than Black ones. As Rana Hogarth discusses in Medicalizing Blackness (2017), there was a myth of innate Black immunity to yellow fever that endured long after it was proven untrue.9 Johnston, however, downplays the usefulness of historical epidemiology in understanding why planters would or did employ a manufactured climatic justification of slavery, calling it "an anachronistic view of racialized health" (194). She goes further in her discursive notes, writing that "it does not do justice to historical actors to apply modern diagnoses to past illnesses" (242n13).Admittedly, reconstructing past disease environments is tricky work. A historian has to understand epidemiology; have access to a range of textual, archaeological, and genetic evidence; and be able to wade through a past era's medical understanding (or lack thereof). Thus, it is far easier to retroactively diagnose a disease such as yellow fever that had unmistakable symptoms than, say, influenza, which could be confused with other illnesses. Furthermore, infections and what they do to bodies can change over time—just look at COVID-19's evolution over the last few years. However, if a disease has been stable over centuries, as some have been, and if historians have evidence that points to a clear set of symptoms, then scholars can use epidemiological history to provide a more richly textured picture of the past. Early modern medical practitioners may not have definitively diagnosed cases of malaria—as Johnston points out, it could have been confused with any number of "fevers"—but there is overwhelming evidence that a portion of enslaved people of West African descent carried the sickle cell gene that afforded some protection against malaria from Plasmodium falciparum. Once falciparum malaria was established in the Greater Caribbean, people of West African ancestry, on average, would have been less affected by that strain than others in the region.10 Johnston's argument about theories of seasoning being the primary lens through which planters and physicians viewed infection rates, rather than along lines of Black versus white, is an important point to make, and it should change how scholars talk about the construction of biological race during these crucial decades. But it is possible to accept that planters did not turn to enslaved Africans for epidemiological reasons without dismissing the material realities of the Greater Caribbean's disease environment.All of the ideas Johnston explored in the first four chapters come together in the fifth, which covers Parliament's investigation of and debates over the transatlantic slave trade. These debates acted as a catalyst for turning unfocused notions of seasoning, health, and the environment into a clear ideology that relied on bodily difference to justify Black enslavement in the Americas. In other words, while the role of climate in the debates themselves was relatively minor, the consolidation of a streamlined climatic narrative was essential evidence for developing ideas of biological race. Johnston writes, "If each body only suited a particular climate, then those bodies must be different internally as well as externally" (156). Again, she uses very fine-grained readings of public versus private testimony in these parliamentary debates to lay bare the contradictions of planters' arguments. On the one hand, planters had to maintain that Africans suited the West Indian environment, and whites did not. On the other, they had to explain why Africans were dying at such high rates that the slave trade needed to continue and why whites were still successfully cultivating land there. Of course, Caribbean planters were not the only entrants into late eighteenth-century considerations of climate and race. Anya Zilberstein'sA Temperate Empire (2016) elucidates similarly twisty logic happening around the same time in a more northerly British colony, Nova Scotia, as officials tried to convince Jamaican maroons and administrators in the metropole that Black bodies could, in fact, thrive in cold places.The solidification of rhetoric that linked climate to biological race explored in chapter 5 had effects that rippled outward through the nineteenth century. Johnston's sixth and final chapter moves out of the Caribbean, back to North America, tracking the climatic justification for racial slavery through major political events of US history from roughly 1790 to 1870. The notion that only Black bodies could labor in the heat was so widely accepted by this point that it became an "axiom too difficult to dislodge" (157). Its popularity also remade antebellum abolitionist rhetoric. In the previous chapter, Johnston showed how abolitionists made use of climatic assumptions to prove planters' brutality toward the enslaved. Here, Johnston discusses the role of climatic ideas in abolitionist arguments over colonization—the removal of African Americans from the United States to Africa so free Blacks could escape racism or reenslavement. Although most Black Americans denied the validity of climatic rhetoric, it was so widespread they had to engage with it. Frederick Douglass, for instance, asserted that the linkage of climate and race was a "miserable pretence . . . for getting us out of this country" (171). But antebellum colonization schemes were not the only resettlement projects proposed for free Blacks in the United States. As Ikuko Asaka writes in Tropical Freedom (2017), there were several attempts, from the American Revolution to Reconstruction, to displace free African Americans from so-called temperate zones to the tropics thanks to the climate determinism established in the eighteenth century. Johnston spends little time on this longer history of resettlement in the United States, although she does mention how perceived post–Civil War labor shortages caused planters to completely reverse their positions on the possibility of white labor in the South's climate. Instead, she concludes the chapter with a brief mention of environmental racism. Over the long term, she argues, tying Black bodies to hot climates not only shaped ideas about emancipation but also justified the deliberate placing of people of color in hazardous environments long before the term "environmental racism" was coined.In the end, The Nature of Slavery is an ambitious work, not only for its temporal or geographic scope but also for the number of historiographies in which it seeks to intervene. Sitting as it does at the intersection of Atlantic and environmental history, this book will certainly interest practitioners of both. In its drive to prove its basic premise, however, The Nature of Slavery sometimes misses opportunities to explore subjects it introduces and then drops, such as the place of Indigenous peoples in climatic justifications for enslavement or, for that matter, the idea of eighteenth-century environmental racism. Nevertheless, Johnston's core argument invites us all to reconsider the stories behind the archival or published sources we frequently use in our work. What other records are we looking at uncritically? What other Big Lies might we be repeating?

title: Wetlands in a Dry Land: More-Than-Human Histories of Australia's Murray-Darling Basin
abstract: O'Gorman explains in the introduction to this book that she went into the archives interested in the politics of water allocation for rice farming and unexpectedly found that much of the documentation concerned the ducks that enjoyed these anthropogenic wetlands. This then led her to think about the ways in which human societies are enmeshed in complex ecosystems with other species, and to explore various case studies about these species. The use of the plural "histories" in the title is quite appropriate since the book is not a single narrative but a series of case studies of different areas far apart from one another.As a Canadian historian of China's wetlands with little knowledge of Australia, I approached this book curious about wet places and the comparative history of Anglo settler colonialism. I am presumably not the only one who knows little about Australia's environmental history, judging from the fact that this is the first work on Australia's environmental history published in either of the two most venerable environmental history book series (by Cambridge and Washington University Presses). The introduction is well designed to convince Australian readers of the importance of approaching the region's history from a multispecies perspective but does not provide ill-informed foreigners like myself with enough background information on Australian geography, history, or historiography. Nonetheless, O'Gorman keeps the focus on the big issues that outsiders can relate to. I found it clear and engaging throughout.The book begins with a chapter on the contemporary politics of weaving. Beginning with a discussion of how Aboriginal women living at the mouth of the river have long used wetland sedges to weave, the chapter moves on to a broader discussion of how women in other regions use weaving as a way of maintaining traditions and building bonds. Unsurprisingly, when officials decide how water is allocated, Aboriginals usually get the short end of the stick, and they are disadvantaged in other ways, such as being prohibited by law for using wetlands for profit (this reminded me of the politics of wild rice cultivation in North America). The connections between Aboriginal people and wetlands remains a theme throughout the book, as does the importance of including them in discussions about wetland management.Chapter 2 focuses on the history of the town of Toowomba, built in the swamps in the upper reaches of the Darling River basin, from the arrival of European colonists in the mid-nineteenth century until the 1930s. The town dealt with flooding, pollution, and mosquitos, and O'Gorman does a good job of situating this history in the broader context of ideas of social regulation and disease in that period. These ideas return in the subsequent chapter, on the concern over malaria in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area during the First and Second World Wars and the anti-mosquito campaigns.The following three chapters focus on birds, and I found them the most enjoyable of the book. While birds in much of the Northern Hemisphere tend to migrate seasonally, the limiting feature of the Australian climate for many birds is not seasonal change but unpredictable longer-term climatic fluctuations, which force them to move where conditions are good at any given time without any fixed pattern. Chapter 4 explores how birds adapted to human modification of wetlands, such as irrigating large areas to grow rice, in the same Murrumbidgee region. The diversion of increasing amounts of water to rice paddies over the course of the twentieth century unsurprisingly attracted many ducks, and this chapter provides a fascinating account of the scientists that researched them, farmers who accused them of eating crops, and the growth of environmental protection in Australia.Chapter 5 explores the history of pelicans at the mouth of the river. European colonists initially slaughtered them as rivals for fish, but they then became a focus for conservation. The next chapter turns to the government itself, showing how international agreements on migratory birds became a key tool of the federal government for protecting wetlands. It is a good study of what types of cultural and administrative factors affect which ecosystems are and are not protected.Like the first chapter, the final one is mostly situated in the present, but it contains an insightful discussion of the uses to which history is put in conservation debates. A large increase in the number of protected seals in the river's estuary has reduced the ability of people to live by fishing there, and the chapter does a good job of considering how workers in an extractive industry (fishing) think about many of the issues discussed in the book. The conclusion correctly emphasizes that the types of histories discussed in the book provide important insights into how Australia's wetlands as they become even more unpredictable as the climate changes.This brief summary does not do justice to the many topics addressed in the book or its many insights, and I would encourage anyone interested in similar issues in other parts of the world—especially Anglo settler colonies—to read it. Despite vast differences of ecology, these regions were all settled as part of the same historical process, and anyone who studies any of them should be aware of what aspects of these processes are shared across space, and which are unique to specific places.

title: The Second Hungarian Conquest of the Carpathian Basin
abstract: Abstract During the nineteenth century many European scientists shared the view that a nation could compete successfully if only it improved its landscape via new infrastructures, such as large reclamation and river regulation projects, and via the intensive use of natural resources—for example, the scientifically planned use of forests. This “high” modernization path orchestrated by the political and scientific elites of Hungary sought to consolidate control over resources, landscapes, and competing ethnic groups and was in many respects similar to the many other versions of high modernism in Europe at the time. This version, however, represented a particular vision closely linked to the ecological systems of the Middle Danube area. Although questions of the political, economic, and technological “rise” of Hungary have attracted scholarly attention for centuries, historians have not fully explored the ecological consequences of modernization. Three of these consequences—deforestation, desertification, and flooding—are the subjects of this article. More broadly, the article aims to show how the political and economic goals of nationalism produced a science of ecological domination.

title: The Dread Plague and the Cow Killers: The Politics of Animal Disease in Mexico and the World
abstract: If a history of an animal disease campaign does not conjure images of assassinations, lynchings, torture, peasant riots, parachuting ice, cowboys drinking cattle vaccines at gunpoint, and archival incinerations, Thomas Rath's history of the Mexico–United States Commission for the Prevention of Foot and Mouth Disease (CMAEFA) is here to correct the record. Between 1947 and 1954, CMAEFA inspected more animals than any other animal disease campaign in history, boasted a budget greater than that of the early Marshall Plan, encountered hundreds of incidents of civil disobedience, and produced the most detailed maps of Mexico to date. The end result, according to Rath and the governments that led the effort, was a campaign "unequalled in the annals of animal-disease eradication," shaping Mexican modernization efforts and the Cold War creation of international animal disease networks (3).Stressing the impossibility of distilling a linear narrative of the campaign to address the "crisis" created by foot-and-mouth-disease, or aftosa, in Mexico during the postwar period, Rath instead foregrounds a multiplicity of perspectives over six chapters, based largely on US records of the commission that Rath claims has remained untouched other than by US Department of Agriculture researchers. After a brief history of the role of livestock in Mexican state formation through the postrevolutionary period in chapter 1, Rath turns to the "high politics" of the commission, examining the political choices and negotiations between the United States and Mexican governments that guided the commission's early direction. While initially driven by the US government's preference for slaughter, the commission was met with fierce opposition on the ground. Chapter 3 examines the full breadth of this resistance, and it is here that Rath's archival work shines. Compiling a database of over 450 incidents of civil disobedience, Rath details a cross-class, if largely uncoordinated, rural mobilization that successfully catalyzed a reversal in policy toward vaccination. This concession was one of many that the commission made in response to the extensive opposition, the subject of chapter 4. Rath makes clear that just as critical to the commission's "success" were its selective use of violence and terror, new information networks, and secrecy and bribes to a wide variety of Mexican interest groups, which ultimately resulted in the commission's "success."With aftosa largely eradicated, the book's final chapters examine the outbreak's lasting consequences. Chapter 5 turns to the domestic, showing how the absence of aftosa and the creation of new livestock institutions catalyzed an expansion and modernization of Mexico's livestock industry. Historians of Mexico, in particular, will benefit from Rath's engagement with the implications of CMAEFA for the country's postrevolutionary political history, in which he suggests that the Institutional Revolutionary Party's ability to hold onto power was the result of its blending of democratic and authoritarian rule. In chapter 6, Rath locates CMAEFA as a launchpad of US-led efforts to create international Cold War animal disease networks, but one that he argues must be understood as shaped significantly by Mexican political ambitions and knowledge as well as the resistance of Mexican peasants, rather than simply a top-down Washington creation.Rath's work is situated within a growing body of literature on how the governance of animal life, and particularly disease control, has shaped state formation and livestock modernization efforts in the twentieth century. By detailing the day-to-day complexities of one of the twentieth century's most influential, though forgotten, animal disease campaigns, Rath's is a critical contribution in moving us beyond linear and top-down accounts of these campaigns. While Rath's emphasis on the complexity and often paradoxical nature of CMAEFA often leaves open the question of how readers should understand this history beyond his stated "simple central argument" that Mexico's "aftosa crisis was just that, a crisis," he suggests in the afterword that its strange veneer might be the result of a collective historical failure to grapple with the ostensibly contradictory roles that livestock themselves inhabit in the story (4). The point is well taken, though Rath does little to draw out these paradoxes in the book's central chapters, particularly as they relate to the wavering of who the central object of governance in the campaign might have been: Mexican human or animal life.But in stressing the everyday resistance and mechanics as the campaign played out on the ground, Rath's history makes for one of the most compelling and important accounts of a modern animal disease campaign. Historians of twentieth-century agriculture, animals, Mexico, and the United States will benefit immensely from grappling with how the midcentury dreams of scientific progress and modernization were ultimately dependent on the messiness at the heart of disease control campaigns like CMAEFA.

title: Running Out: In Search of Water on the High Plains
abstract: In Running Out, anthropologist Lucas Bessire chronicles the culture of depletion. The book results from a personal quest to reconnect to his ancestral roots, explore his grandmother's unfinished research on the now-dry Cimarron River in Southwest Kansas, and explain a mentality that has put this corner of the plains on a course for extinction. In this portrayal of contemporary society and the lack of communal thinking in favor of individual gain, readers will find unfortunate continuities with the findings of key works on the region's history. The book is an important accounting of modern resource exploitation that scholars have established as a key legacy of white settlement on the Great Plains.The book consists of four parts. "Lines" looks backward to the establishment of large-scale irrigated agriculture on the High Plains. Bessire's great-grandfather was responsible for breaking thirty-eight square miles of prairie and for drilling some of the first wells into the Ogallala Aquifer. Later, debts in the operation led the family to sell off land to the region's first hog farms, introducing new, huge demands for water. Reckoning with personal and familial complicity in the destruction of the aquifer and the society it undergirds is a central problem for the author. Bessire shares his research process with his father, whose connections grant access to key players in the community and insights on the rationale of depletion.In "Bones," Bessire compares mining the aquifer to past eras of destruction in the West, such as the 1872–73 bison hunts. Now, the primary agents of destruction are the huge livestock businesses of Southwest Kansas. Local farmers pump millions of acre-feet of water per year (three times more water than needed to sustain New York City in a single year) to produce corn and alfalfa for the feedlots and dairies. These farmers share the blame for running the aquifer dry, as do bankers who have urged farmers to plant the most profitable crops even if they demand too much water. Then there is the federal government, which through crop insurance programs has protected the farmers from loss and encouraged farmers to gamble on ever bigger crops requiring even more water. But the author finds most culpable the absentee corporate landowners and the boards of the groundwater management districts they control. In this conclusion, Bessire echoes a long-standing argument that since the Great Plow-Up during World War I, nonlocals have spearheaded the destruction of the plains (e.g., Donald Worster's Dust Bowl [1979]).The connections between the Dust Bowl era and the present probability of running dry are evident. In "Dust," Bessire observes storms of blowing soil reminiscent of the Dirty Thirties. The mentality of the farmers, that "all it needs is water and it will produce better than any land in the world," meant that when farmers saw the potential for pumping the aquifer, they abandoned nascent conservation techniques introduced during the drought years (88). Indeed, the groundwater management district believes it is "economically irresponsible" to proactively switch to dryland farming, and it instead looks for salvation in quixotic schemes for building aqueducts or canals (109). Local farmers do not escape criticism for the short-sighted economic decisions driving their thirsty swigs at the well.The final section of the book, "Clouds," is so named to symbolize the evaporated water lost from irrigation. It should be noted that clouds can also continue the water cycle with precipitation, and possibly refers to options that might slow losses, if not recharge the aquifer. New irrigation technology can create greater efficiencies, and communities could engage in collective conservation. Unfortunately, most of the region's water users have exhibited an individualistic mindset and tend to lash out at anyone challenging the ideology of depletion. They manipulate the law, government programs, and the boards of the groundwater management districts to take as much as they can, while they can. Those who stand to lose the most from running out of water, the poor and minority groups who make up the labor force in the area, have no voice in the management of the water. Control remains in the hands of the wealthy, white elite, whose capitalistic inertia bowls over all voices of caution.The personal stakes the author brings to his narrative make Running Dry compelling, and the photographs incorporated through the pages show a through line of resource grabbing by the conqueror-settlers of the West. Those of us descended from this culture, and especially those still living its legacies on the plains, should indeed reckon with this dire problem and the mentality shifts necessary to embrace possible solutions.

title: Beekeeping from the South
abstract: Abstract This article examines the role of the stingless bee Melipona beecheii in beekeeping practices in the Yucatán Peninsula, México, in the nineteenth century. Native to Yucatán, the Melipona bee is capable of producing large amounts of honey and has been bred by Maya communities for over three thousand years. In the twentieth century, the Melipona population declined with the implementation of modern apiculture, a system designed to maximize the production of honey and wax with the European native honeybee, Apis mellifera. Previous scholarship on beekeeping has labeled the development of modern apiculture and the systematic expansion of the European honeybee across the Americas as a success story. However, these studies do not consider the cultural, economic, and social transformations brought by the introduction of Apis mellifera in environments that were already rich in bee biodiversity. In order to provide some clues about the impact of—and responses to—modern apiculture, this article focuses on the moment before this process occurred in the Yucatán Peninsula, when Melipona was still environmentally, culturally, and economically significant. The author argues that, far from being an unchanging cultural practice doomed to be superseded by modern apiculture, Melipona beekeeping continued to adapt in sophisticated ways to a modernizing world. During a period of upheaval, extraction of natural resources, environmental exploitation, violence, and Indigenous peoples’ defense of their land, the Melipona continued to be the only domesticated bee species used for beeswax and honey extraction in the entire peninsula during the nineteenth century.

title: The Devil's Fruit: Farmworkers, Health, and Environmental Justice
abstract: In the twenty-first century, California's agricultural opportunities attract both agribusiness corporations and farmworkers, yet the lives of these two populations, as Dvera Saxton shows, are polar opposites. The Devil's Fruit uncovers the challenging medical, social, political, and economic inequalities that im/migrant (as the author designates them) farmworkers in California face. This work is the result of Saxton's multiyear field research, undertaken among im/migrant workers in monocultural farms in California's Pájaro and Salinas Valleys during the 2010s. Unlike many academic books, Saxton's stands out with its combination of theory and narrative and experiments with what she calls "activist anthropology" (5). Written in an engagingly journalistic way and excelling in its research goal, this book will help researchers and students to both understand the harm of modern agribusiness and reflect on the social responsibilities of anthropology and other disciplines.The book contains five chapters in addition to an introduction and conclusion. Chapter 1 debunks stereotypes of im/migrant farmworkers, especially those from Mexico, and the unjust labor conditions under which they work. Chapter 2, an examination of the monocultural strawberry industry in modern California, reveals that underneath strawberries' beautiful packaging is a range of physical harms to both workers and the environment. Chapter 3 explores the medical harm from toxic pesticides. Chapters 4 and 5 discuss methods to actively support im/migrant communities.During her research, Saxton lived beside im/migrant farmworkers and discovered the layered challenges—including resource shortages, lack of legal support, and exposure to toxic substances—directly from the workers' perspectives. Her work combines investigative journalism, oral history, and activist research, in which she assists the im/migrant farmworkers to seek medical or legal help. This methodology shortens the gap between academia and everyday life. Saxton uses narrations of farmworkers' lives to underscore the lived experience of social injustice.Saxton also records her own thoughts and emotions when aiding farmworkers. When accompanying workers to meet with lobbyists or representatives from agribusiness companies, she describes the emotions of both the workers and herself—rage, frustration, self-doubt, or feelings of helplessness toward corporate power—a dimension harder to find in sources such as official reports.Saxton positions her activist anthropology within conceptual frameworks based on existing anthropological research. For instance, Saxton uses Peter Benson and Stuart Kirsch's term "harm industry" to describe the inherent destructiveness certain capitalistic pursuits. She then cites research that has a humanistic and activist approach similar to hers, including Emma Louse Backe's claim that solidarity and sensibility might be more valuable in activist research than objectivity. The book includes a comprehensive thirty-two-page bibliography that is highly valuable to fellow researchers and students.The final two chapters are dedicated to exploring two specific methods of activist scholarship: accompaniment and ecosocial solidarity. The former describes long-term support through being present for the workers, and the latter refers to the establishment of a tight community. Saxton enriches her research by studying multiple actors in this harm industry, such as medical professionals, lawmakers, local schools, and nongovernmental organizations.Critics of Saxton's method might point out that the lack of objectivity could damage activist anthropology's credibility. This critique is not entirely off point. Saxton admits that her humanistic and holistic approach could have issues like scholars "get[ting] caught in intense political and disciplinary debates," feeling "emotionally overwhelmed," or having different social, racial, or economic backgrounds from the community they study (177). Saxton argues, however, that if scholars are more willing to engage and be vigilant, academic work could become "more human and humane" (171).The Devil's Fruit is an important read for activists, scholars, and public historians to grapple with twenty-first-century agribusiness's destructiveness in California and the United States at large. Saxton's argument regarding activist anthropology research is likely to provoke useful conversations among researchers and students.

title: Cattle Beet Capital: Making Industrial Agriculture in Northern Colorado
abstract: In Cattle Beet Capital, Michael Weeks presents a fascinating account of the development of industrial agriculture on the Colorado Piedmont during the twentieth century. The book highlights how farmers on the Piedmont transitioned from cooperative agriculture in the 1870s to corporate sugar beet cultivation in the early 1900s to large-scale commercial cattle feeding in the latter half of the twentieth century. Along the way Weeks, a skilled environmental and agricultural historian, shows how the sustainable agroecology of sugar beets and small livestock operations gave way to "mechanical, biological, and petrochemical technologies" that sustained the huge commercial cattle feedlots. These technologies exploited and altered the environment (11).Weeks's book is divided into seven chapters. The first two chapters detail farming in the Piedmont from 1870 to 1930. In the early years of settlement, farmers established open-range cattle ranching that benefited from the shortgrass prairie in the area. They also developed irrigation systems for agriculture. By the turn of the century, farmers began cultivating sugar beets for the Great Western Sugar Company, yet they largely did so with methods that provided a sustainable agroecology in the region. Even so, sugar beet growing had a cost, especially on migrant workers, a topic Weeks examines in chapter 3. Since the US Department of Agriculture and Colorado Agricultural College played a key role in developing farming techniques and technology that impacted the Piedmont, Weeks discusses the growth of what he calls the "agri-state" in chapters 4 and 5. He ultimately concludes that the agri-state failed both farmers and the environment as it placed industry needs above research assessing the effects of new technologies, pesticides, and biocides on humans, crops, cattle, and the land. The final chapters chronicle the establishment and explosion of the commercial cattle feeding industry in the Colorado Piedmont, including the exploitative consequences it had for cattle and the environment and the destruction it wielded on smaller livestock raisers, all in the name of increased profits for owners of the large operations. The larger narrative of agriculture in the Piedmont is both unique—because of its transformation from beets to commercial cattle feeding—and common, in terms of the dominance of industrial agriculture by the end of the twentieth century.Cattle Beet Capital makes a significant contribution to the fields of both agricultural and environmental history. By showing the effects the transition from small-scale farming and cattle ranching to large-scale sugar beet cultivation and commercial cattle feeding had on human, natural, and animal environments, Weeks expertly demonstrates industrial agriculture's detrimental impacts. His work is steeped in the historiography of cattle ranching and the sugar beet industry, and it contributes greatly to these fields by focusing on the Colorado Piedmont, a place that historians have largely neglected, and by showing the weaknesses of both capitalism and the agri-state—weaknesses that enabled the growth of an industry focused more on money than on life in all its forms. Yet Weeks does so in a way that does not vilify or villainize one group or another—the story merely saddens, but in a thought-provoking way.The numerous strengths of the book make it a compelling read. However, in a few places, Weeks could have provided a little more explanation. For example, though sugar beet cultivation is a prominent part of the first half of the book, it largely disappears thereafter. Admittedly, this is because the growth of commercial cattle feeding led to corn replacing sugar beets as a crop in the Colorado Piedmont, but it leaves the reader wondering what happened to the beet sugar industry. Did it just end, or did farmers continue to grow beets? If so, on what scale? Are sugar beets still grown today in the region? Similarly, the impacts on humans of the chemicals, pesticides, and herbicides used on cattle seems underexplored. These, however, are minor criticisms and do not detract from the overall excellence of the book.I highly recommend Cattle Beet Capital for anyone interested in the beet sugar industry, the commercial cattle feeding industry, or the impact that agriculture has on the environment.

title: Translating Food Sovereignty: Cultivating Justice in an Age of Transnational Governance
abstract: As I write this review in late 2022, the World Food Programme warns on its home page that 345 million people in eighty-two countries "are facing acute food insecurity" (https://www.wfp.org/emergencies/global-food-crisis). Averting catastrophe, the organization insists, requires rising "to the challenge of meeting people's immediate food needs, while at the same time supporting programmes that build long-term resilience." The crisis has multiple origins—COVID-19 and the Russian invasion of Ukraine come the most readily to mind—but there are deeper systemic problems that long predate the current emergencies. These are the problems that food sovereignty activists have been fighting for decades to solve. It has not been an easy struggle, but change, as Matthew Canfield's book, Translating Food Sovereignty, makes clear, has happened in the recent past and is happening in the present as activists claiming food sovereignty are "actively transforming regulation to reflect their vision of decentralized, diverse, and democratic systems of food governance" (25). They are doing it by turning the structures of transnational governance—widely bemoaned for the power they have diverted to corporations—to their benefit.Translating Food Sovereignty is an examination of the origins and the actions of this transformation with a focus on the Puget Sound region of Washington State, the center of food sovereignty activity in the United States. Canfield—an anthropologist—embedded himself with those activists for years, volunteering with them, interviewing them, and observing them. He also went above the regional level, participating in international conferences and online forums. This participation, he argues, allowed him to see something that other scholars had missed: that food sovereignty activists are using what he has dubbed social practices of translation to create new kinds of transnational governance. They are, Canfield writes, "producing political constituencies and relations, undermining the forms of value supposed by global value chains, opposing the dominant forms of agricultural knowledge that have historically constituted private property and liberal sovereignty, and ultimately reimagining global governance by centering the voices of those most marginalized" (25).Canfield asserts that food sovereignty activists were particularly prepared for this work because of their roots in agroecology, which demands decentralization, sustainability, and equitability. Activists recognized that they could through translation—a term Canfield uses to describe the practice of sharing/communicating meaning and values along transnational networks—build shared networks of governance that could challenge and even replace the global value chains dominated by corporations, who had themselves challenged and replaced states as the ultimate wielders of power. The point, Canfield insists, is that activists have recognized and have begun to take advantage of the opportunities that transnational governance created. As one example, he examines the fight over the Super Banana, a Gates Foundation program to use a genetically modified banana to fight vitamin A deficiency in Uganda. Concerned on several levels about the bananas, Ugandan activists used food sovereignty networks to push back in different locations around the world, arguing instead for solutions based on "working with nature rather than against it" and listening to local farmers instead of silencing them with "innovations" (149). In another example, Canfield shows how farmworkers in Washington State unionized as Familias Unidas por la Justicia and forged networks with other food sovereignty activists and with small-scale producers to force changes that ultimately encompassed not just their own labor conditions but also value chain governance. These are two of several examples that Canfield uses to support his point that food sovereignty activists have used and are continuing to use structures built by neoliberalism to undermine it. It is a compelling argument, and Canfield is careful throughout the book to detail how his work is in conversation with multiple scholars of activism.For Canfield, the most important point of the work that the activists are doing is that it has the potential to change more than food. They have, through their work over the past two decades, "produced a new grammar of justice claims that directly confront the neoliberal mutations of transnational law and governance" (194). Critically, this is not a call to return to the past but, instead, a call to build a new kind of regulatory order: one that, among other things, brings marginalized groups into the decision-making process and prioritizes sustainability. Activists' "practices of translation," Canfield concludes, "offer the most powerful democratic antidote to the social, economic, and ecological unsustainability of neoliberal capitalism" (196). The cure begins with food, but it will not end there.

title: Slow Cooked: An Unexpected Life in Food Politics
abstract: By 2022, descriptions of COVID creative projects were a familiar topic in media articles and interviews. Thus, Marion Nestle's introduction to Slow Cooked, explaining that the book was just such a pandemic distraction, might lead some to underestimate the book before them. Slow Cooked belies such an expectation. It is a memoir that is both self-reflective as well as insightful about issues far beyond the personal life of its author.Academics do not often write memoirs. Traditionally, we are trained to eschew the first-person voice and to strive for objectivity about our topics. Nestle, though, is not traditional. She has had an academic career in medical education and then in food studies—an interdisciplinary field that she helped create. In her transition from one field to another, she worked for the federal government, editing a compendium of nutritional science and health. Outside of government and academic circles, Nestle has also enjoyed a unique position as a trusted nutrition authority widely quoted in mainstream press articles, as well as an activist and influential voice in the disparate new food movements. She has certainly fulfilled her goal to be "a critical analyst of the food industry" (4).Slow Cooked follows a straightforward, chronological organization, but Nestle reveals much of herself in the descriptive chapters, including the passion that has animated her circuitous career. At the start of the book, we learn that Nestle was a Depression-era red diaper baby, born to first-generation Jewish Americans with a problematic marriage. Nestle indicates how this upbringing shaped her self-opinion and then how social conventions in the 1950s shaped her early professional path. Nestle followed the path of white, middle-class women to marry, have children, and support the careers of their husbands. The seeds of Nestle's future career are found here, first in her determination to carve out a new path far from a childhood that was "bleak" despite its "moments of pleasure" often connected to food, and second, as she watched her severely obese father die from a heart attack at the age of forty-seven (20). The next four chapters describe Nestle's halting steps in her first jobs, her negotiation of the sexist assumptions made about her, and her naivete about the politics of academia and government. She reveals her own vulnerabilities as well as her growing education about the ways of the world through a series of "epiphanies."The first five chapters of this twelve-chapter book read as a prelude to act 2 of Nestle's life—as she titles chapter 6, "Finally, NYU." Nestle arrived at New York University in 1988 as chair of the Department of Home Economics and Nutrition. She set to work remaking the department, strengthening its offerings and reputation, and within eight years it had degree programs in the new field of food studies. In addition to her work within NYU, we read about Nestle's books and her growing public reputation outside of academia. Nestle's passion for the field—on display throughout—made her open to experimentation, such as the department decision to teach about food systems with the help of a garden cultivated in the midst of the urban campus. Beyond passion, Nestle was indefatigable and sure of her ability to tackle new challenges, even after she formally retired from NYU in 2017. While Nestle's confidence in her work is clear, she also lets the reader see moments of vulnerability and self-doubt, such as her seeking advice from therapist friends. Similarly, Nestle forthrightly gives details about her miscommunication with department members that led to her stepping down as chair in 2003.Throughout the second half of the book, Nestle provides details about each book she has written, her writing process, her goals, and the reception of each. Her section on the 2018 trade book Unsavory Truth: How the Food Industry Skews the Science of What We Eat is brief but especially interesting. Nestle observes that the book did poorly commercially and was ignored by nutrition researchers and academics whose conflicts of interests it dissects. Unsavory Truth demonstrates Nestle as a truth teller ("a critical analyst of the food industry") willing to turn her lens on colleagues as well as profit-driven corporations. The book also expresses the idealism that has lasted throughout Nestle's career.Whether or not you are already familiar with Nestle and her other work or have only heard vague comments about her books, Slow Cooked offers a rich portrait of a public intellectual as well as insights into the food systems that impact us all.

title: Colonizing Animals: Interspecies Empire in Myanmar
abstract: Jonathan Saha's Colonizing Animals weaves animals into many of the key events in the modern history of Myanmar (formerly Burma), including British colonization (1824–1948) and Japanese occupation (1942–45). Colonial Myanmar, often overlooked in histories of the British Empire, is shown to be a context in which "myriad" nonhuman animals participated in the "making and maintenance" of the empire (184). Pushing beyond the single-species focus of much animal history, Saha demonstrates how the plethora of elephants, crocodiles, monkeys, dogs, and other animals clash and collide with humans throughout the text's six chapters.While many cultural histories have long embraced a multispecies approach, Saha deploys an interspecies approach to encompass the interconnections between the colonizers, the colonized, and the nonhuman animals. As a result, Colonizing Animals moves away from the typical prioritization of the animal-centered approach within the field, building instead a case for a greater understanding of history as an interspecies process. Throughout the introduction, Saha proposes that due to the overwhelming focus of animal historians on Europe and North America, new theoretical frameworks are needed in order to understand interspecies relationships in more-than-European contexts. In a meticulous and detailed discussion of historiography, Saha argues that concepts of humanism within animal studies are ruptured and fragmented in the colonial context, where the animal was dehumanized alongside colonized peoples. While postcolonial theory has addressed this marginalization and sought to recover the agency of the subaltern, the framework of the interspecies empire proposes to unify theoretical approaches.Drawing upon environmental, social, posthumanist, and postcolonial theory, Saha demonstrates how both humans and animals were commoditized and marginalized, while ultimately playing a key role in both sustaining and threatening the interspecies process of empire. The significance of interspecies relations as commodities is most potently demonstrated during the opening chapters, in which working elephants and their Burmese oozie riders are shown to be crucial undead capital in the functions of empire. Oxen, too, were living commodities, "vital resources" in the economic operations of the imperial state and the migrant Indian workers who reared them, themselves products of the empire (81). In both instances, control over the labor of animals was interconnected with governance over the colonized.In the third chapter, Saha shows how governance over big game mammals and venomous reptiles branded as vermin was an important symbol of authority for the imperial rulers. These species were not solely perceived to be a threat to the British colonizers, well known for their anxiety about and physical and mental aversion to tropical environments. The value of a dead crocodile was also connected to its threat to plow cattle, an agent of empire. The endangered rhinoceros, by contrast, became in imperial eyes a symbol of Burmese neglect and lack of value in wildlife, in spite of the clear correlation between British imperial hunting and the near extinction of the species.Saha further demonstrates how racial divisions were tied to interspecies relations in the fourth chapter, in which British affection toward pets was contrasted with perceptions of unnatural relations between animals and colonized humans. Oozie elephant riders were dehumanized, yet their "domestication" by the empire rendered them "good animals." Inversely, human-snake relationships were a cause of great alarm, with snake charming a trope of racial and speciesist discourses in Orientalist literature. In the fifth chapter, the text turns toward the role of animals in Burmese nationalism, looking at how animal welfare was connected to the revival of Buddhist thought. This is followed by an exploration of primatology as an anti-colonial discourse as well as negative connections between animals and nationalist leaders. Finally, the sixth chapter discusses the role of animals as symbols of colonial authority, during key events such as the Hsaya San rebellion of 1930–32 and the collapse of imperial control during World War II, particularly with efforts to control nonhuman escapees from Rangoon Zoo.Pioneering studies have provided significant ventures into the environmental, material, and cultural histories of non-European contexts. Colonizing Animals adds to this field while calling for greater engagement with interspecies dynamics. When read in conjunction with posthumanist and postcolonial theory, Saha's work offers an important insight for scholars and students, pushing future proponents to embrace multispecies approaches. Moreover, his work challenges histories of colonialism globally to recognize the significant engagements and entanglements of colonizers and the colonized, both human and nonhuman.

title: Fragrant Frontier: Global Spice Entanglements from the Sino-Vietnamese Uplands
abstract: The editors of Fragrant Frontier have produced an impressively researched book on the contemporary growers, in northern Vietnam and Southwest China, of three spices—star anise, black cardamom, and cinnamon, each of which has local, regional, and international economic importance—as well as the human links in the global commodity chain of these spices. This volume is much more coherent than many edited volumes, and readers should not skip any of it, as there are nice little surprises waiting here and there in the text.A good example is the "Preface and Acknowledgements" section, as this not only provides interesting information on how the volume came into being but also links to websites and scannable QR codes for "story maps" on the three spices and the places mentioned in the rest of the volume. This is a nice touch that gives this volume about the recent situation of farmers, local traders, marketplace workers, street vendors (of both the spices and foods prepared with them), wholesalers, exporters, and state officials a very contemporary feel.
