Since I have not the space here to reflect upon each essay, I will highlight how several of them resonated with me.In part 1, “Natural History and Indigenous Peoples,” chapter 1, “A River through Time: Early Culture on the Big Sioux River,” lays important groundwork in terms of the human occupation and use of the area over the last eleven thousand years. Chapter 2, “From Pipes to Pistols,” introduces an appreciation of the dramatic change precipitated among Native Americans by European contact in the region.Part 2, “Explorers, Settlers, Outlaws, and War,” shifts the emphasis to European colonization of Siouxland. Chapters 7 and 8 stand out for their chronicling of seminal “frontier” events—the James/Unger Gang bank robbery in Northfield, Minnesota, and the “massacre” and kidnapping of settlers during the conflicts of the 1850s, respectively—each of which allow the authors to reflect upon the ambiguity of historical narratives.Part 3, “Writers, Scholars, and Artists,” offer memoirs of specific creators whose works bear the imprint of their connections to the Big Sioux River Valley. Perhaps the most fascinating of these contributions is chapter 10, which chronicles the origins of the term “Siouxland” in the work of author Frederick Manfred. This term, erroneously described by Wallace Stegner as a reference to the Indigenous peoples of the area, was actually an environmental/geographic/social amalgamation meant by Manfred to encompass and invoke the lands and lifestyles of the Big Sioux River Valley and surrounding areas.The two chapters of part 4, “Politics,” describe the electoral politics (chapter 14) and the politics of water (chapter 15). The latter provides an effective point of connection with the topic of part 5, “Water Quality.” Part 6, “Personal Reflections,” which concludes the volume with two heartfelt and insightful essays on the quality and nature of life in the Big Sioux River Valley.By way of conclusion, I will offer one final note of appreciation for this contribution by expressing my hope that other scholars and institutions will take this work as a template and produce similar works describing overlooked (or even not so overlooked) river basins across the American West and beyond.

title: State of Nature
abstract: Abstract Scholars have argued for the importance of industrial accidents and urban precarity in laying the groundwork for the European welfare state in nineteenth-century France. Given the central role that farming played in French economic, political, and cultural life, however, agricultural insurance was among the first and most frequently debated aspects of nineteenth-century attempts to apply insurance to the “social question.” This article explores what François Ewald has termed the “insurantial imaginary” of agricultural insurance by examining debates about which threats could or should be insured and who should insure them. Despite widespread consensus on the virtues of expanding insurance into the countryside, there remained huge areas of disagreement: What counted as an insurable risk in agriculture? How should that risk be assessed? And whose responsibility was it to insure such risks—that of private individuals or the French state? This article argues that the repeated failures of the various proposals designed to protect peasants against the vagaries of nature had as much to do with practical impediments as they did with ideas about the “naturalness” of certain dangers. This perception of the “natural” would inform the construction of the French welfare state.

title: Harvesting State Support: Institutional Change and Local Agency in Japanese Agriculture
abstract: This book is part of an expanding literature on agriculture in Japan from the perspective of political science. This work is firmly rooted in comparative arguments, utilizing richly detailed qualitative interviews, archival sources, and comprehensive fieldwork. The author's main argument is that Japan's agricultural policy framework should be viewed as a “macro-institution” shaped foremost by its positionality at the interface between formal rules and larger social network ties (9). This argument speaks to the agent/structure debate that emerged in political science in the 1980s and 1990s between those focused on large institutions such as governments and those who acknowledged the agency of individual actors, social groups, movements, and social forces.The book uses neoinstitutionalist theory, an iteration of structural theories that emphasize stability and gradual change. Jentzsch argues that neoinstitutionalism has a weak spot noted by comparative political economists—namely, understanding institutional change especially when those changes are internal and gradual. Neoinstitutionalism's focus on formal structures also oftentimes neglects local, informal institutions and the power of local actors to interpret, innovate, and shape responses to national shifts that may have the ability to control the degree of impact made by national legislative efforts. This monograph fills in a theoretical gap in neoinstitutionalism by focusing on change from within institutions by local actors, who Jentzsch argues have the power to shift formal rules by translating them into local practices. As a middle-ground comparative study, the work falls firmly within theoretical approaches calling for an expansion of the state and society interface (despite its use of neoinstitutionalism).The book is divided into five sections: part 1 is mostly theoretical and part 2 is historical, while the meat of the qualitative research is divided between parts 3 and 4, with conclusions presented in part 5. The primary comparison is between two very different agricultural areas in Japan, the villages of Hikawa and Kōfu. Hikawa's agricultural crop is mainly rice, while grapes are the primary one in the Kōfu basin. The town of Hikawa developed a novel approach to national policy goals of consolidating small rice paddy fields to create larger ones using hamlet-based collective farms, called the Kōsha system. Using a cooperative approach between the local Japan Agriculture farmer's union, the Kōsha formed a bulwark against the acquisition of local land by agribusinesses or foreign corporations. The ability of Hikawa to respond in this way resulted from its resistance to earlier efforts to merge with another municipality, thereby maintaining the structure of its existing cooperative system.Once the Kōsha system was in place and many farmers had yielded their rights to the union's management, the merger's potential to subvert local control over farmland was significantly diminished. In the Kōfu basin, however, shifts in the national cooperative structure allowed grape farmers to loosen themselves from Japan Agriculture's control and to innovate entrepreneurial business models.Using these two cases along with additional micro cases, Jentzsch finds that agricultural change in Japan was shaped by the larger context of shifting social and political boundaries—specifically, the municipal mergers and the restructuring of the all-powerful Japan Agriculture cooperative. Jentzsch suggests a negative outlook for Japanese farming, resulting from the gap between national policy directives calling for a sixth industrialization in agriculture amid collapsing local abilities to implement them. Importantly, Jentzsch notes that age-old practices don't just fall away; they remain along with and beside alternative “scripts for behavior—and local actors can revive and/or reinterpret ‘muted’ eroding norms” when it is in their interest do so (191).These processes shouldn't be dismissed as the shadow of bigger ones. They matter to how we understand boundaries, the relationship between formal and informal institutions as well as national and local-level policy implementation. Although the author reveals that he has “opened the black box of institutional arrangements being negotiated,” it is a rather small black box that coexists along with hundreds of others across Japan (190). While we have yet to understand the full impact of national-level policy changes and cooperative reform across the entirety of Japan, this book is an important contribution to this endeavor. The text reveals, with discerning though at times jargon-heavy prose, the power of the common paddy farmer, grape grower, and country villager. The strategies used here should be studied by those who care about the local control of agriculture, as they suggest alternative frames of reference and a potential for agency which can be overlooked.

title: William Ellis: Eighteenth-Century Farmer, Journalist, and Entrepreneur
abstract: Malcolm Thick's detailed study of the eighteenth-century agricultural writer William Ellis examines the work of the multifaceted, public-facing farmer through analyses of his personal life, rural work in Hertfordshire, and prolific agricultural publications and business ventures. The book traces Ellis's activities during a time of significant agricultural change in England. Drawing attention to Ellis's many accomplishments in his analysis, Thick argues that Ellis is worthy of far more historical attention than he has yet received, on the strength of his significant contributions to eighteenth-century agricultural literature.The book is organized topically into chapters that consider different aspects of Ellis's life and work. Chapter 1 introduces the book's contention that Ellis deserves greater attention from historians, while chapter 2 traces his early life, family, and work as a brewer in London. Chapter 3 is a thorough analysis of Ellis's agricultural writings and perspectives on questions such as soil fertility, while chapter 4 explores Ellis's business ventures, including his advertising techniques and sale of agricultural instruments. Chapter 5 considers Ellis's perspectives on food and drink and his collation of rural cooking and preserving methods, while chapter 6 examines Ellis's involvement in his adopted hometown of Little Gaddesden, where he was a churchwarden. Chapter 7 considers other elements of Ellis's life uncovered by Thick's research, including his engineering initiatives, his place within the larger improvement movement of the eighteenth century, and his posthumous reputation. Chapter 8 concludes briefly by pointing to the wealth of information available on multiple facets of Ellis's life. Also included is an appendix giving examples of Ellis's flyers advertising agricultural goods and services, as well as an annotated bibliography of Ellis's published works. The latter is one of the most useful aspects of Thick's work, even though Ellis's frequent republishing of his own writing and the multiple editions (some unauthorized) of his work makes creating a comprehensive bibliography quite complicated. Fourteen black-and-white figures offer useful illustrations of relevant agricultural methods, maps, and frontispieces of several of Ellis's works.Thick, an independent researcher and Fellow of the Royal Society who has published copiously on early modern English agriculture and gardening, wrote this book over the course of the lockdowns in 2020–21, spending what must have been an exhaustive amount of time poring over Ellis's complete published works. What results is an incredibly detailed close reading of Ellis's attitudes toward different agricultural methods, rural lifeways, and food production. The frequent use of block quotes from Ellis's works provides the reader with a sense of Ellis's style without detracting from Thick's analysis. Additional research into contemporary agricultural works by Ellis's peers and of other accounts of Ellis, such as Pehr Kalm's oft-cited recounting of his visit to Ellis's farm, are also employed, often as a foil to Ellis's views.Although Thick's close focus on Ellis's works is one of the book's strengths, such a perspective sometimes obscures the significance of his argument that Ellis's prolific writings make him worthy of more attention from historians. The unintended consequence of such a detailed treatment is that the reader is left wondering about the broader significance of this prolific, talented writer and businessman living and working during a period of profound agricultural and social change. Yet research into Ellis's broader world does not figure as prominently in the book. Allusions to colonialism, to broader improvement trends, and to other eighteenth-century matters that could augment our understanding of Ellis's work and period more broadly are scant, leaving the reader with a detailed understanding of Ellis himself but less of a picture of his role in eighteenth-century British agriculture writ large. Scholars working outside of Ellis's place and period may be frustrated that the significance of Ellis's writing to agricultural change in other locations and contexts receives minimal attention. Because Thick focuses so closely on Ellis, he touches only moderately on the central debates in early modern English agricultural history. Some editorial choices and sparse footnotes occasionally detract from an otherwise accessible work. Beyond Thick's admirable work, space remains for scholars to connect the life and work of William Ellis to other themes in agricultural history, including global, transregional, or other comparative perspectives.Such connections between Ellis and broader themes in the history of agriculture and improvement are made more possible by Thick's work, the most accessible and engaging portrait of Ellis yet. The book shines especially in its close readings of Ellis's equally detailed accounts of cultivation and food preparation methods, where Thick's delight in his subject matter is most apparent. Thick has penned a valuable reference work for specialists, yet his enthusiasm and rich analysis also has the potential to captivate nonspecialist readers. This study creates ample opportunities for scholars of agricultural history to connect Ellis's life and work to emerging themes in the field.

title: American Slavery and Russian Serfdom in the Post-emancipation Imagination
abstract: Since Peter Kolchin's landmark comparison of Russian serfdom and American slavery, works by Alessandro Stanziani and others have approached the topic of bound labor from a comparative perspective. Although Kolchin has also attempted to situate emancipation in the US South globally, the topic of emancipation has received far less attention from a comparative perspective than bonded labor itself. This state of affairs in the field makes Bellows's well-researched monograph as timely as it is compelling.The legacies of Russian serfdom and American slavery haunt us to this day. In the case of American slavery, this legacy is a matter of daily debate in the courts, in the press, and in the streets. This book reminds us that these legacies are, in addition to material factors, constructed imaginings of the past and contemporary life. Making use of an untapped reservoir of sources hiding in plain sight, Bellows tells the story of how societies that were remarkably different in many ways experienced the transition from servile to free labor in similar ways. In both societies the visual and literary arts, as well as other types of visual culture like advertisements, reflected and shaped attitudes toward the servile institutions of the past and the position of the emancipated in the present. In narrating this comparative history, the book offers an explanation of how history is rewritten in the popular mind, of the role played in this construction of collective memory by artists, authors, and advertisers, and of how these constructed memories were used as tools to explain and manage the social and economic changes taking place around them.There are striking similarities in the ways that Russian and American artists and their audiences produced and consumed cultural archetypes reflective of elite perceptions of the servile past. In both cases, nostalgic portrayals of the past provided an instrument that former owners could use to resist further diminution of their power and status by Washington or Saint Petersburg. Cultural productions portrayed the serf estate and the slave plantation as benevolent places where owners kept the unpredictable, potentially violent, and backward characteristics of their property in check. Emancipation, from this nostalgic perspective, had given such features of the peasant and the enslaved person free rein. One didn't have to go to a gallery or read a book to encounter these images, as the expansion of ad-driven consumer capitalism conveyed the same images and messages in periodicals and on placards. The discussion of such advertisements and ephemera in chapter 5 is one of the highlights of the book. Whatever the media, the powerful role of these imagined pasts solidified elite attitudes, justified their attempts to turn back the clock to an imagined golden age, and shaped policy.Through comparison, the book also highlights two key differences between these post-emancipation societies. The first difference is the place of race in the white American psyche, including the particular fear evoked by Reconstruction legislation guaranteeing Black equality. This resulted in racially motivated violence and attempts to reduce formerly enslaved people to their previous condition in all but name. Cultural works proved particularly adept at fixing images of African American racial inferiority in ways that justified white violence and oppression. The second difference is the ambivalent position of the Russian peasant (in contrast to the formerly enslaved) in Russian elites' own self-conceptions of identity. Emancipated serfs received their freedom and a land allotment, but their legal inferiority remained. At the same time, the peasantry, for all its backwardness, still represented the soul of Russia. The peasant was thus inferior on some levels but, unlike the African American, could not be condemned entirely by elites without denying some part of their own identity.No two entities would seem to defy comparison more than the United States and the Russian Empire, if for no other reason than that politicians, ideologues, and historians have invested a lot of time in demonstrating their exceptionalism, manifest destinies, and divinely ordained missions. Yet Amanda Bellows's demonstration of the role played by literature and visual culture in shaping both societies' post-emancipation worlds indicates that similarities between the two were at least as important as the differences.

title: A History of Contested Expertise
abstract: R. Douglas Hurt provides an expansive synthesis of the literature that evaluates the impact of the Green Revolution in different regions of the Global South since the 1950s, sketching a “transnational snapshot of its history” (5). Hurt defines the Green Revolution as “substantially increased food production on traditional farmlands due to improved seed varieties that are nourished with heavy applications of fertilizer and water, the latter provided by irrigation” (1). As Hurt points out, this increase in food grain production—primarily wheat, rice, and maize—“did not depend on agricultural science alone but also on government support in the form of grain price supports, subsidies for fertilizers, and the development of irrigation systems, as well as research” (3). The book chapters are organized geographically, tracing the history of agricultural modernization in Latin America, South Asia, East and Southeast Asia, China, and sub-Saharan Africa, focusing on a few countries in each region.Hurt constructs a complicated narrative that outlines the positions of advocates and critics of the Green Revolution. The overarching thesis is that the Green Revolution was a success in terms of its stated goal of increasing food production for a growing population but that it came with “unintended consequences,” as indicated in the title of the book. The narrow conception of success, measured in terms of increased yield productivity of a few varieties of monoculturally produced cereal crops, remains unquestioned in the analysis. It is worth noting that recent scholarship has also questioned the claims of increased yield productivity of cereals and its attribution to Green Revolution hybrid varieties.1The “unintended consequences” identified by Hurt include a wide range of concerns pointed out by critics of the Green Revolution, such as deepening class and regional inequality, the persistence of hunger and malnutrition, water pollution, aquifer depletion, and loss of genetic diversity. In Hurt's narrative, the social and ecological consequences illustrate a lack of long-term planning by agricultural scientists. Unequal distribution and access to food as well as to Green Revolution inputs by smallholders are attributed to political and institutional conditions.The economic crises facing farmers who were at the forefront of adopting Green Revolution technologies, such as debt traps and overproduction, are mentioned but receive less attention in the analysis. In Southeast Asia, by the 1990s “poor, small-scale farmers who invested in the Green Revolution technologies often fell deeply into debts” (95). In Ethiopia “the Green Revolution collapsed due to overproduction, which brought famine. Ethiopian farmers produced more grain with Green Revolution technologies than domestic consumers could eat or competitively sell on the world market” (152). The concluding reflections of the book do not draw out the implications of such economic crises, which were structurally inherent to the Green Revolution model and produced specific forms of inequalities.2 Hurt suggests that Green Revolution science was productive but had uneven social and economic consequences that were not necessarily “detrimental” (195).Hurt attributes the failure of Green Revolution technologies to increase food production in certain countries and regions to inadequate support from governments, weak infrastructure, and lack of supporting policies and institutional frameworks, especially subsidies and marketing to incentivize the uptake of Green Revolution technologies. This is highlighted, in particular, in the chapter on sub-Saharan Africa. Hurt's argument frames regional inequalities as an unintended consequence even as he points out that the package of high-yielding varieties was by design targeted at irrigated regions and required capital-intensive inputs. For example, crop-breeding research in India neglected dryland regions. Two implicit and problematic assumptions embedded in the book's analysis are that “politics” lies outside the domain of science and that the Green Revolution singularly exemplified science-based agriculture, contrasted with the monolithic category of “traditional farming.” A binary repeatedly invoked in the book is that of agricultural scientists as advocates of the Green Revolution versus social scientists as critics guided by ideology.Several recent histories and ethnographies have gone beyond the long-standing debates focused on yield productivity, impacts on rural incomes and employment to unpack the logics and politics of knowledge production that underpin the agricultural modernization paradigm of the Green Revolution. Works such as Nick Cullather's The Hungry World (2010), Sigrid Schmalzer's Red Revolution, Green Revolution (2016), Benjamin Robert Siegel’s Hungry Nation (2018), Ryan Nehring's “The Brazilian Green Revolution” (2022), and a 2017 roundtable discussion in Agricultural History have drawn attention to how Cold War geopolitics and Malthusian narratives of hunger shaped the trajectory of agricultural modernization, highlighted the political contestations within the scientific community about ecologically and socially appropriate agronomic practices, and traced the complex genealogies of transnational exchanges between actors and institutions in the Global North and the Global South in shaping the politics of Green Revolution. The book cites some of this scholarship, but it does not engage with many of the substantive arguments and, to a large extent, reproduces the assumptions and logics of modernization that they challenge.The final chapter on the more recent debates on genetically modified crops, the so-called Gene Revolution, departs from that framing to some extent and shows the entanglements between politics and agricultural science. In China, for instance, Hurt discusses how shifts in agricultural policy toward the development and commercialization of GM crops have been shaped by competing pressures and interests, by the politics of cultural nationalism, by the goals of national self-sufficiency, and by competitiveness in international trade.The book is a useful compendium that comprehensively maps the debates on the impacts of the Green Revolution in different regions of the Global South. While Hurt frames social inequalities and ecological degradation as stories of unintended consequences within countries, recent historical scholarship as well as contemporary food sovereignty movements are articulating a fundamental critique of the globally structured direction of agricultural transformation inaugurated by the Green Revolution that foreclosed other socially just and ecologically appropriate regional paths of agrarian and rural development.3 Emerging scholarship also demonstrates the transnational geopolitics of expertise that systemically shaped the Green Revolution model, tracing circulations and continuities across regions that show how the adverse consequences of monocultural, agrochemical- and water-intensive agriculture were recognized and contested from the early years.4 Such comparative analyses and global histories upend the entrenched narrative of the Green Revolution as the only possible pathway for postcolonial development and draw attention to erasures and the marginalization of alternative trajectories, expanding the space for rethinking the possibilities for socially just and sustainable agroecological forms of agrarian development.

title: Colonial Impotence: Virtue and Violence in a Congolese Concession (1911–1940)
abstract: From 1911 onward Unilever set about constructing a plantation empire in what was then Belgian Congo, now the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Working with the colonial authorities, the company was allowed to choose 750,000 hectares of land within five circles, each with a sixty-kilometer radius. The concession rights that came with the land included practically exclusive rights to purchase palm products from the local population and establish palm plantations. By 1959 Huileries du Congo Belge (HCB), the Unilever subsidiary that handled its business in Belgium and Congo, was responsible for 9.2 percent of the world trade in palm oil and ranked among the largest plantation projects in the world. After independence the company repeatedly changed names and owners, but four of the five plantations remain operational to this day.Henriet's study focuses on the Lusanga/Leverville circle. Initially designated as one of the most promising locations by HCB, it was the one concession that was unable to make the transition from natural palm groves (semiwild stands of trees where the locals would collect the palm fruits and sell them to the company) to plantation palms. However, the reader soon realizes that this microstudy is less an exercise in history than a vehicle for presenting Henriet's concept of colonial impotence.One book-length historical study of the HCB was previously published by Jules Marchal in 2001 (L'histoire du Congo, 1910–1945: Travail forcé pour l'huile de palme de Lord Leverhulme). At first glance the two books appear similar. They share the same cover photo, cover practically the same period, and use much of the same archival deposits—in fact, the very same boxes and files. It is therefore peculiar that Henriet never refers to Marchal's study—neither in the text, nor the footnotes, nor the bibliography. This lack of engagement is regrettable. One would have thought that several themes picked up by Marchal could have been further developed by Henriet, including the relationship between HCB and the other important concessionary company in the area, the Compagnie du Kasai.While Henriet does explain the well-known Kilamba incident that sparked the Pende revolt and in which both companies were involved, he does not explore other questions. For instance—and considering that both companies recruited workers in the same region—were they rivals, or did they cooperate? Did they present a united front vis-à-vis the administration? Could Africans play the two companies against each other to their benefit? These questions are of more than just historical interest; they speak directly to the plausibility of Leverhulme's paternalistic ambitions in Congo, and thus to Henriet's hypothesis. A discussion of the available archival source material—how much was the author able to consult, how much remains unused—would also have been useful for other researchers interested in the subject. Unilever's other concessions in Congo and throughout Africa, and their history beyond 1945, are not examined in this book.Henriet's hypothesis of “colonial impotence” links the inability of the colonial state and companies like Unilever to impose their will on the ground to sexual impotence. Moving through six thematic chapters, the author surely and steadily builds his arguments. The fundamental tension between Lord Leverhulme's “benevolent” paternalistic vision and a for-profit company are laid out in the first chapter, where Henriet ably points out the similarities between the modus operandi of HCB and that of the blood rubber companies of the Congo Free State. The following chapter deals with the inability of agents, both colonial administrators and company men, to impose their will on the Congolese, and the agents' disregard for the laws and regulations of the colony and the company. Chapters 3 and 4 study the various responses, both physical and spiritual, of the Congolese to the arrival of the company and the violence inflicted by HCB and its agents. The last two chapters look at the all-encompassing influence of the concession on the daily lives of the Congolese—rations, forced Western health care, clothing—and the difficulty for the company of bending the natural environment around Leverville to its will.Each chapter feeds into the book's overall argument, which the author summarizes in the following terms: “Colonial impotence speaks of the gap between the virtuous and the violent guises of the Leverville project; of the refusal of Europeans in the field to conform to the behaviours and attitudes demanded from them; of the agency of indigenous communities which hampered HCB's project; and of the impossibility for the company to bend the Kwilu's environment to its designs” (169). While this reviewer can understand this conceptualization of colonial ineffectiveness, the sexual dimension of Henriet's theory is more difficult to comprehend. “Like colonialism,” he writes, “impotence is inherently relational; it manifested itself through an ‘improper’ performance during intercourse. When actors of colonialism failed to conform to expected rules, guidelines and attitudes, they displayed metaphorical forms of impotence” (69). There is no doubt that sexual contact and, more importantly, widespread sexual violence were key parts of the colonial occupation of Africa. But that is not what Henriet engages with in his book; instead, he takes that well-known fact and superimposes it on a situation where its relevance is open to doubt. To this reviewer, at least, the additional conceptual understanding gained by comparing a company agent unwilling to carry out his duties to erectile dysfunction is not immediately obvious.

title: Mennonite Farmers: A Global History of Place and Sustainability
abstract: This remarkable book is a comparative study of Mennonite communities in seven disparate locations: Friesland in the Netherlands; Washington County in Iowa in the United States; the Rhineland municipality in Manitoba, Canada; Apollonovka district in southwest Siberia in Russia; the village of Margorejo on the island of Java in Indonesia; Matopo Mission in Matabeleland in Zimbabwe; and Riva Palacio colony in the Santa Cruz department in Bolivia. The successive chapters examine the historical origins of each community, their experiences with and in some cases resistance to agricultural modernization in the twentieth century, the differing attitudes toward religion and agriculture, the status and role of women, their knowledge of and attitudes toward a changing climate, and the varying international and global connections of each community.This book is the result of years of research by a team led by Loewen at the University of Winnipeg. It relies on a wide range of sources, from recent theoretical approaches to local publications, archives, diaries and memoirs, and periodicals. The study also uses numerous oral history interviews conducted by Loewen's students and colleagues in each region, based on a standard set of interview questions listed in the book's appendix.Loewen emphasizes that agriculture is based on local environmental conditions, but he also emphasizes the role of culture and “lived religion” in people's relationships to those environmental conditions (265). In his descriptions and analyses of these communities and their agricultural, religious, social, and political experiences, these different components carry different weights, based on their agricultural, economic, social, and political contexts.The Mennonite farmers in Iowa and Manitoba, for example, were much more willing to accept and apply modern mechanized and chemicalized farming techniques than the other communities. They were hesitant in the early decades of the twentieth century, but World War II, the competition of neighbors, and the increasing effectiveness of new technologies led most of them to modernize. They acknowledged Mennonite religious doctrines that emphasized simplicity and traditionalism, but by the 1970s traditional knowledge had become “nostalgia” and “cause for amusement” (82). By contrast, farmers in Riva Palacio tried much harder to hold onto traditional practices until these began to cause serious problems. For example, one of their traditions required them to use steel-wheeled tractors and reject rubber tires, until it became clear that steel wheels compacted the soil and reduced production.Attitudes about climate change also varied considerably. In Matabeleland and Riva Palacio the farmers were very aware of increasingly frequent and severe droughts and had a long tradition of remembering climate conditions that proved to them that their climate was changing for the worse. They attributed these changes in part, and in some cases assigned blame, to “greedy” outsiders who eliminated trees and extracted resources, but many of them understood at least in a basic way the global patterns. By contrast, farmers in Iowa and Manitoba were less affected, and while some recognized the problem, others minimized or denied the existence of climate change, viewing weather patterns as no different from the past and often as the result of divine interventions.The character and intensity of religious attitudes varied considerably. In northern communities, farmers maintained their religious beliefs but interpreted them in ways that rationalized their reliance on science and modern technologies. In Siberia, however, because of a history of harsh state repression of religion, arrests and removal of many men from their communities during the 1930s, World War II, and to a lesser extent during the post-Stalin period, the community's religious beliefs were quite intense even when they used modern farming practices. In Matabeleland and Margorejo, by contrast, Mennonite religion was syncretic and included traditional attitudes and practices from preexisting religious cultures, and their beliefs reassured them in dealing with changing weather, the introduction of modern farming, and social and political conflicts.The status and roles of women in these communities was particularly varied and often served as a greater challenge to religious doctrine. In all of these communities, religious doctrine tended to subordinate women and confine them to the household and peripheral activities. Yet in all of them women often resisted these constraints, taking on larger economic and social roles in their communities, especially in Siberia because the Communist government removed so many men. In Margorejo, women had considerable autonomy and class was a more important social division than gender; in Matabeleland, women had to struggle against traditional male domination and social and political conflicts.The communities also varied in their connections to the outside world. Iowa and Manitoba farmers, like their neighbors, early on were producing for international markets, and some of them went to Riva Palacios to help their fellow Mennonites modernize their work. Frisian farmers were incorporated along with other Dutch farmers in the European Union and subjected to its regulations. Riva Palacios farmers, as they came around to accepting modern techniques, sent representatives north to obtain more modern equipment as well as chemicals and seed. Post-Soviet Apollonovka became a capitalist farm and for the first time began receiving foreign visitors and advisers. Matabeleland farmers were increasingly impoverished and often viewed outsiders as vestiges of former colonial powers, although they also received financial and technical support from fellow Mennonites. Margorejo farmers were incorporated into the growing international Green Revolution and generally accepted it.Overall, this study presents vignettes of the evolution of farming in several of the main world agricultural regions. They show that these “Mennonite” farmers, regardless of their varying religious views, are fully part of their farming regions. Their religious-agricultural views, particularly their emphases on simplicity and traditional methods, were overwhelmed by new technologies such as mechanization, fertilizers, pesticides, and antidisease measures for livestock, and by environmental transformations, especially climate change. Most of these farmers had to accept and rely on such nontraditional measures because of increasing agricultural difficulties and a need for high production for their growing communities and markets.This book provides vivid grassroots views of these farmers' experiences in the process of modernization. It could be a very useful book for courses on regional and world agricultural history, for undergraduate students to expose them to farming in different parts of the world, and for graduate students as background and inspiration for their own research.

title: Complexion of Empire in Natchez: Race and Slavery in the Mississippi Borderlands
abstract: In a feat that would be remarkable under normal circumstances, it is especially impressive that historian Christian Pinnen managed to shepherd not one but two books to publication during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic: Colonial Mississippi: A Borrowed Land (with Charles Weeks, University Press of Mississippi) and this book, Complexion of Empire in Natchez. The latter work explores a changing Natchez, where over the span of about one hundred years, four different outside powers ruled with varying degrees of success. The French, Spanish, British, and Americans each inflicted systems that relied on stratification based on concepts of complexion. In each instance, Pinnen's exhaustive research reveals Native and African negotiations of the imposed hierarchies. Ultimately, the regime tied to cotton became the most successful and rigid scheme.Pinnen begins his analytical narrative with the French, who envisioned a lucrative agricultural empire built on a subjugated labor force. As with other European powers, their evolving concepts of Blackness provided convenient justification for the regime and a sense of order in colonial society, implemented via the code noir. Pinnen emphasizes that Africans, however, complicated French attempts to manage their empire by mounting legal challenges. Understanding that the French hierarchy of complexion not only clashed with their traditions of captivity but also degraded their own status, the Natchez Indians, in turn, rejected the French hierarchy of complexion. According to Pinnen, the Natchez also interpreted the stratification of complexion in a way that made them natural allies with Africans, with whom they ultimately united to prevent the French from establishing a successful tobacco enterprise in the area. In 1729, as the French stood on the verge of realizing profits in tobacco, the Natchez Revolt obliterated the plantation economy. The involvement of African escapees in this insurrection would for years haunt colonizers with the reminder of the catastrophic potential of Black and Brown people banding together against their oppressors.The British who followed also viewed Natchez as a potentially profitable tobacco plantation region, an extension of their Atlantic plantation economy based on unfree African labor. Pinnen reiterates that “settling Natchez was as much about race as it was about imperial control” (59). Concepts of skin color, culture, and heathenism merged to create a British brand of hierarchy based on complexion. British codification of race and slavery in Natchez began in the 1760s, only tightening over time. Pinnen points out that in a significant departure from the French model, the English system assumed Black people as enslaved by default. Pinnen argues that despite the regime's reliance on enslaved African labor as “the backbone of any agricultural endeavor in Natchez,” enslaved people pressed against the system to the best of their ability (50). However, the restrictions of English law meant that running away offered a better chance of gaining freedom than did most legal suits. Because the Choctaw, Chickasaw, and Creek did not view themselves to be in concert with Africans according to the hierarchy of complexion, Africans were unable to join Indigenous societies to the extent that they did elsewhere with other Native nations, like the Seminole.Gaining control of Natchez in 1779, the Spanish also proved intent on using African descent to justify slavery and drew distinctions of complexion by officially prohibiting colonists from enslaving Native Americans. While the Spanish regime differed from the French and English, Pinnen shows that two pillars continued to uphold the colonial foundation: profit and complexion. The model of slave-grown tobacco grew (despite some logistic challenges) thanks to royal tobacco subsidies and tariff-free slave importation. Despite their subjugation due to complexion, nonwhite people in this Spanish colonial structure enjoyed greater access to courts than they had under English law. The hierarchy of complexion subjected African people to slavery but also recognized them as subjects of the Crown and souls for the Catholic Church. Africans in Natchez understood and negotiated this system. In their wrangling for some self-determination or outright freedom, enslaved and free women of color, for example, carefully selected the godparents of their newly baptized children from among powerful whites, establishing advantageous fictive kinship networks.Finally, the United States' acquisition of Natchez via the 1795 Treaty of San Lorenzo accelerated the growth of the cotton economy and ushered in new complexion rules. As Pinnen explains, under US law “phenotype became a total, all-encompassing marker” in Natchez for the first time (184). Although enslaved people did not cease to challenge the system, they increasingly worked within that system as individuals and in their claims to freedom acknowledged the legitimacy of slavery based on complexion. Readers will be more familiar with this last part of the story—the development of cotton capitalism—which has received renewed interest by many historians in the last ten years or so. Complexions of Empire contributes an exploration of one locale before and early on in this transformation without taking it as a given.Besides the book's mastery of a wide breadth of sources to provide a rich narrative of so many different actors, the highlight of the work is Pinnen's emphasis on African (and Native) people's resistance to and shaping of each colonial system imposed on them. Their successes did not disprove the strength of hierarchies of complexion but did demonstrate the flexibility and liminality of colonial projects. Although there are portions of the work in which concepts of complexion could be a bit more tightly connected to the events described, the book offers a rich history of how Native Americans, Europeans, and Africans shaped the manifestation of race, slavery, and empire.

title: Country of the Cursed and the Driven: Slavery and the Texas Borderlands
abstract: In Country of the Cursed and the Driven, Paul Barba “aspires to offer a more comprehensive history of Texas during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries” (3). Through the use of “two culturally resonant impulses,” “manly violence,” and “kin incorporation,” the book weaves together extensive Indigenous, Hispanic, Black, and Anglo-American stories of slavers and enslaved people not often told together in the same study of Texas history (11). Barba concludes, “Slavery in the Texas borderlands was never a static institution or system of practices; it was, rather, part of a web of ever-changing processes” (10).Seven chapters arranged into three main parts, an introduction and epilogue, seven maps and two tables, and a full seventy-five pages of endnotes support Barba's main claim: “Slavery's forms emerged not necessarily from some essential set of core cultural attributes (i.e., ownership rights over others, legal institutions of subjugation, and structural racism) but from the nexus of various, ever-changing human networks, prerogatives, and decisions” (11). Part 1 of this book highlights the ways in which the history of slavery in Texas transcended the borders of the modern-day US state (21). Part 2 emphasizes how understandings of kinship served as catalysts for violence against enslaved people (132). Part 3 underscores how Anglo-American violence rooted in anti-Blackness operated in tandem with other forms of violence against enslaved people in the Texas borderlands (226).Country of the Cursed and the Driven contributes to the historiography on slavery when it successfully argues that kin-making often served as a form of subjugation across Comanche, Spanish, and Anglo-American systems of slavery. Rather than categorize systems of slavery into “better” adoptive systems of slavery that treated enslaved people as members of an extended family and “worse” systems of slavery that valued anti-Blackness and chattel slavery, Barba demonstrates how slavers' understandings of kin-making contributed to exploitation and violence. Enslaved women forced to become wives for Comanche men, particularly when coupled with the physical and psychological traumas of rape and forced parenthood, for instance, certainly did not live better enslaved lives (167–68). As Barba concedes, “Family and slavery were not diametrically opposed. In many ways, they could be two sides of the same coin” (15–16). Barba acknowledges marked differences between Comanche, Spanish, and Anglo-American systems of slavery, but, more importantly, cautions readers against interpreting kin-making within slavery as a sign of more benign forms of slavery (135).Country of the Cursed and the Driven discusses intersections between Texas borderlands systems of slavery through the lens of agricultural expansion, a topic that may be of particular interest for readers of Agricultural History. Barba pinpoints Indigenous efforts to curb Anglo-American proslavery, primarily agricultural expansionism in the mid-nineteenth century, as a topic for future research and identifies Spanish and Anglo-American agricultural expansionism as major turning points in Indigenous, Spanish, and Anglo-American systems of slavery (158, 303). He posits that Comanches may not have fully understood the extent of Black subjugation within Anglo-American systems of slavery in Texas; however, they recognized Black enslaved people forced to work in agricultural spaces as crucial aspects of Anglo colonialism (314).The sheer range of historical voices in this volume constitutes one of the book's main strengths. Drawing on the advice of Saidiya Hartman's Scenes of Subjection (1997), Barba prioritizes the often difficult and untold stories of individuals who lived slavery's “web of ever-changing processes.” Barba frames his work, including the book's title, in response to Cherokee Elijah Hicks's 1840s observations about the interconnectivity of slavery systems through Comanchería (3–4, 317). Barba emphasizes the experiences of María Gertrudis de la Peña, an enslaved woman in Spanish society (169). He highlights Betty Powers, an enslaved woman of African descent who shared her recollections of the constant threat of sexual and whipping violence against women (251). Throughout this work, Barba deftly balances deeply personal, micro-level stories with large-scale historical significances and processes.Country of the Cursed and the Driven stands as a meticulously researched narrative of human stories of violence and resistance. It reframes familiar stories in unfamiliar ways and identifies sites of future research. Students and experienced scholars will find much to consider in this work of Texas history, transcultural and borderlands history, and slavery history.

title: Black Earth, White Bread: A Technopolitical History of Russian Agriculture and Food
abstract: In the wake of Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, the American fast-food chain McDonald's withdrew from the Russian market. McDonald's had operated in Russia since 1990, and the chain was popular with Russian consumers. Analysts predicted that Russians, deprived of their Big Macs, would revolt and place additional pressure on President Vladimir Putin to end the war. But such hopes fizzled. Though McDonald's sold its stores in Russia, the rebranded restaurants, known as “Vkusno i tochka” (“Tasty and That's It”), were able to produce and sell meals that approximated what Russian consumers had grown accustomed to before the invasion.Suzanne Wengle's book was released in March 2022, too late to include coverage of the war. But the book is nonetheless a timely addition to the literature. It includes a wealth of observations that help us understand Russia's ability to weather Western sanctions and continue to project its influence around the globe. The fact that the Russian chain Vkusno i tochka could quickly produce meals that taste like McDonald's has a longer history, Wengle reveals. Putin, far more than his predecessor Boris Yeltsin, “held out a greater degree of food commodity autarky as a desirable policy goal” (71–72). This project accelerated after Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014. Then, Putin embargoed a range of Western agricultural products and sought to strengthen domestic producers. It was under his leadership, too, that Russia became the world's largest wheat exporter, supplying the commodity to the Middle East and Africa.In light of current events, the author's discussion of agriculture during the Putin years is perhaps the most striking aspect of Black Earth, White Bread. But the book is much broader, offering an analysis of agriculture and food production in Russia over the last hundred years, a period that includes Soviet rule (1917–91). Arguing that “politics and technologies together drive change in food systems,” Wengle, a political scientist, uses the framework of “technopolitics” to analyze this history (8). She defines “technopolitics” as “the support of and reliance on agricultural technologies—from tractors to CRISPR techniques—in policy regimes that seek to realize particular political goals and utopias” (8). The value of a technopolitical approach, Wengle argues, lies in its ability to reveal “crucial relationships between diverse and changing groups of actors in the four realms of food systems—politics, production, consumption, and nature” (17). Along the way, the author also highlights global connections embedded within these themes, persuasively fighting back against the tendency to see the development of Russian agriculture as aberrant and disconnected from the West.In the author's view, these four realms are interconnected. To understand the transformation of food systems, it is important to analyze them all. Wengle critiques the discipline of political science for neglecting the spheres of nature and consumption in particular, and the book's title, Black Earth, White Bread, highlights this. The term “black earth” refers to the fertile black soils in parts of Russia that at times helped planners achieve grain production goals. “White bread” gestures to the hopes of some Soviet officials that white bread, which they associated with higher living standards, would replace black bread in the diet of Russian peasants.The book is composed of four chapters, one devoted to each realm. Though this makes for some repetition, particularly in the first two chapters, “Governance” and “Production,” it also serves to underscore the value of a multifaceted approach. I was particularly taken by some of the author's observations about consumption. The author argues that the discipline of political science has tended to focus narrowly on actions, like voting and protests, neglecting other aspects of citizens' behavior, including consumption. In the conclusion, Wengle identifies vulnerabilities of Russia's current food system and speculates that such weaknesses may feature in a “future struggle between the opposition and the Putin regime” (225). Clearly, such observations hold particular relevance in light of the war in Ukraine.The book is not a work of primary source research. Rather, it synthesizes the existing secondary literature to highlight the author's technopolitical approach across a hundred years of Russian food and agricultural history. In a subject this vast, not every topic can be covered in depth. Even so, there are themes that deserved greater scrutiny. First, alcohol. Mikhail Gorbachev's anti-alcohol campaigns in the 1980s became a flash point for Russian consumers, and there is a significant scholarly literature on the subject of vodka in Russian history. However, the author only touches upon the theme in passing. Another missing issue is ethnicity. I was never quite certain of the region under study, whether it is “Russia” in its incarnations as the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic (Soviet period) followed by the Russian Federation in 1991, or, alternately, whether the author intended to scrutinize the entire territory of the Soviet Union followed by a narrower focus on the Russian Federation after the collapse. The book's title would seem to indicate that the book is just about “Russia.” But at times the author uses statistics from the Soviet Union as a whole or evidence from non-Russian republics to support her points, which left me confused. Whatever the geographic focus, the theme deserved greater attention, particularly as so much of the food that Russians came to enjoy during the Soviet period was produced in the non-Russian periphery. Today, the Russian Federation is a major food exporter to former Soviet republics like Belarus and Kazakhstan, illustrating the continuing salience of ties developed under Soviet rule.

title: After Populism: The Agrarian Left on the Northern Plains, 1900–1960
abstract: Few people would think of communism at the mention of rural “red states,” yet left-wing radicalism had an outsized influence in northern plains farm organizations, especially in Montana, the Dakotas, and Nebraska in the first half of the twentieth century. William C. Pratt, professor emeritus at the University of Nebraska Omaha, uncovers the role of rural radicals from multiple angles and within the broader context of the left-liberal alliance. Left-wing radicals, according to Pratt, either identified as socialists or communists or “sought major changes in the existing economic order beyond what the mainstream of historic progressivism or the New Deal attempted” (5). In After Populism, Pratt examines the relationship between left-wing radicals and left-of-center farm groups and their breakup at the onset of the Cold War.After Populism appears to be a monograph but is essentially a collection of articles Pratt published between 1985 and 2014. All but two of the fourteen chapters previously appeared in academic journals but have been “adapted” for the book. As a result, After Populism seems disconnected in the middle. The first seven chapters share a common methodology, thematic focus, and periodization, distinct from the later chapters, which generally have their own unity. The book could avert confusion if separated into two sections with a brief explanation linking them together.In the first several chapters, Pratt narrates the travails and joys of grassroots research. Searching for scraps of information, he traversed long dirt roads, conducted oral interviews, combed through small courthouse records, and visited forgotten graveyards. Under the Freedom of Information Act, Pratt acquired Federal Bureau of Investigation records that provided surveillance information on some of his subjects. Research at the Russian State Archives in Moscow connected communist activities in the region to the Comintern.The first half of After Populism focuses on the period from 1900 to the 1930s. Pratt illustrates the strength of the Socialist Party but cautions that most people who voted socialist mainly did so as a means to express dissatisfaction with the status quo rather than because of a commitment to its ideology. After World War I, the Socialist Party all but died out as members opted for the Nonpartisan League or one of several communist parties. Pratt views the 1924 elections as a major blow to radicalism on the northern plains because Progressive Party candidate Robert LaFollette distanced himself from the budding farmer-labor movement. Next, he examines the farm revolt of the early 1930s, highlighting the interaction between the United Farmers League—a communist front group—and the Farmers' Holiday Association. In some counties the United Farmers League dominated the farm revolt, while in others it worked alongside the Farmers' Holiday Association. In addition to the popularity of New Deal programs, Pratt finds that factionalism played a significant role in the collapse of radicalism in the early 1930s. He also chronicles the activities of three local women farm revolt leaders and explores the creation of left-leaning third parties in the prairie provinces of Canada as compared with those in the US plains.Picking up after World War II, the later chapters consider the National Farmers Union (NFU) leadership, especially highlighting the role of North Dakota Farmers Union president Glenn Talbott, as it tried to maintain a popular front alliance in the late 1940s. Pratt analyzes the relationship between the NFU leadership and Henry Wallace during his bid for president in 1948 and notes that although NFU leaders privately endorsed him, they declined to do so publicly in part because it would open their organization to charges of communism. A brief chapter documents the extensive FBI surveillance of real and suspected communists in the upper Midwest before detailing the NFU's move to the political center and the attacks on it by Wisconsin senator Joseph McCarthy, the Farm Bureau, and others on the right. Pratt concludes with a comparison of the 1980s farm crisis to the farm revolt of the 1930s.Scholars unfamiliar with Pratt's work will appreciate the grassroots level treatment of radicalism on the northern plains. Pratt adds a level of complexity by showing the diversity of background and opinion in some counties and towns in multiple states. He also extends the timeline of the decline of the radical rural Left into the 1950s.Though most of the findings in After Populism are already a part of the scholarly record, this volume brings together decades of work that helps explain the demise of the agrarian left in the northern plains and the many factors involved in farmers' political and economic calculus.

title: Teaching Dissent and Power in South Asia
abstract: In January 2021, in a Toronto winter, as I was getting ready to teach a course on the history of food, environment, and labor in South Asia, my thoughts strayed often to the borders of Delhi, India, several continents away from my desk. Since August 2020, groups of Indian farmers, most from Punjab, had been organizing themselves, coming together to protest new neoliberal farm laws proposed by Narendra Modi's government. These laws were ostensibly intended to free agricultural markets from government regulation but would certainly open them up to the control of large corporate buyers setting prices. Just outside Delhi, along highways linking the capital to surrounding agricultural and industrial districts and the rest of the country, farmer organizations had set up campsites, libraries, performance and oratorial spaces, kitchens, and even small makeshift farms. Thousands of farmers (over the months millions) were there to make their discontent with the new laws palpable, their voices heard, and their labor and solidarity globally visible.As I worked on the syllabus, I very tentatively considered bringing the farmers and their protest into my classroom. My historical training has made me wary of falling into presentism, to make connections between the past and a present that may often be structurally determined differently, though this is one of the easiest ways students relate and respond to historical scholarship. Equally important, I wasn't sure how to maintain a balance between high emotions over an issue that was creating such political waves in India and its diaspora and the kind of careful reading, discussion, and writing that were the aims of the course. As a migrant graduate student in Canada with Indian citizenship, I felt my own vulnerability and that of undergraduate students, who were often migrants too. Hindu nationalist organizations in India and the diaspora have been quick to target events and spaces involving critical discussion of the Modi government, its policies, and the Hindu nationalist movement that it politically represents, denouncing such criticisms as perceived attacks on the nation and religion; critics have been faced with trolling, doxing, other forms of harassment, and in some cases criminal proceedings and jail.1 Despite these misgivings, over two iterations of the course, it became clear that the pedagogical had to be political and that presenting this contemporary people's movement through the course materials was a highly generative pedagogical act. Learning about agricultural history alongside the agricultural present could be a way to make a fractured world of pandemic and climate crisis layered on capitalism and colonialism feel challenging and alive rather than alienating.Over the last century, much of South Asia's wheat has come from Punjab, on either side of a national border between India and Pakistan. Punjabi migration in the early twentieth century was also intimately intertwined with histories of North American settler colonial states, their agricultural development, and immigration regimes. More recent waves of migration and a large South Asian population in the Greater Toronto Area meant that in my online classroom hosted by the University of Toronto, at least some of the students were likely to be South Asian or even Punjabi in origin, and Punjab loomed large in the imagination of South Asia from here. Accordingly, the syllabus included two academic readings that engaged with this history. A book chapter about the establishment of Punjab's canal colonies discussed planned settlements on former scrublands around canals in Punjab, built to further the British colonial government's intention of bringing more land under cultivation and irrigation and improving agriculture in the region.2 Another reading opened up questions around how histories of contested Punjabi arrival could be later subsumed into the settler colonial narrative of good laboring migrants contributing to the aims of the colonial state.3 Lecture materials covered other topics in Punjab's agricultural history, such as the consequences of the partition of Punjab for the control and use of water and the canal system of the region, dam building in postcolonial India, and the impact of the Green Revolution.In the first iteration of the course, I included a journalistic overview by Sharanya Deepak of the farmer protests as something of an afterthought.4 In the second iteration, I added two more: an article by Aniket Aga discussing the protested neoliberal farm laws as the final death toll of the Green Revolution and the inequities it produced, and an ethnography of the protest sites by Sarover Zaidi.5 Both Deepak's and Aga's pieces, though not historical in perspective, briefly discuss the history of agricultural Punjab before the protests; Zaidi allows her readers to step with her into a contingent present. I chose these pieces in the hope that they would allow students to think about change over time and contingencies of history.Given the ongoing pandemic, all discussion happened online in Zoom meetings. I did not always see the faces of my students, but their responses and thoughts lingered powerfully through their participation in discussion and their writing. On the whole, student responses were deeply critical of neoliberal governance and identified sympathetic figures in these narratives around Punjab, historical and contemporary. Thinking about settler colonialism and our entanglements with it in Canada as well as how land itself was reorganized and parceled out to settlers in Punjab's canal colonies brought up profound questions on these systems of agriculture and land use. One student discussed culpability and responsibility in regard to a settler colonial extractive state that they had migrated to in search of a better life. Others were struck by how learning the history of settlement in colonial canal colonies made visible land acquisition processes; for several Punjabi students, this revealed the trajectories of their own ancestors and families, involved in acquisition processes they had not previously probed historically. This kind of self-reflection allowed students to think with sympathy and solidarity about the situation of farmers in a capitalist system that both gives to and exploits them and to ask questions about their own entanglements in capitalist and colonial agricultural systems. Some students with backgrounds in economics wrote analytically about questions of power and economic growth in the agricultural sector, discussing related examples from other non–South Asian contexts and thinking about development and sustainability. The emotional heft of this history and of the protests were however never far from students' analysis; for instance, one student, Harjas Singh, prefaced a discussion of creeping neoliberalism in India's agricultural policies over the last decade with the comment, “As a Punjabi Sikh and someone who has family still living in Punjab, this is an issue that hits close to home. I have friends and family who have protested here in Canada, as well as my family having donated to relief efforts for those protesting back in India.”This engagement with systemic power was coupled with a consideration of what dissent meant in the narratives of Punjabi agriculture and farm labor that we looked at. Most notable was perhaps one tutorial discussion during which some students argued that the state's authoritarian approach was necessary for development; others responded by asking whether the state could ask constituencies to make sacrifices for the common good and in the name of growth and development, who should decide what that growth and development should look like, and which constituencies could be asked to make such sacrifices. This led to a discussion of the place of dissent and opposition within political systems and protest as a means of representation in democracies. I was struck by the enthusiasm students displayed for this political activity by farmers; through their discussion, I could see how examining the issues propelling the farmer protests led many to the idea that people's movements would be increasingly crucial going forward as climate emergency changes many of the rhythms and rules of agriculture. Zaidi's ethnography in particular invited students to imaginatively visit the site of protest and think about its possibilities, and they commented on the immediacy of this reading experience. The discussion questioned the religious and caste politics of farmer organizations too; some students recognized that there was still work to be done for solidarity.In retrospect, this reading and discussion experience could have worked well with invited guests who were engaged with the protests and could speak about them with greater facility than I, the teaching assistants, or any of the students could. But that would have been a very different kind of engagement, with perhaps greater deference and more of a compulsion to take notes than to express ideas. Our more exploratory reading and discussion sessions, in fact, successfully provided a focus for questions and ideas that many students had been dealing with outside of the classroom, as videos and images from the farmer protests flooded Instagram and TikTok feeds and, more generally, we all contended with pandemic-related food supply issues and price rises. On November 19, 2021, when the Modi government announced that the farm laws would be repealed and millions of farmers celebrated the victory of months of sustained protest, I received an email from Mannat Boparai, one of the students in the ongoing course, congratulating me on what she called “our victory.” Attached were three images and a video from one of the major protest sites on Delhi's Tikri border; she had taken these that very morning. In a time of online teaching and engagement, the classroom and the protests were actually very close to each other, and students were taking the history they learned to their own activism.

title: Grasslands Grown: Creating Place on the U.S. Northern Plains and Canadian Prairies
abstract: When I lived in Nebraska, I met a white poet who explained to me in her slight southern twang that her family was “native” to the plains, “as old as the dirt.” I struggled to reconcile her familial placemaking with her erasure of Indigeneity—until now. This woman's claim to settler longevity in the 2010s is part of a legacy of generations of frontier narratives grown in what Molly Rozum calls the “gumbo” of transnationalism (xiv). The intensity with which grasslands-grown generations experienced their surroundings created a passionate sense of place inseparable from a larger regional identity, one that ignored national borders in favor of the environment. As Rozum argues, ecological and cultural change were intertwined (120).Rozum's book follows a chronology of the first immigrant and citizen settlers in the heart of the grasslands in the late nineteenth century through their adolescence and into adulthood. Through diaries and letters, she charmingly reassembles the sounds and smells of the “small world” experience of first-generation grasslands children. Their keen observation of animals, the land, plants, and weather translated into early exposure to archaeology, biology, botany, ecology, hydrology, meteorology, and paleontology. Rozum never lets us forget, however, that their cultivated childhood experiences came at the disadvantage of the region's Indigenous peoples, and that settler colonialism is the driving force behind her study.Parallel stories across the US-Canada border are all that situates the transnationalism in the childhood chapters. It becomes much more pronounced as Rozum follows the children into adolescence and early adulthood. She explains that as their education became more formalized, it also became more national and global—two narratives that served settler colonialism better than regionalism. These adolescents' geographies expanded too as they began to travel greater distances and transition into gendered work life, often in larger towns or regional cities. Yet even in these new environs, these young adults applied their small-world observation skills to bigger places.Many of Rozum's characters begin to lose their charm as they age fully into adulthood. Gone are the youthful days of wandering the prairie and rolling down the hills. They are replaced with first-time encounters with Indigenous peoples (predominately in settler spaces) alongside cultural and intellectual appropriation of Native lifeways and food science. Deviating from her close readings of diaries and letters, Rozum shifts briefly to analyzing creative works as mechanisms for regional placemaking that centered immigrant and citizen stories and erased Native peoples off the landscape. These works rarely broke into national markets but formed a popular region-defining genre of “settler fiction” (254) that, by the early 1900s, had professionalized and exceeded its predecessor: the pioneer novel.By the mid-twentieth century, the grasslands-grown generations had converted their precious region into grainlands. Agricultural innovation followed the establishment of higher education institutions, but, in essence, these researchers formalized the small-world science of their youths. The literary lamentations over industrialized progress following World War I and changes in farming technology manifested in real-world strife following the droughts of the 1920s and 1930s. By the 1940s, they shifted their focus to preservation efforts.While some of the early chapters can be rather encyclopedic, this book is a must-read for anyone with an interest in what is now known as the Northern Great Plains. Though not explicitly about gender, Rozum's careful analysis subtly reveals the divergent gender roles from childhood through adulthood. She weaves in narratives from Icelandic immigrants alongside African American homesteaders, adding to the chorus of voices emerging from the grasslands. Her book is a meditation on the body as much as it is on the land as she tells the story both generationally and seasonally.The poet who raised my hackles with her generational amnesia also once convinced me to lie down beneath the dried canopy of 850 acres of original, unplowed tallgrass and listen to sounds of the Nebraskan prairie. Reading Rozum's book kept my head beneath the rustle of the tallgrass, conjuring memories of a small-world soundscape of tiny critters, my own breath, and a surprising, peaceful silence.

title: Fertile Grounds
abstract: Abstract From 300 CE to 1800 CE, Indigenous North Americans initiated a great material and cosmological transformation. Indigenous peoples moved away from their more nomadic lifestyles by mastering hydrology to manage crop cycles, engineering building systems to house their growing populations and food stores, and developing innovative political confederacies to harness the transformative and spiritual power of the Three Sisters. Through an examination of traditional ecological knowledge—what Gregory Cajete calls the “original instructions for how to care for and relate to the land”—this essay argues that the cultivation and spread of corn, beans, and squash radically remade Indigenous North America into a world bound by a set of relationships and reciprocal responsibilities between humans and plants. These plants were far more than commodities. They were kin—or, as plant ecologist Robin Wall Kimmerer says, “sovereign persons.” As Indigenous women spread the Three Sisters across the continent, these plants and the attendant corn cosmologies provided narratives to explain human ancestry and evolution. Such creation stories attracted Indigenous immigrants to Cahokia, Indigenous traders to the Mandan and Hidatsa rendezvous, and helped precipitate the rise of the Wendat, Haudenosaunee, and Powhatan confederacies.

title: Mapping Food Riots—Teaching Global Connections
abstract: Writing and teaching using global history is by no means a novel concept. Students in both K–12 and postsecondary education systems have been exposed to them to varying degrees since the 1990s. Despite having clear connections to world history, agricultural history has largely been taught through national and or regional lenses. Recently, agricultural education specialists have identified the integration of “a more globalized approach” to teaching agriculture to be a priority for the future.1 As such, we are left to answer the question of how history instructors can develop effective assignments to encourage undergraduate students to think more globally about agriculture. Moreover, how can these assignments be accessible to classrooms that do not have the budget, time, or access to fieldwork and or civic engagement components? These were the two guiding questions that I asked myself when designing assignments for a course titled Food, Science, and Technology during the Interwar Period. My approach was to go digital. Though still imperfect in several ways, the digital assignment (discussed below) inspired students to engage and reflect on global narratives within agricultural history.One unit of this course focused on how World War I reshaped the global agricultural market by disrupting food supply networks. The result was widespread hunger and even famine conditions in many European countries. In some cases, disturbances caused by food deprivation led to revolutionary events and even the collapse of empires (Russia). To consider the global effects of the war and connect them with the issues of food access, I designed an assignment that asked students to trace the outbreak of food riots from 1914 to 1919. In outlining the goals for the assignment, I sought to make it a collaborative in-class experience that focused on developing the following skills: (1) improving historical research skills, including formulating a research question, obtaining data, evaluating it, and placing it in a global historical context; (2) developing knowledge and mastery of digital technologies; and (3) working in collaboration with others.For this assignment, students worked in groups of four to six people during the period of one ninety-minute class. Each group was assigned a year and was asked to find articles in newspaper databases (e.g., the New York Times) using several specific keywords, such as “food riot,” “food revolt,” “food disturbances,” and so on. After finding relevant articles that reported news about food riots in different cities across the world, students put this data into an Excel spreadsheet (fig. 1). Each group had its sheet in the joint Excel spreadsheet in which they recorded the date, city, country, participants, cause, and resolution. Over the course of this assignment, these groups collected and analyzed between ten and twenty newspaper articles.
