The rest of the class time was devoted to transferring the collected data using Google Maps onto a single map that had layers for each year (fig. 2). Each layer was identified with a different color to make it easier to track the development of food insecurity during and after World War I after the map was completed. Students spent approximately thirty minutes creating the map by putting colored pins and writing short descriptions of events based on the information from newspaper articles. After the map was completed, students examined the map layers that their colleagues created and discussed their findings in small groups and then as a large group.As a result, I observed a more engaged and productive conversation about global connections in agricultural history. Students commented on the global impact of World War I on food production and food access, as well as social and racial inequality. Students connected key course themes outlined in lectures and secondary readings with their analysis of primary sources. Further, the map helped not only to visualize the number of food riots but also to demonstrate the growth and then the eventual decline of food riots in different countries. The dynamic nature of digital technologies presents students with another way of looking at the “change over time” concept. Second, this assignment helped students to “live” a life of a professional historian. Students obtained hands-on experience in asking a research question, identifying keywords for their search, and then working through the database with an immense amount of information. In the process, they used critical thinking skills to evaluate information and choose what articles fit their search criteria. Moreover, by working with the database, they realized that not all articles contained the same amount of information, and they were able to identify historical gaps that could only be filled with the help of other sources. Finally, the assignment dismantled stereotypes of agricultural history as a dry and insignificant subspecialty by demonstrating its deep connections to political, economic, and cultural history. In the end, mapping out historical events and processes by using newspaper archives proved an effective way to visualize the agricultural history and food history of the twentieth century.I believe that the assignment can be modified to adapt to different teaching contexts. For larger classes, the assignment can be a take-home group project where students meet outside of the classroom. For virtual environments, students can work in breakout rooms. To shorten the time spent on the assignment in and beyond the classroom, an instructor might choose articles ahead of time and focus students' efforts on analyzing the assigned material and transferring acquired information on a map in Google Maps. The assignment can be adapted to the analysis of other historical events and processes that are not connected to famines and food riots. Mapping the Green Revolution comes to mind.Despite the positive outcomes, the assignment still had some drawbacks. One obstacle for those engaged in premodern, marginalized, or Indigenous histories is access to sources. However, even those who focus on the modern era will have productive conversations about the limitations of newspapers and whose perspectives they provide. Another obstacle was the utilization of English-language newspapers that reported on domestic and foreign riots. While the records of riots were valuable, it was important to recognize whose voice students were hearing in those accounts. Nevertheless, the assignment achieves two crucial goals. It demonstrates how the global military conflict impacted agricultural production and food access in urban and rural areas not only in Europe but also in other places all over the world.

title: Charting the Plantation Landscape from Natchez to New Orleans
abstract: For decades, the tours of many historic plantation sites have focused on the plantation mansion. Charting the Plantation Landscape from Natchez to New Orleans challenges the prominence of the “big house” and the cultural mythology that has made it, in popular memory, the most significant feature of the plantation. Each of the volume's seven essays uses a unique disciplinary lens and focuses on a different thematic aspect of the nineteenth-century plantation to displace the mansion as the focal point of the plantation landscape. Drawing on approaches used by architectural historians Dell Upton and John Michael Vlach, this volume illustrates how the mansion-dominated plantation landscape experienced by visitors today is a fragmentary remnant of a larger historical reality.Arranged chronologically by editor and Oak Alley Foundation curator Laura Kilcer VanHuss, these essays move briskly through a wide range of topics that broadly explore how the built environment of plantations in the lower Mississippi River valley and visitors' perception of them have changed over time. Marie Adrien Persac's 1858 Norman's Chart of the Lower Mississippi River serves as a collective foil, which allows each author to establish a path leading to new vantage points of the plantation landscape. The divergent paths outlined by contributing scholars challenge Persac's highly aesthetic and celebratory depiction of the region's plantations and offers a perspective that defines the plantation landscape historically beyond the mansions that occupied it.Charting the Plantation Landscape begins with architectural historian Laura Blokker's essay “Construction and Construct,” which examines the abundance of architectural styles used in constructing ancillary buildings like the neighborhoods of slave quarters, kitchens, sugarhouses, barns, and hospitals that enabled slaveholders’ intensive agricultural pursuits. The collection's second essay, Suzanne Turner's “The Plantation Landscape,” focuses on the ways in which European colonizers exploited and remade the “wilderness” they found along the Lower Mississippi River. Wading into the swamps to explore how the region’s landscape was transformed into manicured European-style gardens and African swept yards, Turner, like Blokker, minimizes the big house's prominence by emphasizing the construction and changing uses of other aspects of its built environment.Three subsequent essays focus on the plantation from slavery to emancipation. Two of these essays describe the plantation landscape in familiar terms. In “Severed Heads to Statehouse,” Charles D. Chamberlain III examines the violent rise and fall of Creole sugar planter power throughout the nineteenth century. Chamberlain contends that sugar production played an important role in defining the plantation landscape as it appeared on Persac's map. According to William Horne's essay, “Landscapes of Emancipation,” freedpeople redefined this plantation landscape on their own terms during the postwar period. Horne argues that freedpeople transformed plantations into sites of radical grassroots resistance in their “rejection of the established political topography” (131).Christopher Willoughby's standout essay, “Plantations as Landscapes of Medicine,” explores antebellum physicians' role upholding the region's slave system. According to Willoughby, plantation physicians played a critical role in planters' efforts to modernize agricultural systems by ensuring enslaved men's labor productivity and enslaved women's reproductive capacity. Through their claims that slavery was healthy for enslaved men and women, these doctors contributed to the construction of racial science and shaped the “racial imaginary” of the plantation by putting the health of the plantation over that of African Americans.The collection's final two essays analyze changes in the ways artists visually represented plantations during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Christopher Morris and art historian Jochen Wierich both also consider how these representations helped construct and popularize a cultural myth of the plantation focused around its aesthetics. In “After Persac,” Wierich examines how the visual culture of the plantation landscape evolved between 1860 and 1940. Detailed antebellum depictions of planter power like Persac's evolved into romanticized paintings and photographs that blended time and space and distorted the historical reality of the plantation. According to Wierich, the combined forces of heritage tourism, historic preservation, and modern photography in the twentieth century produced the image of the plantation lodged in popular historical memory.In “The Rise and Fall of Uncle Sam Plantation,” Morris further explores how the ghostly photographs of abandoned plantations captured by Farm Security Administration photographers in the 1930s influenced the public's imagination. These images reinforced a cultural narrative that connected the destruction of abandoned plantation structure with the “myth of lost southern glory.” Morris contends that the centralized modern state also used this romantic narrative to justify the destruction of “relics” of the Old South in the name of progress and reclaiming the productivity of abandoned landscapes. By focusing on the environmental transformations and the human and ecological costs associated with the flood control and levee construction necessary to sustain agricultural production, Morris redefines the lower Mississippi River valley plantation landscape by viewing the land and water as active participants in its construction.Some essays, like Willoughby and Morris's, do more than others to chart plantation landscape beyond the mansions that adorn it. Nonetheless, academic audiences will find much to admire and reflect upon as they follow along the paths each author traces. This volume also seems particularly well suited for undergraduate courses. The various definitions of the plantation landscape in this volume offer numerous opportunities to generate discussion among students. More important, perhaps, this volume excels at its self-assigned task by providing the public with an accessible introduction to the complex historical reality of the plantation landscape.

title: Soil as the Archive
abstract: I first came to Duke Campus Farm in winter, for an interview, hoping to become the site's inaugural full-time farm manager. The ground was frozen and the soil tight-lipped, revealing little. Returning in the spring to start work, I found to my chagrin a red clay so fine as to be almost greasy, which seemed to speak only in horse nettle and fire ants. Before arriving in Durham, my most recent farming experience had been on the Central California coast, where the soils are young, rich, and deep. As a grower, the old, tired, Southern Piedmont soils originally struck me as a cataclysm, a shambles.As I've settled into North Carolina and started teaching with the farm, through hands-on work in sustainable agriculture and also in the environmental humanities, I now see the same landscape more clearly, as an incredibly rich environment for a campus farm. With less production pressure and an educational mission, we have the time to really pay attention to our soils, and to care for them and about them. In struggling with the paucity of the land we farm, the effort it takes to make it yield and to restore its basic functions, we understand in a different way what has already been taken from it.1 Our “native” soils are the result of geological weathering, yes, but also an all-too-human combination of two hundred years of extractive agriculture and a century of chattel slavery.Our site offers a space to step into the complex systems of small-scale agroecological farming and the demands of a student-powered, seventy-member CSA. Our land is a catalyst for reflection on the wider systems of processing and transport, consumption and waste, food culture and foodways. Our soils, like so many others, also carry the legacies of extermination and enslavement, of displacement and migration, of abundance and resilience in American agriculture. As I work with this soil in both farm and classroom, I'm learning to better hear its stories. Through the actual work with soil, our contact with it—through broadforking, digging, pricking out, raking, shaping, cover cropping, composting—we can experience in a more direct way all that the farm's denuded soils represent, what this land has seen and what its future might hold.Through the archival work of Duke Forest and several intrepid students, we know that our farm was part of a three-hundred-acre parcel granted to Mr. Thomas Couch in 1754.2 Over the next two centuries, the Couch family and the people they enslaved and hired built a plantation that at its height reached several thousand acres, working it continuously until 1947. We know the names of thirty-six people that they enslaved, but we assume from the extent of their operations that they enslaved many, many more.3What happened before the Couch family's arrival is visible mostly through the soil. Much of what we know about the agriculture of North Carolina's Native peoples comes from the 1585 account of Thomas Hariot and John White. These English explorers spent roughly a year in coastal North Carolina with Algonquian-speaking peoples. But their attempts at establishing a colony were famously unsteady and soon failed.4 As they noted, disease spread rapidly through all of the Indigenous communities that they visited, and the settled agriculture that they initially encountered quickly unraveled as local populations sharply declined.5 By the time a subsequent expedition arrived a few years later, the lifeways Hariot and White first encountered were already fractured. And by the time John Lawson recorded a voyage on foot through the interior of what is now North Carolina in 1700, he encountered “a small people, having lost much of their former Numbers . . . most by the Small-pox, which hath often visited them, sweeping away whole Towns.”6The land's more recent history as a farm project launched by undergraduates in 2010 builds on these legacies of loss. What I am learning, both through work with our soil and work with colleagues such as Dr. Dan Richter, a critical zone scientist, is that the soil that we encounter is not a given but is in an important sense a human artifact, a juncture of bio-hydrogeologic pedologies and also human ones. In visiting our farm in 2018, Vivette Jeffries-Logan, a citizen of the Occaneechi Band of the Saponi, told us: “What you're farming on is the dust of the bones of my ancestors.” The style of farming that we practice on our intensively cultivated acre necessitates deep contact with our soils, with this dust and these bones. When we invite students and members of the general public to join in the work of civic agriculture, when we talk of regenerative agriculture and the work of repair, we are also inviting them into contact with these histories and all that is both broken and resilient within them. We recognize that embodied contact with these histories has the potential to disturb, even to traumatize, as well as to heal.How, then, to tell these stories? The temptation to ignore them—to lean into a more pastoral vision of young people at an elite university growing organic vegetables for their communities—can be strong. What are the ethics of a more anti-pastoral kind of storytelling? Who has the right to share these stories, and in what context can they be shared?7 These are live questions that we are still navigating as educators. One strategy that has worked for us is to allow the soil, and the plants themselves, to bear witness.8 In our Cackalacky Heritage Garden, for example, we grow crops that were significant to those who cultivated this land before us: seed sunflowers, green and brown colored cottons, Bright Leaf tobacco, indigo, heirloom okras, cow peas, sorghums, and benne.9 These crops become a tangible, living testimony to the wisdom and technologies of communities and their seeds. They also serve as conversation starters that help students reflect on their own place within, and the ongoing legacy of, plantation systems. As members of the Duke community, we are active participants in an institution founded on tobacco and its economies. As staff and faculty at Duke, we are also, of course, implicated in this legacy.10We also have a ten-foot-deep soil pit at the Duke Campus Farm, dug with an excavator. With this we can “read” each soil layer or horizon, as a dendrochronologist might read the rings of a tree. To a soil scientist like my colleague Dr. Dan Richter, the profiles voice the stories of carbon cycles deep below the earth's surface, of the Piedmont ultisol's weathered history. What is compelling about the pit is also what is not there, the three to four feet of soil above the surface of the pit (as estimated by Richter) that eroded soon after white settlement in the Carolinas.11 The soil horizons missing from the Duke Campus Farm's topography can be read, among other things, as an invisible record of the many thousands of lives—of Indigenous and enslaved peoples—ground down and seemingly vanished, and the profound environmental as well as human loss that this absence represents.As of this writing, fifty-nine student interns, thousands of volunteers, and billions of soil microorganisms have made substantial progress in bringing the soil back to life. Through our soils and the intimate connection with them that our way of farming necessitates, we are able to teach both the deep time of geology and offer a case study for the Plantationocene, making visible and tangible connections between our ransacked soils and their human histories.12 The ecological dead zones that were the majority of DCF's native soils have become a way to think with our farm as an unfolding of geological time, as a site of mourning and enslavement and as an opportunity for partnering with the more-than-human world—fungi, bacteria, actinomycetes, earthworms, pollinators, plants, and countless others—to bring these soils back to life.While we grow thousands of pounds of organic produce each year, our chief output is ultimately, therefore, not produce but students with a renewed sense of self-efficacy and an understanding of the vastness of the food system and the human histories at its roots. We are contravening the Anthropocene cycle described by Anna Tsing as “promise and ruin,” of extraction and abandonment of land and communities, to return to the wreckage and offer it a muscular kind of love, the work of repair.13 We do this despite the fact that very few of us who work at the farm are from this place, and none of us will ever own it. Moving forward, I hope our soils will have new vitality and more generative, and regenerative, histories to share.

title: Don't Just Learn the Lesson, Live the Lesson
abstract: My research suggests that reembedding in a human-scale economy can help individuals connect to fundamental values: meaningful work, belonging in community, and connection to nature. Scaling down economies to the local or bioregional scale will help us to mitigate some of the worst risks of climate change, biodiversity loss, soil erosion, and social unrest. Small-scale production is something anyone can take part in and has the potential to form the basis of entirely new economic and political networks that can blossom into the world to come. Teaching these agricultural history concepts through experiential learning has the potential to transform the perspective of students to what is possible in terms of a sustainable future.1Based on these research findings, I founded Rizoma Field School in Uruguay, where American university students participate in immersive, place-based volunteer learning. They engage with community members in a mutual process of learning about and practicing sustainability. Students collaborate with community partners on sustainability projects. In the projects, students observe ongoing community efforts in areas such as sustainable agriculture while also supporting new initiatives. Students work especially in the realm of sustainable agricultural production, focusing on projects such as agroecological food production and bioconstruction. Students do tasks such as tree planting, sowing and reaping crops, or hand-making buildings of bamboo, mud, and straw. After working on the projects, students and instructors reflect on their experience and connect it to broader issues related to consumption and production.With my training in environmental sociology, I act as an accompanying instructor to the students' experiences. I work to connect the fieldwork with discussions of topics related to sustainable consumption, such as agroecology, cultural diversity, engineering, and social dimensions of nature-culture dynamics. Students are asked in nightly reflections to highlight some of their observations of sustainable production practices in this context. They are then encouraged to consider how they might apply some lessons from Uruguayan sustainable livelihoods into their own lives. In combination, applied learning and more conceptual, content-focused discussions mutually reinforce each other, encouraging students to reflect on their own values, perspectives, and behaviors. This is strengthened by volunteering in projects with local community members as students come to see how sustainability is influenced by people's livelihoods, culture, and context.Student groups have worked with community partners to build small farm structures using methods of natural building (see figs. 1, 2, and 3). The natural building process is low skill but labor intensive. Therefore, community partners have used the donated volunteer time to build simple structures on their land. In most cases, students have constructed storage sheds for farm tools and food harvest preservation.The natural building process involves mixing together ratios of materials like earthen clay, sand, water, and straw. Mixing can be done with a concrete mixer, or by hand (or foot!). Structures are usually built out of felled tree trunks and bamboo, and then a clay/sand/water/straw mixture is applied on this bamboo scaffolding to make the walls. Students are split into groups for the various tasks and given a short demonstration by community members, who then provide ongoing instruction during the building process.At the end of each volunteer session, students ask questions to community members to understand things like: Why do you build with natural materials?What are the benefits of this style of building?How did you come to learn about natural building?At the end of the experience, students have built a functioning structure for community members, and students leave the experience with hands-on skills and a philosophical understanding of the natural building approach.At the end of each workday, in the evening, I attend students' reflection sessions. I offer a sociological lens to questions about culture, sustainability, and the built environment. In this particular example, I explain to students how natural building is a traditional technology that is financially accessible to most people in the world. It has the benefit of being a sustainable, not extractive, mode of building. I also try to highlight that there are natural building practitioners around the world, including in Europe and North America, to highlight the fundamental ways in which students can bring these experiences and lessons back into their own lives at the end of the trip.The field school can give students hands-on experience at implementing sustainable livelihoods and provide new perspectives on what sustainability solutions can look like in unfamiliar contexts. Students come to understand the necessary human scale of sustainable systems of production and to consider the advantages and disadvantages of common technological approaches to sustainability solutions.The experience highlights the amount of effort that goes into agricultural production processes, illustrating tensions with easily available and cheap consumption opportunities in Global North economies. The pedagogical approach centers the agroecological farmer as expert, upending the normal power structures where information flows from Global North to Global South. Building these new perspectives helps to illuminate the problematic pattern of consumption patterns in the developed world, such as industrial agriculture, that create detrimental impacts for individuals who make their livelihood through relatively sustainable actions. In this way, experiential learning can be leveraged to compel students to think critically about systemic structures of production and consumption, the negative outcomes that these structures operationalize, and the students' role in responding to these challenges.Working from the idea that the most transformative learning must take place in context, Rizoma Field School seeks to pair ideas with experiences in order to facilitate meaningful long-term changes in thinking and behaviors for our students. The ultimate goal is that students leave Rizoma with an intellectual and experiential toolkit with which to take to their part of the world and their life's work.Assessments after the period abroad confirm the transformational quality of the experience: I want others to grow in the same ways I have and to have this motivating experience. I needed a trip like this to give me the ability to feel the importance of my everyday choices regarding the environment, as well as my interactions with people. (Ohio State University Student, Buck-I-SERV 2019)This trip changed my life. I feel more equipped to live a life with my values after learning from everyone here. I am so thrilled to go home and share what I learned. (Ohio State University Student, Buck-I-SERV 2019)On this trip, I learned that service is more easily accessible than I thought. If I see a problem or want to help a cause, I realize that I can find the people that can get me involved. I will also actively promote good and sustainable ideas since I got to learn about them in Uruguay and want to share with my friends and family (University of Idaho Student, ASB Winter 2018)The world that we live in seems as if it is growing smaller and smaller and the way people notice this is through cultural diversity. People notice different mannerisms, customs, foods, language, clothing etc. These things are very interesting to me and I love learning about them and how they came about. (University of Idaho Student, ASB Winter 2018)I wanted to tell you guys just how much I appreciated this opportunity and all I have learned from your family and way of life. I raved to my parents and all my friends about how much I loved Uruguay and all the people we got to help. I feel so lucky to have gotten to go on this trip and meet all of you. Currently in the process of setting up a recycling initiative in my sorority (baby steps) and composting all our left over food to the back yard area, to hopefully start a small garden! Moscow is cold, windy and I have yet to see the sun. I could really use an afternoon at the beach and eating some of Pablo Jordan's delicious food. I am so grateful for your hospitality and wish you guys all the best! (University of Idaho Student, ASB Winter 2018)The model of Rizoma Field School describes efforts to promote sustainable consumption through experiential learning in Colonia, Uruguay. However, the approaches could be translated to a variety of settings by maintaining an emphasis on collaboration with community partners on a range of hands-on, sustainable production-oriented projects. These experiences, whether abroad or closer to home, facilitate intimate learning opportunities that make sustainability tangible. Teaching agricultural history and sociology through experiential learning with agroecological producers, if it were a model adopted globally, has the potential to transform education.

title: Teaching US History through Land-Grant Universities and Agriculture Education
abstract: Some years ago, like many recent graduates starting visiting teaching positions, I was in the unenviable position of creating new courses a few weeks before the semester started. As I constructed my syllabus for a history of science in the United States course at the University of California, Berkeley, a land-grant university (LGU), I realized that covering the history of land-grant universities was an ideal way to incorporate agricultural history and local history into the class while touching on many major themes and events in American history. Since then, I have continued to use local agricultural history and history of the LGU system to explore issues such as gender, segregation, dispossession, knowledge creation and dissemination, human and nonhuman animal relationships, and theory of bodies, health, and the environment in a wide range of courses from first-year US history surveys to graduate student history of medicine seminars at Cal, Michigan State University, and Oklahoma State University. I have designed several activities that can be adapted for different courses, content, and locations. Collaborating with the university archives and local historical associations allowed me to tailor these lessons and activities for each university and class. Discussing local agricultural education and history with students provides them with an opportunity to directly connect their college experiences with past events and actions and gain insight into how their education and institution is part of American society and history. They also learn how agricultural teaching, knowledge, and practices shaped their university and communities. In this article, I will share my current lesson plan and strategies for adapting it for different courses and skill levels.When I began my current position at Oklahoma State University, I dove into Oklahoma history to update my material on land-grant universities and make it relevant to students in my US history since the Civil War survey. As I prepared for the course, I realized Oklahoma is the only state with 1862, 1890, and 1994 Morrill Act institutions and that creating a lesson centered on these three LGUs would provide me with a platform to discuss gender, race, segregation, and land. These topics were introduced before this lesson both in the textbook and lecture, and we continued to discuss them throughout the rest of the class. Covering them in the context of agricultural education and land-grant institutions allowed students to understand how these issues shaped Oklahoma State University and connected them to their own lives and experiences.I set aside two class sessions for this lesson plan and started by sharing a photograph of the first class of Oklahoma Agricultural and Mechanical College (1862 Morrill Act) students. I asked my students who were the students attending what is now Oklahoma State University at its founding. Many in the course were surprised to see that about half of the initial student body were women, but they were not surprised by the fact that the founding class was all white. This activity segued into a brief overview of how and why land-grant universities developed and why there were three separate Morrill Acts over 132 years.After the content about the Morrill Acts, I returned to OSU for an activity about gender, higher education, and career opportunities. Using information from old course catalogs available in the university archives, I listed the seven course options that were available for first-year students in the 1901 spring semester (Etymology and Structure, German or Latin, Algebra, Geometry, Hygiene, Cooking, and Woodworking or Stockjudging) and assigned groups of students to represent seven actual students (women majoring in general science, English literature, home economics education, and zoology, and men majoring in plant agriculture, math, and engineering). The groups then selected what five courses they thought were most relevant to their major and shared their decisions with the class. After that, I revealed that some of these courses were gender-restricted (Hygiene and Cooking for women and Woodworking or Stockjudging for men).After this reveal, I shared additional content about the gendering of majors and courses at land-grant universities and started discussion with another photo analysis prompt. This image was of six students (four women and two men) in an 1896 Oklahoma Agricultural and Mechanical College dissection course. I asked the students why they thought women would be in an anatomy course, which then led to a larger discussion about how agriculture and science educational and career opportunities were gendered at the time. We kept returning to this point throughout the course as we talked about the changing roles of women in the workplace and wage disparities during the twentieth century.From there, I moved away from OSU and to Langston University, the only historically Black college or university founded in Oklahoma under the 1890 Morrill Act. This gave me an opportunity to cover segregation in Oklahoma and to provide local examples that complemented the textbook content on the issue. I shared with the students that the 1890 Morrill Act specified that the split of funds provided to the state for LGUs had to be “just and equitable” and provided an example from the archives that the split was $22,500 for OSU to $2,500 for Langston in 1900. We then discussed what “just and equitable” means and who determines that. We returned to this point the following week when talking about Plessy v. Ferguson and the concept of “separate but equal” and later in the semester when covering Brown v. Board of Education.Finally, the first class session ended with an introduction to the Land-Grab Universities project and the land dispossession that built and funded these institutions.1 Oklahoma was not covered as part of the reporting project, but by sharing the website with students, they saw the larger pattern and picture of how Native American land and natural resources were taken to build the land-grant university system. The students read about the Dawes Act and land rushes in the textbook that week, so when we talked about the “donated” land that white farmers gave to establish what is now the OSU campus, they connected the dots of how land rushes played a role in transferring this space from Native control to the university.In between the two class sessions, the students read an excerpt of Laura C. Kellogg's writing, available in the American Yawp Reader, for their weekly primary source assignment, and in addition they were asked to watch a thirty-minute documentary on the legacy of Chilocco Indian Agricultural School, an American Indian boarding school and the only one that specialized in agriculture.2 They then wrote short journal responses with their initial thoughts and questions and brought those notes to the next class.I started the second session with a brief overview on the history of Native American boarding schools and a short clip from the documentary. I used a photo analysis prompt, this one of students in front of a building at Chilocco surrounded by two fences, to spur discussion about the differences between the aims of Oklahoma's land-grant universities and Chilocco, including the differences in the educational experiences, and how the boarding school sought to replace Indigenous agricultural knowledge and practices as part of forced assimilation. To continue the conversation about forced assimilation, the students broke up into small groups to share their thoughts on Kellogg's writing, and then we talked about it as a class. We returned to this discussion weeks later when covering Native American communities during the New Deal and then again when learning about the Red Power movement and Native activism in the late twentieth century.Next, I introduced students to a new type of primary source that they had not encountered yet in the course, oral histories. First, I informed them what an oral history is and why they are of value to historians. Second, I showed them the Chilocco Indian Agricultural School Oral History Project as an example of how oral histories can be used to capture the experiences of people whose voices might not be heard or included in other sources.3 Then, I shared a segment from Claudine King's (Chickasaw) oral history interview.4 As an alum and former employee of the school, she offered a unique perspective on the transition of the institution from federal control to Native American control. We did a photo analysis prompt using an image of 1957 Chilocco Princess Marie Brown (Osage) and 1957 Chilocco Brave Gordon Roy (Ponca) to discuss the move away from forced assimilation policy at the school. I then wrapped up our discussion of Chilocco by covering the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act of 1975 and the College of the Muscogee Nation (1994 Morrill Act) and introducing the concept of self-determination and sovereignty that we returned to when covering the Red Power movement later in the semester.The last question for this lesson was a takeaway question for students to consider on their own. I asked “Why are there still three separate land-grant universities in Oklahoma?” and “Do they address the original LGU mission of benefiting the agriculture and the mechanical arts?” I reminded them to think about the intent of the institutions to serve communities in Oklahoma as they pondered the question over the weekend. We returned to this question again at the end of the semester as we discussed multiculturalism, free speech, who controls and dictates education requirements, and other current issues at universities in the late twentieth and early twenty-first centuries.Since there are land-grant universities in every state and most universities have robust institutional archives, this lesson can be adapted to any location and modified for different courses. By working with the archives at your local land-grant universities and historical societies, you can find course catalogs, photographs, student papers, diaries, letters, and oral histories that can be used in class as primary sources and to provide local content for this lesson. While Oklahoma is the only state with all three types of LGUs, the topics of gender, race, and dispossession can be covered even if there are no local 1890 or 1994 Morrill Act institutions. Focusing on historical and current admission policies and rates at your state's land-grant university or universities, including how this may vary at each individual campus in a larger system like the University of California system, and how and why those campuses were built in those locations, can provide students with insight into these issues.5This lesson can also be modified and adapted in any number of ways for upper-division students and courses. For example, when I covered this subject in an upper-division science and society course at Michigan State University, we spent more time exploring primary sources including photographs from the early years of the university. I split the students into groups of four or five; each group had a different photo that they analyzed, and then they shared their findings with the class. Another option would be to allow the students to do the research. For this lesson, I found the old course catalog and university pictures in the archives and relied on an existing oral history project housed in the library for content. In an undergraduate capstone course or a graduate course, students could conduct this research instead and share their findings not only in class but through public history projects such as a podcast or short documentary, digital maps, or specialized tours of campus.Exploring the creation and early days of agricultural education at Oklahoma State University, Langston University, and Chilocco Indian Agricultural School provided me with an opportunity to use local examples and archival resources to teach students about sexism, segregation, and forced assimilation and directly connect it to their university experiences. It also demonstrates to students how agriculture shaped education and educational institutions in the state. For historians of agriculture, this lesson can provide an opportunity to teach about the intersection of education and agriculture and how the long history of issues that campuses and students currently grapple with can be understood through this lens.

title: Plantation Life: Corporate Occupation in Indonesia's Oil Palm Zone
abstract: Recent scholarly and media attention on palm oil has documented widespread negative social and environmental consequences of its production. In this book, anthropologists Tania Li and Pujo Semedi, in collaboration with a team of Indonesian and Canadian graduate and undergraduate students, draw attention to the increasing presence of both state-owned and private oil palm plantation companies in a specific community in West Kalimantan, Indonesia. They demonstrate how corporate influence has dramatically transformed the lives of residents who remain reliant on land for their livelihoods and survival. Using both political technology and political economy as analytical lenses, they show how plantation companies (Natco and Priva) have been able to structure economic, cultural, and political lifeworlds in ways that prevent meaningful agroecological alternatives from being imaginable, let alone realized. By focusing on the productive effects of developmentalist discourses, corporate promises, cultural and nationalist narratives, as well as legal and state infrastructures, the book highlights formal and informal mechanisms and practices that seek to legitimize highly inequitable relations of dependence.Over five chapters, the book successfully shows how the entrenched forms of social, economic, and cultural hierarchy characteristic of contemporary Indonesian agrarian capitalism stem neither from the absence of state regulation nor solely from the deployment of overt violence and coercion. Rather, the authors suggest that the persistence of unequal distributional outcomes resulting from oil palm production relies on active state institutions at all scales to privilege corporate plantation interests, especially in terms of land access. It also requires various individuals to be either “willingly” co-opted into the expansion of the crop's production or complicit in “stealing” monetarily and materially from an infrastructure that ultimately, despite its seeming totalizing character, is not led by state or private elites able to know all, see all, and control all. The book's insights regarding not only the petty involvement of even the most impoverished or marginalized in the “mafia system,” sometimes for the purposes of basic subsistence, but also its elaboration of the myth of the autonomous “independent” outgrower, point to the difficulty of identifying clear victims and villains.The authors' ethnography articulates the heterogeneity of views, fates, and perspectives among different state officials, outgrowers, brokers, foremen, harvesters, laborers, and “locals,” allowing readers to appreciate the complexity of structural realities and situated contingencies faced by different actors as they respond to discourses, incentives, and risks linked to oil palm development specifically and economic development more generally. Such analytical moves demonstrate the need to question dichotomies of state-market, consent-coercion, legal-illegal, and ethical-corrupt as ways to adequately describe or judge the actions and decisions of those implicated in the realities the book discusses.In this regard, the book offers excellent insights into the predicaments faced by those who gain little or lose out from the expansion of oil palm. The authors valuably criticize existing vocabularies and approaches espoused by human rights organizations and environmental initiatives to make plantation oil palm more just and sustainable. More broadly, they convincingly argue for ambivalence toward liberal reformist frameworks, based on more “accurate” maps and land use classifications and “better” implementation of laws and regulations. For example, the heterogeneity of positions of different state officials would suggest that vague invocations of “good governance” would not be very effective in contributing to substantive change in economic and political arrangements. Relatedly, their elaboration of the contentious relationships between “local” Dayak and Malay communities and transmigrant laborers/farmers from other Indonesian provinces would suggest the difficulty of realizing alternative land tenure arrangements primarily based on indigeneity or custom.These complexities do not mean that the authors believe that genuine alternative moral economies are not thinkable or possible. Importantly, they are not inherently against cash crop production. They recognize that the region has had a long history of livelihood strategies that in part involved market-oriented agriculture. Rather, the authors emphasize a qualitative shift beginning in the 1980s when Natco and Priva began to establish themselves as corporate occupiers of the region, catalyzed in part by concomitant shifts in land and labor regimes. In addition, the authors repeatedly link the inability of collective action to act as a countervailing force to the continued vilification of organized left politics in Indonesia, especially of unions that were robust up until the 1960s. As such, the book's attention to the lingering specter of authoritarian and paternalistic rule during President Suharto's rule during 1966–98 is especially notable.The book should be of interest to agricultural historians, especially those grappling with how to periodize plantation histories in the Global South and understand resistances to its persistence from the colonial era onward. Especially with its multiple references to Ann Stoler's theoretical work on “imperial debris” and her historical anthropology of Sumatran plantations, the book's argument that plantation histories in their continuities and ruptures are simultaneously political histories of a heterogeneous Indonesian state is one that can also apply in various other contexts.

title: Purity
abstract: Abstract This article uses the concept of purity to explore the thinking of purebred animal breeders and that of eugenicists in Britain and North America between 1880 and 1920. It begins with an explanation of why such a study is important and continues with the historical background of purity's role in animal breeding over the nineteenth century and an assessment of the theoretical foundations of Francis Galton's eugenics. The article argues that the shared concern with pedigree keeping, which characterized both purebred breeding and eugenics, made it easy for historians to assume that the two fields were more connected than they actually were. In fact, the basis for purity in animal breeding—namely, inbreeding and marketability—could not migrate to eugenics. Pedigree use in animal breeding (inbreeding, consistency, and marketability) actually had little in common with pedigree use in eugenics (evidence of inheritance via statistical quantification). Unpacking this historic connection between animal breeding and eugenics has significance today for such disciplines as animal breeding itself, genetics, politics, and ethics.

title: Field Trip!
abstract: Field Trip! Many first encounter museums during a school visit. The best of such trips tend to feature close inspection of historic artifacts or opportunities to put the hand to the plow and learn by doing. These two approaches—“reading” an artifact as higher-level thinking or performing a historic task as kinesthetic learning—affirm the primary function of a museum, which is to create knowledge through interpretation of historic artifacts and archival material. Students can learn about agricultural land use and its environmental context by analyzing living collections (flora and fauna) and cultural landscapes. Through engagement with collections and interpreters, they can explore subjects as wide-ranging as social justice and civil rights, food security and human health, the social construction of technology (both mechanical and biotechnical), geopolitics of trade, and animal, seed, and soil science, to name a few.The book Interpreting Agriculture at Museums and Historic Sites (2017) explores the many ways that collections support knowledge creation focused on these agricultural subjects.1 Care must be taken with any teaching opportunity to balance the positive lessons with the complex realities of the past, negative or positive. Museums that interpret agriculture have received their share of criticism for being out of touch with guest interests. Living history, generally, has been criticized for emphasizing white perspectives and providing a romantic view of a past by avoiding discussion of conflict. Instead, those who use museums to teach through agriculture can set a new standard. Artifacts become the best examples of technological change over time and can help us learn about humans and landscapes, about cultural systems focused on crops and livestock, and about conflict at the heart of food security. Ultimately, using museums to teach through agriculture engages the student in the highest level of thinking. The student turns the material and immaterial culture they have studied into their own interpretation of a plow or a plot of land or a pot of stew simmering on a stove in an agricultural museum or living history farm near you.The process of knowledge acquisition in museums often begins with archival collections. These two-dimensional resources can take many forms, such as personal correspondence or articles in historic farm journals. Among the most useful for teaching are educational stereographs sold by the tens of thousands to teachers as formal curriculum materials. For example, Underwood and Underwood, the largest stereograph publisher in the early twentieth century, released its instructional guide, The United States of America through the Stereoscope: One Hundred Outlooks from Successive Standpoints in Different Parts of the World's Greatest Republic in 1904. It focused on national productivity including cattle, cotton, rice, and tobacco, among other agricultural products. Keystone View Company began its education division in 1905 and published Visual Education as a teacher's guide to its “600 Set” in 1906. Experts wrote the background information for these visual instructional materials. Another resource is the work of Frank M. McMurry, a professor at Columbia University, who, with twenty-four other educators, compiled The World Visualized for the Classroom: One Thousand Travel Studies through the Stereoscope and in Lantern Slides, Classified and Cross Referenced for Twenty-Five Different School Subjects.2 Agriculture, the second of the classification schemes in the book, addressed soil formation and drainage, crop cultivation, livestock care, and product management. Homer C. Price, dean of agriculture at Ohio State University, compiled 272 subject entries, stressing connections between agriculture and nine other subject headings including geology, industries, transportation, and physical geography among others.The stereographs described in the instructional manuals often included leading questions that teachers could use to guide class discussion. The text on the back of “A Home Garden” stereograph included a warm-up activity—“Have you ever had a garden of your own? What did you plant in it?” Then it encouraged students to create a list of plants the family raised in their garden and to discuss it in a Think-Pair-Share scenario. After more thinking and discussion of the vegetables and flowers raised, and of the garden plan, it asked students to apply what they learned to draw a plan of their garden and to put their plan into action by creating their own school garden.The stereograph began as a teaching tool. After being accessioned into a museum collection it becomes an artifact useful in teaching about historic education practices, including how schools engaged students in home-scale agricultural practices. The school garden, when implemented, became a tool to teach agriculture broadly defined. Today, schools are recommitting to campus gardens as part of a larger Edible Education initiative.3 Museums could do the same.Engaging youth with hands-on opportunities to work in soil, raise a garden crop, and prepare it for a meal can translate into lessons in soil and crop science, seed viability, and human health and nutrition, among other subjects. Museums can expand on these lessons with tools that gardeners used, little changed over the centuries, with historic seed display boxes and seed packets and with market wagons and market structures that supported sales to populations unable to raise their own fruits and vegetables.Museums teaching through agriculture provide hands-on and minds-on engagement. While digital resources may enhance understanding, they cannot compare to the act of stepping into a farming landscape. Living history farms, a type of agricultural museum, offer this unique experience. The artifacts that guests encounter at these cultural institutions can be as small as an open-pollinated seed saved from the last growing season for planting the next season. That could lead to conversations about seed-saving techniques, culturally distinctive seed repositories like Native Seeds Search, and seed research collections operated by the US Department of Agriculture's Agricultural Research Service and curated by plant geneticists. There are twenty of these USDA-ARS repositories in the United States, the oldest in Ames, Iowa, founded in 1947.A seed or plant could lead a student into a research project focused on one crop or livestock breed, or other mechanical technology. Such projects should draw on three-dimensional evidence (as museums exist to collect, preserve, and interpret such evidence). Museums stress the benefits of close reading of real artifacts, but many have also embraced opportunities to digitize archival and artifact holdings to increase access and use. Funding from the Institute of Museum and Library Services and the National Endowment for the Humanities support digitization projects at land-grant universities and museums. These translate into publicly accessible resources such as the “Farm, Field, and Fireside” digital newspaper archive at the University of Illinois, or “Core Historical Literature of Agriculture” and “HEARTH—Home Economics Archive: Research, Tradition, History” at Cornell University.4 Museums often have collection portals on their web pages. These virtual collections enrich source identification, data analysis, and higher levels of thinking expressed through research projects. Results can take the form of a blog, virtual exhibit, podcast, or other online delivery (as well as a more traditional research paper), focused on a region, time period, or specific farm. The finished product can combine historic horticulture and plant science lessons with cultural practice and even contemporary perspectives on such popular perishables as celery, strawberries, or pumpkins, for instance.5The largest artifact is the landscape, including historic structures, farm fields, fences, orchards, and ecosystems. As student interests increase about historic claims to land, environmental degradation, and regenerative agriculture, this largest cultural artifact becomes essential to teaching through agriculture. The past survives in the landscape. Cultural geographers and architectural historians have studied these spaces and written eloquently about the methods to read this evidence. Organizations dedicated to agricultural museums, including the International Association of Agricultural Museums and the Association for Living History, Farm and Agricultural Museums, support those working in these distinctive cultural institutions.6 Much overlap exists with others dedicated to environmental education or nature center interpretation. As a result, a rich literature exists to learn more about reading and interpreting historic and contemporary agricultural landscapes.7Between the seeds and the landscapes exist many other artifacts that support teaching through agriculture. A grain sickle, a common hand tool, can document cultural practices of grain harvest, stoop labor essential for food security, and artisanal talents of both woodworking and blacksmithing, or it can be a launchpad to talk about technological change over space and time and crop culture. Applying the social construction of technology framework to such study ensures that numerous perspectives inform exploration of the artifact(s). Yet all too often students may summarize the lesson as one of improvement. This tendency is one of the most difficult to challenge. I have participated in weeklong teacher institutes on industrialization and urged participants to apply the social construction of technology to interpret a range of harvesting technology. When asked to engage students in lessons about a sickle, a reaper, a Massey-Harris no. 30 combine, and a New Holland TR-70 combine with corn head, all teachers stressed improvement using evidence documented through statistics that confirmed savings in labor needs and faster harvest. It is difficult to move beyond these lessons that equate innovation with progress, repeated in history textbooks. Museums teaching through agriculture can complicate this history, linking certain crops to certain implements that had certain effects on people, landscapes, and the environment as well as on labor systems and the local, regional, and global food and fiber supply.Archives and artifacts cannot teach these lessons alone. The scholarship that agricultural historians generate provides the baseline. Multisensory lessons in agriculture can make new understanding created through museum collections more memorable. Holding well-worn plow handles, smelling freshly mown grass curing in the sun, hearing wheels on implements turn, seeing draft animals push into their yokes or harnesses, and tasting a meal made from a fresh harvest make quite an impression. Learning through agricultural archives, artifacts, and immersion experiences also helps students see themselves in agricultural production systems. It helps them realize the ways that agriculture influences their lives and the ways that their choices can influence agriculture.

title: Agricultural Public History, Reimagined
abstract: When feeling especially buoyant, I like to imagine a future in which busloads of students arrive in Upper Deerfield Township, New Jersey, where the agribusiness Seabrook Farms once operated. By the end of World War II, Seabrook Farms was unrivaled as a producer of canned, dehydrated, and frozen vegetables. At peak production, it employed nearly seven thousand laborers in its fields, plants, and trucking fleets. In 1947, the company directly cultivated eighteen thousand acres of land in southern New Jersey and bought produce from another six hundred small farmers to whom it also served as a creditor.1 A company town, Seabrook Farms ran cafeterias and commissaries and built and leased housing to its workforce.Most of this has not existed for decades, but in my imagination funding has been secured to reconstruct a dwelling typical of those occupied by Black migrant farmworkers from the South during the early years of World War II. Traveling up the Atlantic Seaboard, migrants arrived in South Jersey beginning in April and remained until late fall, when the last spinach was harvested. The Orchard Center Camp, which Seabrook Farms rented out, exemplified the dismal accommodations Black migrant families encountered. At Orchard Center, migrant families lived in tents or prefabricated wooden “Pemberton” homes that were sixteen by sixteen feet and usually housed between eight and twelve people. The camp had no indoor plumbing, and only four washtubs for more than 250 residents. Orchard Center was home to forty children who, too young to work, fended for themselves while their parents were on the job. White area residents fiercely resisted opening public schools to Black migrant children.2 In 1942, the federal Farm Security Administration built a seasonal camp on Seabrook Farms' property, the Big Oak camp, which accommodated a thousand people. In contrast to privately run camps, it offered workers health care, schools, and affordable housing that was not contingent on employment with a particular grower.3 In 1943, however, the arrival of Jamaican guest workers—who were guaranteed Farm Security Administration housing—led to a shortage of beds. Many Black American migrants were forced to move to Orchard Center instead.On my imagined tour, visitors to the restored quarters are introduced to individual perspectives and stories that complicate how mid-century migrant farmworkers were usually portrayed by growers—as anonymous instruments of production. Visitors hear from Joe Brown, who in the 1930s journeyed back and forth between Fort Lauderdale and South Jersey, working at the Heinz tomato processing plant in Salem and at Seabrook Farms. In 1942, Brown traveled north in a caravan of three trucks and nineteen cars after a Florida recruiter employed by Seabrook Farms put word out that the company was looking for three thousand field hands for the mid-June snap bean harvest. Migrants often arrived penniless, so timing was everything, but the recruiter assured Brown that early arrivals could work cutting asparagus. Farmworkers in New Jersey could earn considerably more than they did in Florida.4 This economic reality led white growers to use violence to try and “freeze” workers in place in the South.5Tours then enter the Seabrook Educational and Cultural Center (SECC), which, in this imaginative exercise, is no longer a basement room in a municipal building with minimal visiting hours but instead a freestanding institution actively engaging the community. Through exhibits, visitors learn the different legal and racial contexts that shaped relations of production at Seabrook Farms. Even though the company's unmet wartime labor needs strained its productive capacity, it resisted hiring Black migrants to permanent positions. Eventually, an alternative emerged. By the end of 1945, Seabrook Farms received more than seventeen hundred incarcerated Japanese Americans, who were resettled in New Jersey by the War Relocation Authority.6The SECC has traditionally told the story of Japanese Americans’ resettlement as one in which a beneficent company provided refuge to displaced citizens wrongly detained by the federal government. In my imagined museum, the narrative instead explains how Seabrook Farms practiced a form of capitalism where management sought to exploit groups of workers separated by race and connects agricultural history to intersectional Black and Asian American labor histories. C. F. Seabrook, the company's founder, opined to his lawyer in 1943 that Black men were not as “good at factory work as white women,” and that they were “happier outside in the fields and in the sunshine.”7 Attitudes at Seabrook Farms conformed to local white supremacist attitudes. In May 1944, the president of the city council in nearby Bridgeton indicated to War Relocation Authority officials that white residents would prefer “investigated American Japanese citizens”—a reference to the so-called loyalty test that incarcerated Japanese Americans had to take to be eligible for resettlement—to “undesirable southern Negro labor.”8In the museum of my imagination, the critical reckoning with racialized capitalism and industrialized agriculture continues. Visitors learn about a 1934 strike at the company where C. F. Seabrook deputized local members of the Ku Klux Klan to attack Black and Italian picketers, and about efforts in the late 1940s to sponsor Estonian displaced persons from camps in Germany in order to provide another reserve of white labor. Difficult questions are posed and answered.Sharing my dreams here is a welcome and generative flight from the often challenging work that goes into trying to realize new public histories for Seabrook Farms in practice. This work involves hours of organizing, collaboration, and stakeholder engagement. In 2019, the SECC was awarded a small grant by the New Jersey Council for the Humanities, and I was hired to organize two public meetings with stakeholders. The meetings' focus was on how new narratives and audiences for Seabrook Farms' histories might be developed.9 Delayed by COVID-19, the meetings took place in spring 2021 and were powerful events. Gloria Kates, whose family came to Seabrook Farms from Georgia in 1945, articulated what she and other Black locals felt after visiting the SECC: “Where are we?”10Students from Rutgers attended those community meetings. My pedagogical approach, more broadly speaking, has been to involve undergraduate and graduate students in conferences, exhibits, and programming related to my public history work on Seabrook Farms. I curated with undergraduate students an online exhibition for the New Jersey Digital Highway and organized with students a 2018 conference on the history of Seabrook Farms, which involved representatives from the New Jersey-based El Comité de Apoyo para Trabajadores Agrícolas and the Florida-based Coalition of Immokalee Workers discussing their organizing work with migrant farmworkers and how wage theft, deportation, and substandard housing persist as threats to migrant farmworkers.11 With John Seabrook, a New Yorker staff writer and C. F. Seabrook's grandson, I have been conducting oral histories and soliciting “memory maps” from descendants of Black workers—including one that Kates contributed to—which we hope to one day use in a digital exhibition.Teaching agricultural history should include efforts to train students to research and develop public narratives that capture the experiences of workers. In local museums and at living history farms, migrant farmworkers' stories rarely appear, even though small farms were dependent on seasonal laborers as well. The work being done to reinterpret antebellum plantations in ways that foreground the stories of enslaved agricultural workers is a relevant reframing to learn from.12 In the context of wage labor, if Seabrook Farms can similarly inspire as a public history site one day, I will rest easier.

title: Pushed Out: Contested Development and Rural Gentrification in the US West
abstract: The popular interpretation of the western economy is that of a seemingly natural boom-and-bust cycle. That story of inevitable failure curiously contradicts the equally popular progressive narrative of Frederick Jackson Turner's frontier thesis, in which American ideals of independence, self-reliance, freedom, and opportunity attracted newcomers to the region. In Pushed Out, sociologist Ryanne Pilgeram both complicates and reconciles those narratives, recognizing that since the mid-nineteenth century and the dispossession of Native lands, corporations often developed the physical and economic infrastructure for settler towns, profiting even after the nation no longer depended on the rural West for its natural resources—lumber, copper, coal, crops—to fuel industrial America.Pilgeram argues that the history of the rural West continues to guide future development decisions, as locals have, over time, come to accept the power of outside investors who cater to “amenity migration.” Nonextractive amenities cater to and attract outsiders—whether tourists, retirees, or the creative classes—to rural western places, effectively destroying the systems that provide locals with a historic sense of place. Such “gentrification” undermines the authenticity that comes from retaining or rehabilitating tangible remnants of past development and social relationships. Pilgeram historicizes the rural gentrification phenomenon as part of the boom-and-bust cycle common throughout the American West and its history, but she believes that it is a pattern that communities can break.She does this by applying sociological theory to historical patterns to understand recent commercial development in the rural West. Pilgeram develops a single case study of one Idaho town, with a local, community history perspective and archival research. Much as the timber barons extracted the region's forest and other natural resources, Pilgeram extracts a lot from her case study (and hometown) in Dover, Idaho, and specifically the battle over the controversial Mill Lake development. She has applied David Harvey's theory of the “spatial fix” to understand rural gentrification through the fickle nature of a capitalist system triggering a Marxian class struggle over places tied to local resources to explain the boom-and-bust cycle, periodically reinventing places through economic and social systems as much as actual building, to make it once again profitable.Pilgeram relegates Dover's history primarily to the first chapter, titled “A Brief History of the Last 62 Million Years,” which covers the displacement of the Kalispel people and the arrival of Europeans, until we quickly get to the establishment of Dover by the timber barons from the mid-nineteenth century through the prosperous period just after World War II, when the mill sustained its workers, who in turn built their own communities. Pilgeram emphasizes how swiftly lands passed from the government to the railroad to the barons, creating places owned by people who did not live in them and setting up unsustainable social and economic systems. Chapters 2 and 3 discuss the economic downturn in the 1980s and 1990s, along with the decaying infrastructure, not unlike in a peripheral urban neighborhood. Those in power allowed “demolition by neglect,” to borrow the preservationist's phrase, in order to rebuild the physical, economic, and social infrastructure to benefit themselves. Chapters 4 and 5 explain local attempts to resist developers by either villainizing developers or cooperating with those in power. Local residents failed to account for the systematic scaffolding of ordinances and zoning that would influence new development.Pilgeram's research is based on a local history conducted through interviews and local archives, presumably applicable to other rural western places, but the sociological approach does not engage the broader historiography of the rural American West, including Frederic Luebke's evaluation of the rural immigrant communities, Hal Rothman's Devil's Bargains, and R. Douglas Hurt's The Rural West since World War II. The “spatial fix” theory, which seems tied to the colonization process, undervalues many examples of local agency and power, but the analysis has significant value to understanding the postwar rural West.In Pushed Out, Pilgeram persuasively challenges several narratives of the rural West: the independent settler, the boom-and-bust cycle, and even that of the paternalistic company town. She argues that gentrification is not inevitable but “the product of a capitalist system reorganizing its exploitation of human and natural resources” for continued profit (164). Perhaps recognizing and understanding the authenticity inherent in a community's sense of place will allow the type of economic sustainability that actually defies the historic boom-and-bust cycle so attributed to the myth of “natural market cycles.”

title: Introduction
abstract: Many of us reading this journal have taught agricultural history in some form. The roles of animals, crops, soil, diseases, gardens, and tractors, to only name a few, are key ingredients in understanding numerous parts of our individual and collective pasts. As a result, the venues of learning can be just as diverse as the topics' influential reach. Many of the stories we tell in our university survey classes, highly specialized graduate courses, or with students in K–12 classes include agricultural history, sometimes in quite unexpected ways for both the learner and the lecturer. Agricultural history stretches across disciplinary fields and spaces of learning, and it manifests inside formalized classrooms and outside across informal ones, often in literal fields.A key lesson, then, is that to teach agricultural history is to connect learners in visceral ways just as much as intellectual ones. Feeling freshly tilled soil or smelling a recent rain across alfalfa fields matters just as much as reading primary sources. Experiential learning plays a significant part of our agricultural history pedagogy, with the “doing” of agriculture taking various forms from reading records to reading the landscape. The authors in this forum speak to these many possibilities and the uniqueness of agriculture in its capacity to connect seemingly disparate students, researchers, disciplines, and practices.“Teaching through Agriculture” is the beginning of a much longer conversation about the processes and values of teaching the agricultural past. It is also the continuation and braiding of various recent threads of inquiry in the field, including the recent roundtable in this journal, “Why Does Agricultural History Matter?”1 Each contributor offers keen insights about how they combine intellectual and experiential learning in their classrooms and, in other cases, into their local communities. You will read about successful instruction techniques in more conventional forms, the diverse kinds of primary sources these instructors use to engage learners, and perhaps unexpected ways to integrate the past and present.Teaching has long been foundational to the mission of agricultural history. The Agricultural History Society was founded by an interdisciplinary group of historians, scientists, and economists as a space for learning, with the first members including extension agents asking how history could help anchor the relevance of traditional and new agricultural practices for their farmer-audiences.2 Over the society's history, scholarship from members has included pedagogical essays that reflect on the importance of agricultural topics in the classroom, teacher-mentors, the importance of theoretical and interdisciplinary thinking in teaching, and the use of the visceral, material elements of agriculture to ignite curiosity in learners.3 The James C. Giesen Teaching Excellence Award is just one formal recognition of the society that marks this much longer dedication to teaching in the field.The beginnings of this particular forum started at two academic conferences. The first spark came at the National Council on Public History in 2017. In that meeting, David presented on the history of agricultural science and the use of archival material in instructing STEM students and then bringing those lessons to a general public. Conversations about pedagogy continued into the 2019 Agricultural History Society meeting, where David presented work with Neil Oatsvall, Jenny Barker-Devine, Pamela Riney-Kehrberg, and Margaret Weber in “The Place of Agricultural History in the History Curriculum: A Roundtable.” The scholar-teachers on this panel expanded the discussion on every educational level and encouraged us to keep carving out a space where others could join the conversation, workshop their ideas, and share teaching strategies. Nicole sat in the audience that day and later connected with David about organizing a forum for publication focused on teaching.Then COVID-19 hit. Teaching all online posed significant challenges, especially in pedagogy. We felt that this kind of forum was needed more than ever, and our next steps included issuing a call for papers for an agricultural history pedagogy workshop. Three clear interests of the group emerged: (1) the role of agricultural primary sources in framing and designing courses; (2) the use of agricultural topics in public history and community-engaged work; and (3) how the materiality of agriculture might lend itself to innovative pedagogical approaches that can take place outside, in the dirt. From there, we decided to host an online workshop in January 2022.Our call for proposals emphasized a forum for a pedagogy of agricultural history across fields. Part of this thinking had to do with the 2020–21 academic year, where many of us had to rethink our teaching in the transition to masked, outdoor, or completely virtual spaces. Effective, adaptable, engaging, inclusive teaching takes time, research, and replicability. As such, it is important to have ongoing conversations about pedagogy rooted in the future of teaching. “Teaching through Agriculture” aimed to create a virtual and textual forum about teaching in history and related interdisciplinary fields that addressed topics linked broadly to agriculture, science, or the environment.The goal of the workshop was to gather a diverse range of research, case studies, and reflections about teaching in the ever-developing field of agricultural history. And as this forum illustrates, it is ever developing. The virtual workshop included time to discuss pedagogy candidly with colleagues around the world. We also built space into the workshop to draft the pieces that would be included in this forum. The call for proposals invited participants to address teaching in any aspect of agriculture or agricultural history, including, but not limited to, experiences (whole courses or parts of classes/workshops) in archaeology and anthropology, histories of science, technology, and medicine, environmental history, animal studies, food studies, agriculture and rural life, primary school education, or FFA/4-H instruction. We especially encouraged submissions that highlighted the work and teaching of early career and/or contingent faculty, nontraditional researchers, and underrepresented scholars. We also originally focused on three central categories for analysis and discussion—activities, assessments, and assigned media—with hopes of compiling a collection of cases and tools to be used by future instructors across disciplines and educational levels. The final cohort included fourteen instructors who would contribute thirteen pieces in total.Workshop participants voiced a hunger to talk about teaching: What was working? What wasn't? What were the pressing issues of the time? How could agriculture serve as a creative connector? It was clear that agriculture was uniquely positioned to cultivate engaging, inclusive classrooms, no matter the format. Agriculture connected people across geographic and temporal scales, perhaps for the sheer reason that, as Peter Coclanis has argued many times before, food is the anchor of our history and livelihood.4 Food studies certainly lends itself to creative teaching strategies, as illustrated by leading scholar-teachers in the field experimenting with unessays, recipe archives, and in-class exercises with food.5 Such strategies needed to be retooled and reimagined in online and asynchronous spaces during the pandemic, and the “how” of these (and other) methods struck a chord with the thoughtful teachers of the “Teaching through Agriculture” workshop. How do we articulate the essence of an assignment? How do we assess its success? And how might we adopt multiple approaches—online and outdoors—into different classroom communities?
