title: From Old Regime to Industrial State: A History of German Industrialization from the Eighteenth Century to World War I
abstract: German industrialization has been the subject of heated debates among historians. During the so-called Sonderweg debate in the 1980s—which scrutinized the long-term structural developments that enabled the rise of National Socialism and attempted to explain the peculiar German path into modernity—the patterns of German industrialization and its entanglements with politics and culture ranked high on the agenda of historians. Attention to the topic has recently faded as German historiography, in the pointed words of Paul Nolte, said “farewell to the nineteenth century.” Yet economic and social historians continued to compile new econometric evidence, researched regional patterns of development, and questioned some of the assumptions that earlier historiography had taken for granted.This book encapsulates this historiographical trajectory. It provides a synthesis between two elements. One consists of a book that Richard H. Tilly published in German in 1990, Vom Zollverein zum Industriestaat; the other element presents new research tracing the roots of German industrialization back to the eighteenth century and offering new evidence on its regionally diverse evolution in the nineteenth century. Tilly's coauthor, Michael Kopsidis, is among those historians who have decisively contributed to this new perspective. The result of this synthesis is a concise, yet highly differentiated and insightful narrative of the making of the German industrial economy that connects industrialization to agriculture, state formation, the emergence of a modernizing bureaucracy, public and social policy, scientific knowledge and technology, migration and demography, and the change in financial institutions.Compared to other accounts that stress the suddenness of Germany's breakthrough to industrialization, Tilly and Kopsidis emphasize a drawn-out transition that proceeded gradually. They begin by examining the interplay between demographic change, agricultural reform, protoindustrialization, and institutional change in the eighteenth century. The spread of rural industries and protoindustrial structures contributed to a partial integration of the German economy into the flourishing Atlantic economy, yet regional differences remained important. Indeed, German industrialization was essentially an insular phenomenon. The state and a reform-minded bureaucracy played an important role, Prussia being the most striking example of a reform from above, creating a capable yet authoritarian modernizing bureaucracy that promoted a rapid transition to the market economy as a response to the challenges of the French Revolution and Napoleonic hegemony.Part 2 offers an account of early German industrialization covering the period from the Congress of Vienna in 1815 to the Revolution of 1848. Tilly and Kopsidis emphasize the role of the Zollverein, the German customs union established in 1834, as a crucial institutional precondition for integrating and widening markets. Moreover, state-supported investment in transport systems contributed to the development of closer interconnections between different regions and sectors of the economy and foreshadowed the importance of railroads as a driving force of industrialization. Out of the crises of the 1840s emerged two changes with far-reaching consequences for German industrialization: the political economy of public finance altered decisively; and the revolution, despite its ultimate failure, pushed the nonaristocratic bourgeoisie into the ruling center of power at the cost of blocking democratization.The interdependencies of steam power technology; railroads; the iron, steel, and machine industries; and coal mining had important effects on the overall economy in the 1850s and 1860s, pulling a growing share of agricultural and artisanal producers into capitalist markets and commercializing economic relationships. These developments were not without tensions. Farm families lost their subsistence and the gathering of craftsmen in centralized workshops promoted class consciousness, while economic and social inequality visibly increased.Part 4 discusses Germany's emergence as an industrial power from 1871 to 1914. This period was shaped by a more self-conscious and interventionist economic policy of the Kaiserreich; the formation of “organized capitalism” in the form of business associations, cartels, and unions; the rise of large-scale industrial businesses especially in the chemistry and electrotechnical sectors where the interplay between science and industrial production was most intense; the emergence of a new financial and monetary system with massive concentration processes in the banking sector; the rapid urbanization of the population; and a growing yet conflict-prone integration of the German economy into the world economy.In sum, Tilly and Kopsidis offer a rich and fascinating economic history of German industrialization that is, in their words, a combination of “economic history with a bit of social history” (vii). Indeed, some readers might wish to have more than just a “bit” of social history in such a narrative. The experiences, interpretations, and suffering of those who went through these fundamental changes are pushed out of sight due to an approach that favors econometric evidence, the mathematic charm of tables and graphs, and an abstract language borrowed from economic theory. One wonders, for instance, what family relationships and the gendered division of work looked like in the protoindustrial family economies of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. How did Polish and Russian seasonal laborers experience their integration into the East Elbian estate farms in the late nineteenth century? And what meaning did artisans and craftsmen give to the forces of industrial capitalism that threatened their economic existence and their way of life? Despite all its differentiated and judicious arguments on the structural development of German industrialization, the book remains strangely silent on questions like these. These reservations aside, Tilly's and Kopsidis's book is without doubt an important contribution to the history of German industrialization in the long nineteenth century.

title: West of Slavery: The Southern Dream of a Transcontinental Empire
abstract: Kevin Waite's new book is broad in geographical and chronological scope, extending from Washington, DC, across the continent to San Francisco and from the early 1840s through Reconstruction to twentieth-century memory of the Civil War. It is also broad in ambition, seeking to integrate original research with new literatures on empire and the Civil War–era West to create a new understanding of the South during the Civil War era. Far from viewing the South as a traditional, inward-looking society trying to protect old ways, Waite portrays an energetic, outward-looking society looking to create a new transcontinental empire.The book is divided into three generally chronological and topical sections. The first starts with examining the desire of southern leaders to expand to the Pacific coast both to gain more land for agriculture and to acquire California's deepwater Pacific ports vital for new markets in China. The development of a transcontinental railroad was central to this vision, with Waite commenting on the eventual irony that the “railroad, a great national project designed to bind together the American East and West, had triggered a rupture between North and South” (39). There is also a chapter on what Waite calls “the lesser slavery road,” how southerners secured a large federal subsidy for the nation's overland mail route and Jefferson Davis's plans for a camel corps to tame the West. Waite nicely shows how slave owners embraced broad construction of the Constitution and called for a massive mobilization of state power to aid their dreams of a continental empire.The second section focuses on the “southernization” of the West. Though a minority of the population, southerners dominated western states and territories through a combination of effective local politics, patronage from national Democrats, and anti-Black and anti-Chinese racism. Waite ably shows how “the view from the Desert South also throws new light on the so-called Slave Power, illuminating how it operated thousands of miles from the nation's capital” (125). In western states and territories the racism was intertwined with various forms of unfree labor, ranging from slavery to coolie labor to debt peonage. The southernization of the West meant that during the secession crisis in 1861 “as federal authority deteriorated across the continent, the Southwest had become a vast borderland of conflicting loyalties,” with some even fearing a military coup or the West splitting from the United States (176).The last section explores the fate of a southernized West in the Civil War, Reconstruction, and memory. Confederate sympathizers in California tried to cause problems, though Waite acknowledges that they never came close to overthrowing the US government, and a Confederate force of 2,500 soldiers tried to capture parts of the Southwest. Still, Waite is probably too enthusiastic when declaring in the epilogue that “Confederate grand strategy evolved from slaveholders' antebellum ambitions” (245). He is more measured analyzing how Reconstruction in the West greatly paralleled and to a lesser extent affected Reconstruction in the East. The few pages on Confederate monuments and memory in the West, including the Jefferson Davis Highway, are a nice coda to the book.Waite's book provides new ways to understand the antebellum South, the Confederacy, and the Civil War–era West by putting all three into conversation with each other. The southern interest and energetic pursuit of a continental empire using national power make the idea of an “old South” even more quaint than the last generation of scholarship has shown. Along the way, Waite gives insights into the thinking of southern leaders and tells some good stories. I have already used some material, including Davis's camel corps, from his book in my classes.

title: Histories of People and Landscape: Essays on the Sheffield Region in Memory of David Hey
abstract: English local history has thrived on exploring the deep connections of people and land over time. This memorial volume for David Hey gives tribute to a dedicated and highly regarded practitioner of local history. It serves as a testament to the many ways land and people can be studied, as well as to Hey's influence on our knowledge of his native region (acknowledged by all the contributors) and the broader field of local history.Histories of People and Landscape provides a multifaceted look at a region in England's north, historically characterized by aristocratic deer parks, common wood-pasture farming, and extractive industry. A brief preface by the editor and a personal tribute by Charles Phythian-Adams, Hey's longtime friend and a leading figure in English local history, open the volume. The ten research articles in the collection explore people and places of this region across a broad expanse of time. About half of the contributions concentrate on the early modern period, Hey's main focus. Others range more widely, examining Sheffield and its region from the time of the Domesday Book up through the twentieth century.Changing land usage is a theme of several chapters. Melvyn Jones's close study of medieval deer parks utilizes both landscape and documentary evidence to show the powerful imprint of aristocratic values on the land, as well as the ways deer parks evolved to incorporate a variety of uses beyond hunting. Ian Rotherham's piece studies the landscape to chart its history from the eleventh century until today. Using an interdisciplinary approach combining methods from ecology, archaeology, and history, he uncovers “shadow landscapes,” evidence of a changing countryside that reveals a story of the past that can act as a guide for present-day land policy. How people responded to government alteration of land use by law and policy features in John Beckett's chapter on opposition to parliamentary enclosure of agricultural manors in the eighteenth century and Nicola Verdon's piece on the food production campaign (bringing more acreage under tillage) in World War I. It comes as little surprise that those working and living on the land did not always appreciate the government's policies, in either era.The close relationship of agriculture and industry in this region is another important theme. Long known for its knives, the Sheffield area was a key early center for English steel production, as Dorian Gerhold's careful reconstruction of the region's industry shows. Studies of individual families—Peter Edwards's on the noble Cavendish family and Alan Crosby's on the yeoman Bagshaws—demonstrate that both elite and common landholders diversified their agricultural interests into mining and other activities to enhance their bottom lines. Richard Hoyle's insightful chapter on early modern Sheffield's cutlers and the earls of Shrewsbury analyzes the complex relationship between the tradesmen of the town, struggling to govern themselves and their trade, and the great noble lords of the manor who wished to control them.As with many collections of this sort, the contributions vary in scope and impact, and the volume as a whole lacks a strong analytical theme. Nevertheless, it provides a richly detailed picture of one unique region, its land and people, farms and industries, jurisdictions and place-names. It demonstrates that deep study of a particular place reveals patterns and nuances often missed in more general studies. Histories of People and Landscape, like the scholar it memorializes, champions the value of both local history as a scholarly endeavor and the region that it illuminates.

title: American Slavery, American Imperialism: US Perceptions of Global Servitude, 1870–1914
abstract: This provocative and original volume enriches the scholarship on the post–Civil War United States as a nation and empire. It avers that conservative and pragmatic arguments reoriented antislavery in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Originating in Britain, this transformation spread to the United States after its grinding Civil War and legal abolition of slavery. There, despite occasional dissent, postbellum currents saw antislavery marshaled behind anti-immigrant, patriarchal, and imperial policies. The volume is wide-ranging, surveying Anglo-American commentary on unfree labor in places such as Hawaii, Nigeria, the Ottoman Empire, and South Africa.The volume delivers a complex portrait of ideological change in the United States. The struggle over southern slavery, it holds, narrowed domestic understandings of unfree labor to the chattel form present there. Transatlantic polemics about the institution, moreover, left enduring intellectual legacies, including antislavery strategies of foregrounding ideal victims and firsthand accounts. From Appomattox to the early twentieth century, Americans carried this baggage as they encountered, in person and in print, diverse forms of unfree labor around the globe. As a result, Americans, while they generally shared a faith in their nation's antislavery credentials, mulled over and debated what constituted slavery, sometimes with policy at stake. They often invoked slavery, for example, in criticisms of other empires' labor regimes, outrage over urban prostitution (decried as “white slavery”), and warnings about allegedly unfree immigrants. Yet Americans at other times tamped down such rhetoric, especially with Jim Crow practices. Antislavery infused and helped justify American imperialism, which some claimed would free victims of local exploitation, but also anti-imperial arguments that pointed to an impending flood of unfree Asian contract laborers arriving from annexed territories. Here, despite American conceits, the United States ended up being like its European peers, whose antislavery often veiled metropolitan complicity in labor oppression. The Belgian Congo, which itself elicited American responses, was paradigmatic in seeing the empire proclaim antislavery principles only to terrorize local populations. Social Darwinists, eugenicists, progressives, and others spoke out on these topics, with many directing antislavery toward controlling laborers, colonized peoples, and women. Onlookers frequently blamed victims, whether in terms of culture, race, religion, or gender, for their predicaments. Antislavery might generate outcry over white Circassian women held by allegedly lustful Turks, but, more concretely, sustained campaigns to regulate women's behavior in urban America and exclude Asian contract laborers. A similar movement, the author notes, took place in South Africa. More critical perspectives, often attuned to antislavery's emancipatory potential, came from individuals such as Frederick Douglass, Jane Addams, and the exploited themselves.Comprising an introduction, six chapters, and a conclusion, the volume moves thematically through its subject. Featured places, developments, and authors are wide-ranging and often reappear across multiple chapters. The introduction outlines the book's scope and purpose while providing helpful context. The first chapter focuses on antebellum carryovers—including racial beliefs, proslavery charges of antislavery cynicism, and an abolitionist iconography featuring whips, chains, and dogs—that shaped postbellum perceptions and rhetoric. Chapter 2 surveys the global influences on postbellum American thinking, with the British looming large for pioneering an antislavery nationalism and imperialism while tolerating and relying on unfree forms of labor. Chapters 3 and 4 examine the othering of slaveholders and slaves, which Americans presented as both outside of and antithetical to their own progressive and pure nation. Often this was done through racial or religious categories, sometimes both. The fifth chapter focuses on gendered commentaries on oppressed women. Women were at once ideal victims in the popular imagination, active campaigners against exploitation, and yet often rhetorically denied agency in their own struggles, especially if not white. The final chapter explores how the oppressed resisted their conditions and challenged the conservative and pragmatic form of antislavery with more radical variants. The conclusion succinctly reviews the volume and gestures toward its contemporary relevance.An ambitious volume, American Slavery, American Imperialism nonetheless leaves room for rival interpretations. Murky is the exact chronology of conservatism and pragmatism's ascendancy within American antislavery. The pivotal post-abolition decade ending in 1875 receives relatively little attention but saw a host of haphazard American campaigns to spread freedom abroad as well as federal and state efforts to control laborers. Did Americans, then, need the British example to end up where they were by the turn of the century? Also, while it is plausible that the struggle over southern slavery rendered a narrow domestic conceptualization of unfree labor, the volume does not prove the point. Grounds for skepticism include long-running metaphorical uses of the term slavery, including to describe political subjection, and antebellum interest in serfdom, industrialization, captivity narratives, concubinage, and polygamy. Finally, it is often difficult to determine from the volume how cohesive American discussions were and whether the selected authors influenced each other, broader discourse, or policy making. How often did postbellum Americans draw their own connections across space to make broader points about unfree labor? This work points the way to picking up such issues, and as scholars do so they will be in its debt.

title: The Curious Case of Oscar Lorick: Race, Markets, and Militancy during the Farm Crisis
abstract: Abstract In 1985 Oscar Lorick—an aging and illiterate Black farmer clinging to seventy-nine acres of land and burdened with massive debts—turned to local farm activist Tommy Kersey to help stave off foreclosure. The ensuing mobilization tied together the NAACP, Black church networks, white supremacist militants, corporate sponsors, a millionaire benefactor, and even the Atlanta Falcons in the ultimately successful attempt to save his farm. Lorick's story serves as a point of departure to assert that the Farm Crisis facilitated the convergence of anti-federal and federal-skeptic ideologies, both radical and conventional, in the fertile ground of rural America. Relying on court records, news reports, and organizational documents, this article reconstructs a story that grabbed national attention during the Farm Crisis to demonstrate the importance of free-market narratives, racial discrimination, and the legacy of civil rights mobilization in understanding the complexity of agrarian activism in the crisis-era South.

title: Water and Agriculture in Colorado and the American West: First in Line for the Rio Grande
abstract: A relative “newcomer” to a region of the Southwest where Latino families had farmed for over one hundred fifty years, David Stiller grew fascinated with the dualities that he observed in the San Luis Valley, carved at high altitude from the headwaters of the Rio Grande. Having studied earth science at several institutions, and as a hydrologist by profession, Stiller marveled that “water was diverted from the river as much by habit as by immediate need” (xi). He set himself the task in this fourteen-chapter study “to wonder how the valley's water habits came into being” (xii).The story of water in Colorado has been told at great length, from its laws to its irrigation practices to its dryland farming successes and failures. The author reviews the basic features of these works, in particular the Colorado Doctrine of “beneficial use” and its outcomes for agricultural sustainability. Stiller also has an eye for geological detail, describing the uniqueness of the eight-thousand-feet-high San Luis Valley as a function of four stages of growth and change.These included the expansion of irrigation canals in the late nineteenth century (little is made of the customers of this crop production: the silver mines of the Rockies and the coal camps of southern Colorado and northern New Mexico). The “closed basin” phenomenon of the valley led to a rise in its water table in the early twentieth century, a condition that allowed farmers to engage in “subirrigation” instead of increasing the flow of their ditches (this at great expense then as well as now.)After a century of growth and development along Colorado's Front Range, where San Luis Valley farmers supplied potatoes, hay, and alfalfa in large quantities, the more astute irrigators realized that they could drill groundwater wells to augment their farming practices. This left holders of senior water rights facing reductions in their direct flows from the valley's streams. Persistent drought in the first two decades of the twenty-first century only exacerbated these tensions. A solution appeared with the organization of “groundwater subdistricts,” where farmers charged themselves for overuse of the aquifer, and planned more wisely for the rotation of crops for market.Where the author might contribute to knowledge about the San Luis Valley is the place of Latino farmers in its long history of irrigation. There is no population or financial data on Anglo versus Hispano, even though the author accepts the conventional wisdom that the former had advantages that the latter did not enjoy. This appears in such references as “Spanish farmers” having a more collaborative worldview than what the author calls “Euro-American” farmers, not explaining how the former preferred to celebrate their roots in Europe instead of Mexico, Latin America, or even the Southwest (32).Stiller also wrote before the appearance of evidence that Native slavery was common among Latino farmers of the Valley. Nor does the author note that the first families from northern New Mexico entered the San Luis Valley under the protection of the US Army, who were charged with removal of Native hunters who had traversed the valley for centuries.This belief in the hardiness of Latino pioneers also can complicate the author's explanation of the Front Range water market, and its investors who wished to transfer Rio Grande flows to Denver and its environs in much the same fashion as diversion projects like the Colorado–Big Thompson, the Frying Pan–Arkansas, the multiple water projects of Denver Water Company, or the sale in the late twentieth century of Arkansas River ditch-company water rights to Colorado Springs, Thornton, and Aurora.For those who are interested in how such a small source of water (the San Luis Valley holds less than 1 percent of all of Colorado's stream flows) could attract so much attention from scholars, scientists, and visitors alike, David Stiller's work is a good start. Another generation that is curious about the complexities of culture and water will benefit from the author's bibliography, and his inference that the timelessness of the valley may not be what we think.

title: Farm Crisis/Identity Crisis: Letters from 1980s Iowa
abstract: Abstract The Farm Crisis of the 1980s was not just an economic crisis, but an identity crisis for the two-thirds of Iowa farm families that risked losing their livelihoods. Confronted with a situation that was well outside of their control, they sent thousands of letters to government officials, asking for, and sometimes demanding, answers. Many of those letters expressed puzzlement, anger, and disappointment as writers tried to explain how the hopes and dreams of a lifetime had slipped through their grasp. They expressed deep frustration with politicians, consumers, and even other farmers who did not understand or sympathize with the stresses imposed by markets, environmental forces, and government policy that first encouraged borrowing and expansion, and then punished those who had followed that advice. Although the Reagan administration eventually responded, it was not before a significant number of farmers had left, or been removed from, their land.

title: The Orchards of Eastern England: History, Ecology, and Place
abstract: This book explores the material forms, economies, ecologies, and cultural histories of orchards in an interconnected way that will be of interest to a wide range of academics and general readers. The scope is broad, taking a comprehensive and critical view of the place of orchards in the English landscape as a whole and their place in the national context of developments in horticulture, agriculture, landscape architecture, and community planning. The book situates these larger movements in detailed examinations of specific orchards in towns, villages, and individual estates. In both respects, the book is exemplary, providing a social and humanistic study of orchards that has been lacking until now, despite broad popular interest in the subject.The book presents a wealth of information on the specific local circumstances of orchard management in eastern England. For the local historian, the book serves as a blueprint for how one might conduct further investigations, providing examples of different research methods, resources, and honest accountings of the questions yet to be addressed. The authors use historical and modern maps, archival and documentary sources, and ground-truthing evidence collected by volunteers through the “Orchards East” project.The authors apologetically explain the limitations of each of these sources in assessing changes in landscape over time, acknowledging “the impression of accuracy that obscures . . . the uncertain character of much of the data,” as well as the difficulties of defining an “orchard” in the first place (167). But this apology highlights for the reader the authors' achievement in bringing all these resources into useful conversation with each other. They have not only greatly increased the knowledge of the material realities of orchard landscapes over time, but have also introduced a new intellectual critique of the limits of knowledge, deepening our intellectual questions about what we think we can know, and thus how we can orient conversations about local landscape identity, conservation, and preservation.Another audience who will benefit from this book is the growing national and international community of people interested in the history of orchards and cider. While the eastern counties of England were not oriented toward the cider industry in the same way as the West Country, the growing enthusiasm for orchard preservation has coincided with a revival in the cider industry both in England and abroad. The authors are in conversation with the orchard conservation movement, and the rigor of their investigation into local data allows them to explore the impact the conservation of orchards, spearheaded by community groups and enshrined in agricultural, environmental, and planning policy, can really have on local landscapes.The authors' critical inquiry into the meaning of tradition and the efficacy of environmental conservation in the contexts of orchards is perhaps their greatest contribution to academic and public discourse on the topic. While the authors are supportive of the positive effect that romantic enthusiasm has had on the effort to conserve orchards and sustain local ecologies and landscapes in the face of industrialization and suburbanization, they do a great service by gently prying open the popular assumptions and myths attributed to orchards. Romanticism, myth, and sentimentality are not only vital threads of our personal and social attachment to orchards—and thus our conceptions of cultural heritage—but are woven into the ecological and environmental arguments for conservation policy. The authors ask the reader to think more critically about the way conservation is conceptualized and deployed in specific policies and to weigh whether policies are delivering outcomes that serve the greater good. In an era where discussion of conservation is quickly polarized, this nuanced approach opens up a trove of new creative orientations on the subject.Though often discussed in terms of tradition when targeted for conservation, orchards have specific histories related to the expansion of industry and transportation. The authors argue that “landscapes in which orchards formed a key element—ones that owed much of their distinctive ‘character’ to fruit production—were, for the most part, a nineteenth- and twentieth-century development.” The authors ask, “Given that landscapes have primarily been shaped by practical considerations—by agriculture and industry—and are constantly changing, how do we decide which of their constituent elements are worthy of protection?” (238).Growing out of a publicly funded project, relying on data-gathering and knowledge production by community members, and in conversation with sectors involved in the creation and application of public policy and preservation, this book is remarkably democratic in its construction of a knowledge community. While not every chapter will interest every reader in focus or detail, it is written in an accessible style that invites this diverse knowledge community into a rich and detailed conversation about the subject matter while elevating the intellectual pitch of that conversation to productive new levels. This book dives into the specific density of its topic with such rigor that, rather than closing the subject to future investigation, its intellectual framework opens up the possibility of new works on orchards everywhere and suggests new questions to investigate in light of the wealth of data presented about eastern England.

title: Threatening Property: Race, Class, and Campaigns to Legislate Jim Crow Neighborhoods
abstract: While many scholars have documented attempts at urban housing segregation in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, historian Elizabeth Herbin-Triant reveals how, in North Carolina, ideologies regarding housing segregation in cities also influenced the southern countryside. White demands to control where African Americans lived grew more fevered as Black families grew in economic power. Concerned about continued loss of property and economic standing, middling whites in particular tried various methods to control and suppress Black property acquisition in urban and rural areas.Herbin-Triant starts her history by explaining how North Carolina's geography and large population of independent, yeomen farmers meant that a significant segment of white farmers embraced a vision of self-sufficiency, democratic engagement, and individualism. These small white farmers acutely felt competition for property from increasingly successful Black farmers. At the turn of the twentieth century, Black farm ownership was expanding and white land ownership was diminishing, a fact that many whites attributed to African Americans' willingness to accept “lower standards of living” (37). Migration to urban areas, too, produced racial tensions. In cities such as Winston, middling whites grew alarmed by growing numbers of Black workers seeking homes in historically white neighborhoods near employment centers. Resentment from working poor and middling whites produced violence and experiments with property segregation that took the form of restrictive covenants and, when those measures failed, racial zoning (which was soon ruled unenforceable).Clarence Poe, the young editor of Progressive Farmer, eventually the largest circulating farm journal in the Southeast, followed such urban segregation practices and the writings of South African apartheid architect Maurice Evans closely, considering how property segregation might be used to advance white small farmers' interests. Embracing populist ideals, Poe promoted yeomen self-sufficiency and the idea that white farmers should work together to benefit white farmers as a group. He sought a successful recipe for land segregation that would strengthen white farmers' economic opportunity and withstand challenges in court, and he regularly promoted the advantages of property segregation in his journal and in other venues. However, elite whites (whether urban industrial interests or rural planters) saw few advantages in property segregation: they saw no reason to hobble Black economic achievement, particularly because it did not threaten their own economic standing. They did not want to encourage migration by stifling Black success, as they depended on easy access to low-cost Black labor, and some thought individuals should be able to dispose of property as they wished. Thus, elites thwarted the property segregation efforts of middling whites in towns and the countryside.While there are already a number of scholarly works examining housing segregation in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, Threatening Property makes several important contributions to the subfield. Herbin-Triant shows that property segregation was an evolving conversation between urban and rural areas, and at least some white leaders saw advantages to implementing racial segregation in nonurban spaces. Furthermore, she outlines how this North Carolina story is both locally contingent and illustrative of national trends: North Carolina had a white independent, yeomen tradition that meant that farmers who owned (or had owned) small farms felt particularly threatened by and had the potential to be mobilized against Black economic success, a situation that Democratic political leaders took advantage of and that resulted in, among other things, Black disenfranchisement. At the same time, Winston reflected national engagement with racial segregation practices: it mimicked other cities in its attempts to confine Black families to neighborhoods lacking in resources or with fewer advantages. But the author is particularly successful in demonstrating how elite and middling whites experienced and responded to the “threat” of Black economic success in different ways. The elite white inclination to allow some measure of Black economic progress prevailed because elites held significantly more power. Thus, within the white community, conflicting class desires meant that some white supremacist agendas failed, even while white supremacist infrastructure (such as de facto social segregation) endured. And at least in the instances described, the failure of the middling white agenda benefited Black families who owned property or sought to, even while white racist terror continued.

title: An Empire Transformed: Remolding Bodies and Landscapes in the Restoration Atlantic
abstract: The ascension of Charles II in 1660 marked a new era for England and its empire. Eager to bring order to English people and landscapes across the globe, the king and officials embraced the rhetoric of improvement and envisioned new projects that would (hopefully) turn rhetoric into reality. This, in turn, would create a healthy body politic. Kate Luce Mulry tracks this language, the policies that came from this rhetoric, and their consequences in An Empire Transformed. In doing so, she charts efforts to reconstitute a disaggregated body politic that was not only separated by the Atlantic Ocean, but also reeling from the Civil War and Interregnum. To encourage healthy English subjects, officials and thinkers envisioned projects that would transform landscapes from the fenlands to London's streets to Jamaican forests. As a result, An Empire Transformed chronicles the environmental history of state building in the early modern Atlantic world.An Empire Transformed begins in London on the eve of the 1666 fire. Mulry tracks how the dual disasters of plague and fire influenced how officials and Londoners conceived of the city, its urban spaces, and its inhabitants. As disease circulated among residents, officials quickly blamed the city's poor. In public discourses from pamphlets to proclamations, people reflected on how to prevent infection and improve the city of London. Similar discussions ensued in the wake of the fire. People of diverse backgrounds promoted different visions for the city's rebuilding. While many of these plans were too difficult to implement, small changes to the urban landscape enabled Londoners to mitigate the risk of similar events. For those interested in city planning and the rhetoric of improvement, the first chapter shows how this language guided recovery efforts in the wake of disasters. Moreover, it charts the emergence of city planning impulses that soon guided colonization in North America. Though firmly focused on London, this chapter's story has transatlantic implications.The next two chapters show how promoters and Restoration officials envisioned drainage projects as public health initiatives on both sides of the Atlantic. The English viewed swamps as dangerous places that were often inhabited by people deemed “unruly” by metropolitan and imperial officials, including fenlanders and Native Americans. Mulry tracks efforts to bring order to these environments—efforts that officials hoped would also improve the health and character of residents. By analyzing efforts to drain the English fenlands alongside projects to transform the marshy shores of the Delaware River, Mulry demonstrates how improvement was not only a transatlantic project, but also a collective one. Restoration officials, writers, and colonists all proposed ways to improve English landscapes. Yet, these public works projects were not always supported, especially by non-English residents of the colonies. Along the Delaware River, such projects raised important questions about public and private property as well as the ability of officials to demand labor from non-English residents in the wake of conquest. Local residents—as well as seasonal changes in environments—often undermined the quest for improvement.The final two chapters chart the role of food and gardens in England and its empire. For Restoration officials, food was both a mechanism of control and essential to a healthy body politic. As a result, officials sought to ensure reliable access to foodstuffs through legislation and state-sponsored agriculture. In England, some argued for the creation of grain storehouses. In the colonies, officials promoted planting orchards to not only showcase the English ability to control nature, but also to guarantee foodstuffs for residents. At the same time, English officials and thinkers promoted certain kinds of food as more appropriate than others. Because the body was believed to be porous, one's health depended on where one lived and what one consumed. Some foods were deemed more “English”—or appropriate—than others. As English officials sought to Anglicize diets, they also sought to build gardens. Envisioned as places to grow medicines to heal body politics, they would also create smellscapes that could transform the “wild” environs of Jamaica into a more civilized place.Situated at the intersection of environmental, imperial, and political history, An Empire Transformed enriches our understanding of the English Atlantic by tracing improvement projects throughout England and its colonies. But one wonders how much of this story is unique to the Restoration. In many ways, this story extends beyond the reign of Charles II, in both directions. Indeed, the rhetoric of improvement is a well-known aspect of England's transatlantic empire. While this longer story is obscured, Mulry's focus on the Restoration allows scholars to better understand the false starts and unfinished (or even hypothetical) plans of the mid-seventeenth century. Mulry chronicles how officials, colonists, and writers discussed not only how to improve English environs, but the best ways to do so. The quest for improvement was fraught with debate, incompletion, and myriad challenges. Indeed, Mulry ultimately shows that efforts to bring order to English places could, in fact, sow disorder.

title: A Moral Duty to Uphold the Family Farm”: The Religious Response to the 1980s Farm Crisis
abstract: Abstract The 1980s Farm Crisis began receiving national attention in the middle of the decade in large part because of Hollywood films such as Country and the star-studded Farm Aid concert. However, religious leaders and organizations had already started to warn of an impending crisis as early as 1978. They were motivated by a scriptural belief in land stewardship as well as empathy for their struggling rural parishioners. Throughout a series of noteworthy conferences, position statements, and protest actions coordinated by religious organizations across the denominational spectrum, Midwest-based leaders increasingly attempted to raise awareness, influence public policy, and bear witness to the escalating crisis. This article documents these ecumenical efforts during a pivotal time in America's rural history and provides a new angle on the farm crisis of the 1980s.

title: The 1980s Farm Crisis: A Boots-on-the-Ground Retrospective
abstract: Abstract In 1979 the author of this article was hired to write for Successful Farming, a national magazine founded in Des Moines, Iowa, in 1902. This led to a privileged, front-row-seat perspective on the lead-up to the 1980s Farm Crisis, the depth of the financial turmoil, and its devastating aftermath on rural America. This article highlights the trajectory of the 1980s Farm Crisis, and reveals how her coverage documented the impact on farmers, as well as the efforts of support groups, farm organizations, and the US government to stabilize farms and farmers, and to keep families on their land. The financial repercussions are noted, but the focus is the emotional toll of the crisis, including stress, depression, suicide, divorce, dysfunctional family relationships, rural social problems, and how the Farm Crisis frayed the fabric of rural communities.

title: Land without Masters: Agrarian Reform and Political Change under Peru's Military Government
abstract: Anna Cant's book is an innovative study of the politics of the most radical agrarian reform in Latin America, in terms of the land expropriated; the speed with which cooperatives were created; and their rapid collapse and subsequent division into small, individually owned private property units. Peru's agrarian reform was not associated with violence, and was managed by a special bureaucracy under a left-leaning radical military government.On June 24, 1970, Gen. Juan Velasco Alvardo decreed the beginning of this agrarian reform. Television newscasts of the army occupying the largest sugar plantations amazed even the most skeptical civilians. Another part of the reform effort was carried out in the Andean highlands, dissolving the traditional hacienda system and liberating the Indigenous colono population who were obligated to work without pay in exchange for small subsistence plots.Agrarian reforms were demanded by communists, unions and worker movements, peasants, and revolutionary thinkers for at least half a century prior. Such reforms were also deemed a priority for Latin America by the West, backed by international institutions such as the Organization of American States, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, and John F. Kennedy's Alliance for Progress. Velasco's government declared that it was neither communist nor capitalist, but nationalist and reformist. It ruled through a corporatist, top-down bureaucracy that affected businesses, institutions, communications, social norms, schools, and civilians from every walk of life.This book is a remarkable study of the most controversial aspect of this dictatorship's rule, the Sistema Nacional de Movilización Social (SINAMOS). Its phonetic pronunciation could be understood in Spanish as sin amos, without masters. SINAMOS was eventually shut down in the second phase of the military rule by General Francisco Morales Bermudez in 1976 when the military had become unpopular and SINAMOS its most visible target.Subsequent regimes, especially Alberto Fujimori's, dedicated themselves to undoing most of Velasco's policies. The state apparatus was weakened and decentralized, and its archives were dispersed. Neglected papers decayed or were destroyed. With meticulous and cleverly applied methods and lots of patience, Anna Cant has reconstructed the activities of SINAMOS's offices in three regions: Piura on the North Coast, Cuzco in the Highlands, and the coastal department of Tacna on the border with Chile.Chapter 2 presents the results. SINAMOS caused tensions between different bureaucracies as newly recruited intellectuals from the Left exasperated officers of the ancien régime with their rhetoric. In Piura, preexisting unions, peasant confederations, and land-hungry social movements promoted land occupations before, during, and after Velasco's decrees, and consequently, SINAMOS's expropriations competed with peasant land occupations on the same terrain. In Cuzco, enthusiasm for the Confederación Campesina Peruana led to a lukewarm response to the recruitment efforts of the pro-Velasco Confederación Nacional Agraria. SINAMOS also fostered the recognition of official comunidades campesinas created from the lands and people of ex-haciendas, and these communities sabotaged the efforts of the gigantic collective state farm that government agencies had created. Finally, in Tacna, a region of smallholder properties without many haciendas to expropriate, SINAMOS was met with indifference.In Chapter 3, Cant examines SINAMOS's activities promoting the extension of citizens' rights, aimed at awakening the Indigenous political consciousness while devising mechanisms to make it congruent with Indigenous cultural norms as well as those of the nation. It moved away from the image of meek inferiority so that Indigenous people could occupy their rightful space in the modern nation of Peru. SINAMOS adapted and incorporated pedagogical techniques to reach out to colonos, the landless, and very poor casual laborers. Velasco renamed the Indians campesinos to address them as beneficiaries of the agrarian reform. Practices included literacy campaigns, puppet theaters, broadcasting programs, and official recognition of the Quechua and Aymara languages and their use in newspapers, TV, and radio shows.Though short-lived, these initiatives did a lot for the peasant population. The literacy campaign, for example, produced people who could sign only their name, but that permitted their acquisition of citizen papers and a legal identity. Educational reform pushed the children of campesinos into schools, wearing a single uniform that erased class distinctions, and the officialization of Indigenous languages brought smiles to waiters in Lima restaurants. Though a token, this was important. In carrying out its mandate to politicize the downtrodden campesino, SINAMOS incorporated other branches of government, culture, education, mass communications, and legal affairs into the tasks of social mobilization. Though brief, SINAMOS's impact was important. I agree with Cant that the effects of these measures went beyond the agrarian reform, that they were part of the social and political emancipation that the reform intended, and that it planted the seeds of processes that are still ongoing.On the other hand, the reform and SINAMOS generated strong opposition. Resentments and critiques often relied on cruel humor in gossip circles; Velasco's stern face became a repeated image in anticommunist editorials. A powerful right-wing opinion regarded the Velasco regime as a total disaster. The other side responded, in more measured terms, that Velasco's reform was a watershed in social and political terms. I compared it to the abolition of slavery in the Americas in Ugly Stories of the Peruvian Agrarian Reform (2009). Those changes are more lasting and are relevant to a rethinking of the historical trajectory of the nation. The agrarian reform emancipated a lot of people with an official act, full of its own limitations and contradictions and accompanied by a maverick style of interventions of which SINAMOS was the most interesting example. While middle-class urban rhetoric demonizes Velasco, his memory is still admired and maintained by more marginalized people, with gratitude for his programs expressed in shantytowns, villages, and campesino homes.

title: Frederick Watts and the Founding of Penn State
abstract: Part biography and part school history, Williams's book provides a well-researched and richly detailed story of Frederick Watts—businessman, lawyer, gentleman farmer, and president of Penn State's board of trustees—and his role in both the establishment of Pennsylvania's only land grant college and its surprising struggle to survive in the years 1864–82. In addition, the author includes an excellent chapter on Watts's work after he left the school's board to serve as President Ulysses S. Grant's commissioner of agriculture from 1871 to 1877. Williams states that his goal is to present a “fuller biographical treatment” of his subject and he largely succeeds in this task (xiii). He provides a more honest and realistic history of Watts's involvement with Penn State as he notes that many previous, but unnamed, biographies verged on hagiography. Readers do get a fuller picture of both Watts and these early decades in the college's history, but Williams does not always provide sufficient analysis and oftentimes he presents pieces of the puzzle but does not necessarily fit them together or state their importance and the result is that one is left to infer things or to just wonder about them.The book focuses on the “critical period” in Penn State's history, according to Williams. Following the death of its first president, Evan Pugh, the school entered a very difficult time during which it suffered greatly and almost failed because the spate of new leaders who followed either did not truly understand or were not dedicated to the agricultural/industrial mission of the school as outlined in the provisions of the first Morrill Act (1862). In short, the author tells us that this was a disaster for the school and states that “Watts, as president of the board of trustees until 1874, must bear the strongest measure of accountability for the appointment of four of five of the institutional presidents who floundered and failed during this eighteen-year retrogression” (xiii). The school's presidents during this time—William Allen (1864–66), John Frasier (1866–68), Thomas Burrows (1868–71), Rev. James Calder (1871–80), and Joseph Shortlidge (1880–82)—all varied in ability, background, effectiveness, interest, and vigor. Frequent changes at the top brought revisions in the curriculum. Some of these were generally positive, but others weakened the agriculture and science core and a least one was a blatant attempt to transform the college into a classical institution of higher learning. Williams notes challenges from the outside were no less dangerous, including the school's struggle to maintain its exclusive land grant funding and carping from Keystone State farmers and the members of the Pennsylvania Agricultural Society and the Grange who were eager to find fault with almost anything related to the college. These streams of discontent combined into a potent toxic mixture that damaged the institution's reputation among members of the legislature and the public at large and constituted an ongoing existential threat. Faced with this sea of troubles, with Watts at the helm, the board fumbled repeatedly in the searches for new leadership and Williams points the finger at Watts for the errors and even questions his commitment to the school's mission.This assessment is perhaps too harsh on Watts. Williams demonstrates but never says outright that Watts shares the blame for the choices of ill-suited presidents with the entire board. If the candidate pools for the president were weak, the board had five different opportunities to come up with a creative solution to finding an appropriate new leader for the college. It could have run the school itself for a time—extending the time of the search until it was able to locate a more suitable candidate to fill the position or even consulting the boards or presidents of other land grant institutions. And maybe it needed to make the criteria for the job clearer. Williams attributes the board's poor selections for new college presidents to expediency, yet he never clearly states the origins of this sense of urgency. He presents clues but neglects to put them together for the reader. Surely the rush to fill the presidency of the school multiple times stemmed from a sense of pressure, a fear of failure, and growing complaints about the school and doubts about its effectiveness. There were many eyes on the institution, and some wanted it to fail so they could accrue clout and political power or to take the land grant money. Ironically, in moving quickly to fill the college president's seat, the board was providing more fuel for the growing chorus of critics by helping to create the very situation it wished to avoid.Although he presents a great deal of information about Watts, Williams does not attempt to explain the man's unfortunate poor performance in guiding the selections of college presidents. Again, he scatters several pieces of the puzzle around, but he does not put them together and he leaves it to the reader to try to discern what might have been behind this situation. He does indicate that while president of the board of trustees of the college, Watts had many other interests that occupied his attention, including two farms and his service as the head of the board of directors of the Cumberland Valley Railroad. These responsibilities had to be time-consuming. For instance, Williams notes Watts's “parsimonious management” of the railroad (20). Although his penny-pinching style saved the company once and contributed to increased profits, at the end of his tenure in 1873, he was criticized for it. This suggests that Watts was a conscientious person and careful with other people's money—admirable traits for someone who runs an organization with investors. It is certainly possible that he brought that same level of frugality to the management of his household, his farms, and the college, too. Evidence of this can found in his intimate involvement in the design of the barn on the experimental farm at the college, for which he even provided specifics for the materials and fastenings for “racks” in the building. Watts was well-known for his innovative barn design on his Carlisle farm but it is odd considering all he was responsible for that the president of the board of trustees would take the time to involve himself in such a small thing. Did his penchant for frugality and an apparent love for minutiae distract him while attempting to grapple with issues posed by recurring searches for college presidents? It seems incredibly likely. Furthermore, Williams overlooks the fact that Watts was the father of nine children. Their education, health, and general well-being also had to have taken some of his attention during the eighteen-year period when the board struggled and floundered in its efforts to find a person who had the same drive and vision as Evan Pugh to lead the school.Williams provides a wealth of detail about the early history of Penn State and addresses previously unanswered questions about its past. However, the book prompts many new questions about this rocky period in the history of the school and agricultural education in Pennsylvania. Nevertheless, it could very well be a “must read” for many of the school's graduates in the agricultural sciences. The work should inspire others to do more research on the unresolved questions that it raises.

title: Reflections on the 1980s and After: An Interview by Pamela Riney-Kehrberg with Paul Lasley and David Ostendorf, February 24, 2022
abstract: Paul lasley and david ostendorf were crucial participants in Iowa's response to the Farm Crisis of the 1980s. Paul Lasley had just finished his PhD and a postdoc in rural sociology at the University of Missouri when he came to Iowa State University. He worked on many projects that helped farmers cope with the decade's troubles, and often mediated between competing groups in his position with Iowa State Cooperative Extension. He was the founding editor of the Iowa Farm and Rural Life Poll, which gathered important evidence of the effects of the crisis at the ground level. Rev. David Ostendorf came to Iowa as part of the advocacy group Rural America. He arrived thinking he would be working on rural housing issues, but quickly found himself working with embattled farmers. When Rural America dissolved, he founded and headed PrairieFire, one of the decade's most important activist agricultural organizations, which demanded and provided aid to distressed farmers. Lasley has recently retired after forty years in Extension and rural sociology at Iowa State. Ostendorf continues to be a minister in the United Church of Christ, as well as organizing on issues of social, economic, and racial justice.In an hourlong conversation, the two of them reflected on their experience of the 1980s, the changes that have happened in agriculture and rural communities in the decades since, and the importance of history.

title: The Dam and the Valley: Land, People, and Environment Below Buffalo Bill Dam in the Twentieth Century
abstract: In 1915 the United States Reclamation Service (USRS) chose the Shoshone Project in Wyoming as the model for the reclamation idea at the PanamaPacific Exposition in San Francisco. It built a tabletop scale model to show such features as the storage dam, diversion dam, and distribution system. As the distilled essence of the engineer's idea of reclamation, it was a popular element of the Department of the Interior exhibit at the exposition.1 Dam a river where it leaves the mountains, regulate the flow downstream to where it can be diverted to cover cropland, and then watch the social and economic capital accumulate around it. This view of the dam, stubborn in its simplicity, remained at the heart of the reclamation vision. But the valley?both the land itself and the people who lived there?often had other ideas, and the conse? quences of damming and diverting the water of the Shoshone River have frequently proven more complex than the reclamation idea ever acknowledged. The Shoshone Dam (renamed Buffalo Bill Dam in 1946) was constructed in a narrow rock canyon a few miles upstream from Cody, just below the confluence of the north and south forks of the river. title: Heyward G. Leavitt's Influence on Sugar Beets and Irrigation in Nebraska
abstract: From the time Heyward G. Leavitt moved to Grand Island, a town 140 miles west of Omaha, he was actively involved in the establishment of Nebraska's sugar beet industry. Leavitt promoted the growing and processing of sugar beets, including building his own factory. When he saw the necessity for change, he quickly moved to the North Platte Valley of western Nebraska, first developing an irrigation project that was needed to raise sugar beets, then actively promoting the establishment of a sugar refinery in Scottsbluff. Leavitt was a visionary with the ability to attract investors with the large amounts of capital necessary to promote his projects; however, he seldom persevered long enough to profit from these projects. Leavitt was born in New York City, 22 March 1861, to prosperous parents, Henry S. and Martha A. Young Leavitt. His father was a New York banker, his paternal grandfather, David Leavitt, was president of American Express National Bank, and his maternal grandfather, Henry Young, was a banker and a builder of gas plants in Chicago, New York, and elsewhere. After attending private schools, Heyward graduated from Harvard 1882, and Columbia Law School in 1884. He practiced patent law for a time in New York City but left to work with his grandfather Young's gas plants. Around 1887, Leavitt moved to Grand Island, Nebraska, to operate the Grand Island Light and Fuel Company, of which he was president.1

title: Water in Print: Nature and Artifice
Jewish Agricultural Experiment, Wellington, Nevada, 1896-1902: Epilogue to a Communal Failure
abstract: Two major population shifts toward the end of the nineteenth century catalyzed the Jewish colonization of Wellington, Nevada. The first of these was the forced emigration of millions of Russian Jews following a wave of anti-Semitism during the reign of Czar Alexander III beginning in 1881. The second was the desperate attempt by the state of Nevada to offset the effect of its eroding mining economy and the precipitous decline in its population. One of the proposed solutions to the problems created by an inundation of unwanted new immigrants to American eastern cities was the relocation of Jews to rural sites throughout North America. The philanthropic Baron de Hirsch Fund provided transportation assistance from Europe to New York City, where the wealthy Jewish banker and entrepreneur, Jacob Schiff, helped to deploy clusters of Jews to remote agricultural sites. Nevada's prescription for its malaise was to advertise for immigrants. One group responding to the call included the family of Joseph Nudelman, whose experience mirrored the idealism, struggles, and failure of the late-nineteenth-century Jewish agricul? tural colonizing movement. The Wellington agricultural experiment is significant for a number of rea? sons. First, abundant land partly under cultivation, an adjacent river water

title: The Changing Political Fortunes of the Truckee-Carson Irrigation District
abstract: in California and end in Nevada. The Truckee River originates at Lake Tahoe and is fed below the lake by Prosser Creek, Martis Creek, Independence Creek, and the Little Truckee River. After crossing the border into Nevada, the Truckee flows east through Reno and Sparks, then turns north and ends at Pyramid Lake, natural sink or basin, from which water can only leave by evaporation. The headwaters of the Carson River originate in east and west forks in Alpine County, California. As it flows eastward the Carson River is impounded by the Lahontan Reservoir, part of the Newlands Project. After it is used for irrigation purposes on the Newlands Project, the water terminates in the Carson's sink, a wetland which fluctuates in size depending on the extent of the winter's snow pack in the Sierra Nevada Mountains.1 This article examines the changing political fortunes of the Newlands Project irrigators and their governing entity, the Truckee-Carson Irrigation District (TCID). The TCID is controlled by an elected board of directors cho-

title: Putah Creek: Water, Land, Wheat, and Community in the Sacramento Valley in the 1850s
abstract: On 17 February 1854, George Washington Pierce and his wife, Eunice, arrived at the Ranch on Putah Creek in southern Yolo County in the lower Sacramento Valley to begin work as hands. It would be the third time in less than twenty years that the two had, in effect, started over. As young adults, both had migrated in 1835 from the East?he from upstate New York, she from Connecticut?to the fringes of the Midwest in Southport (later Kenosha), Wisconsin. They married in 1846, started a family, and seemed destined to live out their lives in this community of wheat farmers. Three years of severe drought, however, brought widespread crop failure by 1851. Many of their neighbors had already been swept westward by the intense excitement of the Gold Rush, and in April 1852, the Pierces followed them, leaving their son, George Jr., behind with relatives. After a four-month overland journey, they arrived in the Sierra foothills only to find that surface deposits had been depleted by the 100,000 forty-niners who had gotten there ahead of them. Too ashamed to return home, the Pierces turned to what they knew best. When Charles Greene, an old friend from Kenosha and now man? ager of the Big Ranch, offered them work, they jumped at the chance to start afresh.1

title: The Problem of Leasefarming in Eighteenth-century Piedmont and Lombardy
abstract: There are good reasons for taking up the problem of leasefarming in eighteenth-century Europe. The leasefarmer, paying cash rents in return for control over all the harvest, was the central figure in the physiocratic program of economic growth, the champion who could revive and expand the French economy with proper support from the laws. For the Swiss scholar Herbert Luethy, Quesnay's idea of winning the crown over to agriculture of large landed estates administered by 'capitalist farmers' was so much the apt attempt at saving the old regime from itself that, in comparison, Voltaire's attack on physiocracy, his UHomme aux quarante ecus (Geneva, 1768), coming from the pen of the feudal lord of Ferney, can only appear as an act of bad faith. Indeed, in a massive thesis of 1994 about the leasefarmers in the Ile-de-France in the fifteenth through the eighteenth centuries, the French historian Jean-Marc Moriceau has brought to life an astonishing collection of these physiocratic entrepreneurs and entrepreneurial families, whose secular accumulations of capital and leaseholds, whose technical achievements and social promotions, bringing wealth and status to themselves and enrichment to the national economy, are sufficiently impressive to raise doubts about the established understanding of pre-Revolutionary France as a brilliant but fatally sclerotic civilization. Conversely, the American Philip Hoffman, in a recent study in econometrics, claims that making sense of this kingdom

authors: Douglas Helms Douglas J. Lawrence P Smith

abstract: Water-quality considerations are, and historically have been, integral to soil conservation, not separate from it. In establishing the Soil Conservation Service (SCS), Congress directed the new organization to carry out a continuing program of soil and water conservation.1 Conservation methods and practices usually provide benefits to multiple resources, such as soil, water, plants, and animals. Climate History at the National Agricultural Library
authors: Alan M. Fusonie; William L. Hauser
abstract: The purpose of this essay is to present a selective view of research materials both print and non-print relative to the development of weather and agriculture in the holdings of the National Agricultural Library (NAL). In the 1941 Yearbook of Agricu/ture entitled Climate and Man, Claude R. Wickard, then Secretary of Agriculture, said Next to crop prices, nothing is more important to the farmers' business than the weather, (Fig 1.)1 The tradition of the importance of weather can be found as far back as the early Greek and Roman agricultural writers: Cato, Varro, Pliny, Palladius. For example, Junius Moderatus Columella, in his work Husbandry. In Twelve Books: And His Book Concerning Trees (1745X, provides extensive information on astrology and weather conditions.2 In volume one of Napier Shaw's secondary work entitled Manual of Meteorology (1932), there is an historical overview of the early development of the subject.3 Another work of note is W. J. Humphrey's The Way of Weather: A Cultural Survey of Meteorology (1942).4 American meteorology reportedly began with Reverend John Campa-
